inspector, each and every day the event is in operation. Temporary food
service establishment booths not staffed by a certified food supervisor that
are able to prove their identity, will be closed. Inspections shall be in
accordance section 5-62 of this code. Inspection fees are set forth in
section 13-1 of this code and shall be paid by the special event operator.



(Ord. 2012-25, § 1, 9-24-2012)



Sec. 3-128.  Conduct Of Audience; Overcrowding:



   (a)   The audience of any special event must be orderly and quiet at
all times, and it shall be unlawful for any person attending such special
event to create a disturbance in the audience.



   (b)   It shall be unlawful to permit or gather such a crowd to
witness any such special event as to create a dangerous condition because of
fire or other risks.



(Ord. 2012-25, § 1, 9-24-2012)



Sec. 3-129.  Indecent Shows:



   It shall be unlawful for any person to present, exhibit, conduct or
take part in any indecent show, theatrical, play, motion picture exhibition
or other form of public amusement or show.



(Ord. 2012-25, § 1, 9-24-2012)



Sec. 3-130.  Inciting Riot Or Disturbance:



   It shall be unlawful to present any public amusement or show of any
kind which tends to or is calculated to cause or promote any riot or
disturbance.



(Ord. 2012-25, § 1, 9-24-2012)



Sec. 3-131.  Penalty:



   Any person violating any provision of this division shall be fined not
less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00). A separate and distinct offense shall be held to have been
committed each day any person continues to violate any of the provisions
hereof.



(Ord. 2012-25, § 1, 9-24-2012)



Secs. 3-132–3-150.   Reserved:



DIVISION 2. AUTOMATIC AMUSEMENT DEVICES AND ELECTRONIC GAMES



Sec. 3-151.  Definitions:



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Amusement Devices And/Or Electronic Games: Any machine not requiring a
federal or state gambling stamp which, upon the insertion of a coin, slug,
token, plate or disc, may be operated by the public generally for the use as
a game, entertainment or amusement, whether or not registering a score. It
shall include, but not be limited to, such devices as jukeboxes, any form of
electronic games played with electrically operated devices upon a table or
board having holes, pockets, cups or electrically activated devices that are
actuated by any object or electrical contacts, electrical impulse and/or
cathode-type games, and all games, operations or transactions similar thereto
under whatever name by which they may be indicated.



   Flipper Ball Games: Any amusement device which moves a ball by use of a
form of flipper propellant which scores points as it rolls down or across
surfaces among pins and targets.



   Juke Box: any instrument containing one or more phonograph record,
compact discs, or DVDs operated by means of tokens or coins.



   Pinball Games; Any amusement device in which a ball propelled by a
plunger scores points as it rolls down or across a slanting surface among
pins and targets.



   Slot Machine: Any device not a gambling device, operated by means of
tokens or coins, which shows pictures, numbers or symbols, singly or in
combinations, as a result of operations.



   Table Games: Any device, whether controlled by skill or chance, for the
operation of a game, pastime or contest by the manipulation of a marble,
sphere or of objects or figures, or by controlling the movements of the same
or setting them in motion by mechanical means.



(Ord. 2012-25, § 1, 9-24-2012)



Sec. 3-152.  Table Games:



   It shall be unlawful to maintain or expose for public use any table
games, or amusement devices operated with a token or coin or for the use of
which a fee is charged, without first obtaining a license therefore. License
fees are set forth in section 13-1 of this code.



(Ord. 2012-25, § 1, 9-24-2012)



Sec. 3-153.  Slot Machines:



   It shall be unlawful to maintain or expose for public use any slot
machine, operated with a slug or coin, for the use or operation of which a
fee is charged, without having first obtained a license therefore. License
fees are set forth in section 13-1 of this code.



(Ord. 2012-25, § 1, 9-24-2012)



Sec. 3-154.  Jukeboxes:



   It shall be unlawful to maintain or expose for public use any
phonograph, compact disc player, or DVD player, operated with a token or
coin, without first obtaining a license therefore. License fees are set forth
in section 13-1 of this code.



(Ord. 2012-25, § 1, 9-24-2012)



Sec. 3-155.  License Required:



   (a)   No person shall own, place, keep, maintain, operate or permit
any electronic game or automatic amusement device in any building or place
within the village for use by the public without there first having been
obtained a license for each such device, and such license will be issued only
to those who operate a business within the village, licensed by the village
or state, and who will use such game or device as a subordinate part of such
primary business.



   (b)   No license shall be issued for any electronic game or
automatic amusement device if the premises and primary license of the
applicant do not fully comply first with the requirements of this code.



   (c)   A license shall not be transferable from person to person, nor
place to place, and shall be usable only at the place and by the licensee
designated in the license.



   (d)   No license issued hereunder shall permit the operation of any
automatic amusement device at any place or in any manner which will disturb
the peace and quiet of persons outside the licensed premises.



(Ord. 2012-25, § 1, 9-24-2012)



Sec. 3-156.  Specific Regulations:



   (a)   Except as otherwise provided in this division:



      (1)   Any place of business, or any place of any character of
public resort, may have the number of machines as determined by the authority
having jurisdiction (AHJ). The AHJ shall make a determination based upon the
square footage and maximum occupancy of the location, and the safety, health
and welfare of the community.



      (2)   Adult supervision (minimum twenty-one (21) years of age)
shall be maintained on business premises during times amusement devices and
games are in operation,



   (b)   Any person or corporation violating this section shall be
fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00). A separate and distinct offense shall be held to
have been committed each day any person continues to violate any of the
provisions hereof.



(Ord. 2012-25, § 1, 9-24-2012)



Sec. 3-157.  Applicability Of Other Provisions:



   Automatic amusement devices and electronic games shall be subject to
the provisions of this division and other applicable codes and ordinance
provisions of the village.



(Ord. 2012-25, § 1, 9-24-2012)



Sec. 3-158.  Amusement And Vending Operator’s License:



   (a)   No person shall own, place, keep, maintain, operate or permit
any location containing amusement devices and/or electronic games without
having obtained a license. Licenses may not be transferred to other machines.
The license fee will be as set forth in section 13-1 of this code per year,
in addition to the established fee per device.



   (b)   No person shall allow unlicensed operators and/or machines in
the place of business.



   (c)   Any person or corporation violating this section shall be
fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00). A separate and distinct offense shall be held to
have been committed each day any person continues to violate any of the
provisions hereof.



(Ord. 2012-25, § 1, 9-24-2012)



Sec. 3-159.   Video Arcades:



   (a)   No person shall own, place, keep, maintain, operate or permit
any business conducted strictly for the purposes of automatic amusement
devices and electronic games without having obtained a license. A Video
Arcade is defined as a business in which more than fifty percent (50%) of the
gross revenues are obtained from automatic amusement devices and electronic
games.



   (b)   The license fee for a video arcade shall be as set forth in
section 13-1 of this code per year, in addition to other license fees as
required by this code.



   (c)   No more than three (3) video arcade licenses shall be issued
by the village.



   (d)   Hours of operation are not limited, but the licensee shall be
responsible for the curfew hours of minors in his or her establishment.



(Ord. 2012-25, § 1, 9-24-2012)



Sec. 3-160.   Businesses Utilizing Coin-Operated Equipment:



   (a)   All businesses utilizing coin-operated equipment shall be
required to post prominently in the business establishment the name and phone
number of a person to contact in the event of a customer losing money or
receiving inadequate service from the coin-operated equipment.



   (b)   Any owner of such establishment shall make arrangements so
that the above phone number is manned during the hours of the business. Any
such complaint or inquiry shall result in timely response from the license
holder.



(Ord. 2012-25, § 1, 9-24-2012)



Secs. 3-161–3-175.   Reserved:



ARTICLE VI.  CLEANERS AND DYERS1



1  65 ILCS 5/11-42-8.



Sec. 3-176.  Definitions:



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Cleaning And Dyeing Establishment: Any place or vehicle where the
service of dry cleaning, wet cleaning as a process incidental to dry
cleaning, dyeing, spotting or finishing any fabric is rendered for hire, or
is sold, resold or offered for sale or resale.



   Cleaning Plant: Any cleaning and dyeing establishment equipped to
perform dry cleaning.



   Dry Cleaning: The process of cleaning fabrics by immersion and
agitation, or by immersion only, in volatile solvents, including, but not by
way of limitation, solvents of petroleum distillate type, the coal tar
distillate type, and the chlorinated hydrocarbon type, and processes
incidental thereto, including, but without limitation, spotting, cleaning,
wet cleaning and finishing.



   Fabric: Any article of wearing apparel, household furnishing, rugs,
textiles, fur and leather.



   Finishing: The process of pressing and/or reshaping any fabric, which
is designed to restore as nearly as possible the shape, dimension and contour
of such fabric.



   Proprietor: Any person by and/or for whom a cleaning plant is operated.



   Retail Outlet: Any cleaning and dyeing establishment located within the
village where dry cleaning is sold, solicited or offered for sale, directly
to the retail customer, and also includes any automobile, truck or other
vehicle operated within the village from which dry cleaning is sold,
solicited or offered for sale, directly to the retail consumer.



   Retailer: Any person or member of the cleaning and dyeing trade by or
for whom a retail outlet is operated.



   Spotting: The process designed to remove spots or stains which remain
in a fabric after it has been subjected to the other processes of dry
cleaning.



(Code 1972, § 3-4-1)



Sec. 3-177.  Violation:



   It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain, manage or operate any
cleaning and dyeing establishment, cleaning plant or retail outlet within the
village, for which a certificate of inspection has not been issued, or upon
which a certificate of inspection has been revoked or suspended, during time
of suspension, or any employee of any such person employed in the operation,
management or maintenance of any such establishment, plant or outlet to
assist or aid therein. It shall further be unlawful to wilfully make any
false statement in connection with any application for a certificate of
inspection or petition for rehearing, and any proprietor or retailer who
shall represent any fabric as dry-cleaned or finished dry-cleaned, which does
not comply with the requirements of this article and the provisions of this
code, shall be subject to penalty as provided in this code.



(Code 1969, Ch. 11, Art. 4; Code 1972, § 3-4-12)



Sec. 3-178.  Inspection; Certificate:



   To promote and protect the public health of the village and to remove
and prevent fire hazards, every cleaning and dyeing establishment, cleaning
plant and retail outlet located within the village and every cleaning and
dyeing establishment, which is not located within the village but has a
retail outlet operating in the village shall be regularly inspected and shall
obtain a certificate of inspection as hereinafter provided.



(Code 1972, § 3-4-2)



Sec. 3-179.  Sanitation1:



   Every building or premises used or occupied by a cleaning and dyeing
establishment, cleaning plant or retail outlet located within the village or
used or occupied by a cleaning and dyeing plant not located in the village
but which has a retail outlet in the village shall be kept in a clean and
sanitary condition as to its floors, side walls, ceilings, woodwork and
fixtures and as to the tools, machinery, equipment and storage facilities
used and kept in any such building or premises. At regular intervals and at
such other times as may be deemed necessary and as shall be specified by the
health officer, the floors, side walls, ceilings, woodwork and fixtures of
any such building and premises and the tools, machinery, equipment and
storage facilities used or kept thereon shall be washed or sprayed with a
disinfectant in solution or other liquid form or vapor approved by the health
officer.



(Code 1972, § 3-4-3)



1 See Ch. 5 of this Code.



Sec. 3-180.  Employment Of Diseased Persons:



   No person affected or afflicted with tuberculosis or any other
infectious or communicable disease shall be employed in any dry-cleaning
establishment, cleaning plant or retail outlet located within the village, or
in any cleaning and dyeing establishment or cleaning plant which is not
located in the village but which has a retail outlet therein. The health
officer of the village may require each employee of such cleaning and dyeing
plant, cleaning plant or retail outlet to be examined by a licensed and
practicing physician and may require any proprietor or retailer to file in
the office of the health officer a certificate of health and freedom from
tuberculosis or other infectious or communicable disease for each person
employed by him as such proprietor or retailer, which certificate shall be
signed by a licensed and practicing physician.



(Code 1972, § 3-4-4)



Sec. 3-181.  Restrictions:



   (a)   No finished or unfinished dry cleaning sold, solicited or
offered for sale within the village shall show, upon the dry-cleaned fabric
being rerinsed in water-white solvent (one gallon to one pound of garment
weight), sufficient dirt or soil residue or other foreign deposits sufficient
to darken dry solvent below fifteen (15) saybelt chorometer.



   (b)   Finished dry cleaning sold, solicited or offered for sale
within the village shall be free from solvent and chemical odors.



   (c)   No chemical or other substance which is poisonous, injurious
or unwholesome to human beings and which is not essential to the service or
process of dry cleaning, dyeing, spotting or finishing shall be used in
rendering any such service or performing any such process in any cleaning and
dyeing plant located within the village or in any cleaning and dyeing plant
or cleaning plant which is not located within the village but has a retail
outlet within the village.



   (d)   In case any such chemical or other substance which is
poisonous, injurious or unwholesome to human beings is used by any such
cleaning and dyeing establishment or cleaning plant in rendering any such
service or performing any such process essential thereto, then such chemical
or other substance shall be completely removed from the fabric drycleaned,
dyed or spotted or finished or such chemical or other substance shall be
completely and entirely neutralized and rendered harmless and innoxious to
human beings before such fabric is permitted to leave such establishment or
plant for delivery to the person entitled to the possession thereof upon
completion of the process.



(Code 1972, § 3-4-5)



Sec. 3-182.  Inspection For Fire Hazards:



   The chief of the fire department of the village shall have the right to
enter any building or premises situated within the village and used or
occupied by any cleaning and dyeing establishment, cleaning plant or retail
outlet in order to examine same and to determine whether or not such building
and premises, or any material, article or fabric drycleaned, dyed, spotted or
finished as received, used, kept, maintained or stored in such building or
premises, conforms to the fire hazard regulations within the village.



(Code 1972, § 3-4-6)



   Cross reference-Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 4.



Sec. 3-183.  Application; Certificate Of Inspection:



   (a)   Every proprietor or retailer of a cleaning and dyeing
establishment or cleaning plant located within the village and of each
cleaning and dyeing establishment and cleaning plant which is not located
within the village but which has a retail outlet in the village shall make
written application in duplicate to the village clerk for the issuance to
applicant of a certificate of inspection.



   (b)   In the case of cleaning and dyeing establishments and cleaning
plants located within the village, one (1) copy of the application shall be
delivered to the health officer and the other copy shall be delivered to the
chief of the fire department of the village. Within fifteen (15) days after
the filing of the application the health officer and the chief of the fire
department shall cause an inspection to be made of the building and premises
on which such cleaning and dyeing establishment or cleaning plant is located,
together with the floors, sidewalls, ceilings, woodwork and fixtures of any
such building or premises and the tools, machinery, equipment and storage
facilities used or kept thereon, and of any delivery trucks to and from such
cleaning and dyeing establishment, cleaning plant or retail outlet operated
in conjunction therewith. The health officer may require health certificates
to be filed for each employee of the applicant within fifteen (15) days after
such application is filed or at any time thereafter, and the health officer
may also require that any such employee be examined by a competent licensed
physician practicing within the village. Upon their respective inspections
being completed, the health officer and chief of the fire department shall
determine whether such establishment, plant or outlet mentioned in such
application and examined by them is used, maintained and operated in
conformity with the provisions of this article and in case their
determination is in the negative shall deny the application. In case the
health officer and chief of the fire department are not able to agree, they
shall submit the facts disclosed by their respective investigations to the
board of trustees, which body, upon being fully advised, shall decide whether
or not such application shall be allowed or denied.



   (c)   In the case of cleaning and dyeing establishments or cleaning
plants which are not located within the village, but which have a retail
outlet located therein, one (1) copy of the application shall be delivered to
the health officer. Within fifteen (15) days after filing of the application,
the health officer shall make or cause to be made an inspection of the
building or premises on which such cleaning and dyeing establishment or
cleaning plant is located, together with the floors, sidewalls, ceilings,
woodwork and fixtures of any such building or premises and the tools,
machinery, equipment and storage facilities used or kept thereon and may
cause an inspection to be made of any delivering of fabrics to and from any
such establishment or plant and retail outlet located within the village and
operated in conjunction therewith. The health officer may require health
certificates to be filed for each person employed by the applicant in such
establishment or plant and in any such retail outlet located within the
village within fifteen (15) days after any such application is filed or at
any time thereafter and may require that any such employee be examined by a
competent licensed and practicing physician. Upon the completion of such
inspection, the health officer shall determine whether such establishment or
plant, or outlet mentioned in such application and examined by him is used,
maintained and operated in conformity with the provisions of this article and
in case his determination is in the affirmative shall allow such application,
and in case his determination is in the negative shall deny such application.
Any such applicant whose application is denied may take an appeal from the
decision of the health officer to the village board.



   (d)   In case of retail outlets not situated in the same building or
premises with a cleaning and dyeing establishment or cleaning plant an
inspection made under the direction of the health officer and the chief of
the fire department for the purpose of determining whether same is used,
maintained and operated in conformity with the provisions of this article,
and a certificate of inspection shall issue upon the same conditions and in
the same manner as prescribed above for cleaning and dyeing establishments
and cleaning plants located within the village and the procedure upon an
application for such a certificate shall be in all respects the same as in
the case of such establishments or plants. Retail outlets situated on the
same premises as a cleaning and dyeing establishment or cleaning plant shall
be inspected at the same time and in the same manner as such establishment or
plant. Where several cleaning and dyeing establishments or cleaning plants
and/or retail outlets are operated by a single proprietor or in conjunction
with each other, a single application may be filed for certificate of
inspection for each such establishment, plant or retail outlet.



   (e)   All certificates of inspection shall be signed by the
president of the village.



   (f)   An applicant, if he so requests, shall be personally heard by
the officials or representatives of the village who are required to pass upon
his application, prior to the determination thereof, and upon appeal if he so
requests an applicant shall be heard by the village board prior to its
determination of his appeal.



   (g)   In case any application is denied either by the official or
officials to whom the same is presented in accordance with the provisions
hereof, or by the village board upon appeal thereto, the applicant whose
application is so denied may file a new application provided that such
application is accompanied with a statement under oath that the facts which
caused the denial of the previous application no longer exist.



(Code 1972, § 3-4-7; Ord. 2009-15, § 14, 6-22-2009)



Sec. 3-184.  Inspection Fees:



   (a)   At the time of filing an application for a certificate of
inspection for any cleaning and dyeing establishment or cleaning plant as
provided in section 3-183 and annually thereafter, the applicant shall pay to
the village an inspection fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) for the
inspection of any cleaning plant as defined in this article.



   (b)   An additional inspection fee shall be charged or paid for the
inspection of or issuance of a certificate of inspection for any retail
outlet situated in the same building or on the same premises as a cleaning
and dyeing establishment or cleaning plant in conjunction with which it is
operated. The inspection fee for any such retail outlet operated in
conjunction with such establishment or plant and not situated in the same
building or on the same premises shall be thirty-five dollars ($35.00) per
outlet, and for the purpose of this section, each automobile, truck or other
vehicle operated within the village from which any cleaning is sold,
solicited or offered for sale directly to the retail consumer, shall be
subject to inspection and to the inspection fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00)
as herein provided.



(Code 1972, § 3-4-8; Ord. 2009-15, § 14, 6-22-2009)



Sec. 3-185.  Term Of Certificate:



   Each certificate shall expire the last day of April next following the
date on which same is issued and application for renewal thereof shall be
filed on or before the first Monday of the month during which it will expire.
An inspection fee shall be paid to the village in the same amount as in the
case of the application for the issuance of the original certificate at the
time of the filing of an application for renewal. Upon the filing of an
application for renewal of a certificate and payment of the inspection fee,
such application shall beinvestigated and the establishment, plant or outlet,
and persons employed therein shall be inspected and investigated and the
procedure on such application for renewal shall be in all things the same as
in the case of the application for the original certificate and the
termination thereof.



(Code 1972, § 3-4-9; Ord. 2009-15, § 14, 6-22-2009)



Sec. 3-186.  Certificate Of Retail Outlet:



   A certificate of inspection shall not be issued to or for any retail
outlet until and unless each cleaning and dyeing establishment or cleaning
plant for which it is a retail outlet has been issued a certificate of
inspection, and revocation, suspension or expiration of the certificate of
inspection of any cleaning and dyeing establishment or cleaning plant shall
automatically act as a revocation, suspension or expiration respectively of
the certificate of inspection of each retail outlet located within the
village and for which it is a retail outlet.



(Code 1972, § 3-4-10)



Sec. 3-187.  Periodic Inspection; Revocation, Suspension:



   (a)   The health officer shall cause periodic investigations and
inspections to be made of cleaning and dyeing establishments, cleaning plants
and retail outlets for which certificates of inspection have been issued.



   (b)   Violation of any provision of this article shall be cause for
revocation or suspension of a certificate of inspection. Upon notice and
public hearing the health officer may revoke any certificate of inspection
heretofore issued or may suspend same for a period of not more than thirty
(30) days. An approval may be taken to the village board, from any decision
rendered by the health officer under the provisions of this section.



(Code 1972, § 3-4-11)



Secs. 3-188-3-205.  Reserved:



ARTICLE VII. SELF-SERVICE LAUNDRIES1



1  State law reference-Municipal regulation of laundries, Ill. Rev. Stat.
Ch. 24, § 11-42-8.



Sec. 3-206.  Definition:



   The term "self-service laundry" as used in this article shall mean any
establishment in which coin-operated facilities are available for washing
clothes or for drying clothes, or both, and which is open and available to
the general public for use.



(Code 1972, § 3-16-1)



Sec. 3-207.  License Required:



   It shall be unlawful to establish or operate any self-service laundry
in the village without first having secured a license therefor as herein
provided. Application for such license shall comply with the general
provisions relating to applications for licenses and permits.



(Code 1972, § 3-16-2)



Sec. 3-208.  Hours Of Operation:



   It shall be unlawful to keep any self-service laundry establishment
licensed in this article open for business between the hours of 11:00 p.m.
and 7:00 a.m. unless there is an adult attendant in charge of the premises
during such hours.



(Ord. No. 61-12, 10-5-61; Code 1972, § 3-16-4)



Secs. 3-209-3-240.  Reserved:



ARTICLE VIII. CHILD CARE HOMES1



1  State law reference-Child Care Act of 1969, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 23, §
2211 et seq.



Sec. 3-241.  Definition:



   As used in this article, the word "home" is hereby defined to mean any
institution, place or family used for the reception or care of three (3) or
more infants or children apart from their parents either permanently or for
any period of the day. A "home" is further defined to mean any institution
used for the reception or care of persons who are dependent or not capable of
properly caring for themselves, and shall be understood to include homes for
the aged or infirm, orphan asylums, half-orphan asylums, refuges,
convalescents and shelters.



(Code 1972, § 3-10-1)



Sec. 3-242.  Violations:



   Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be
fined as provided in this code; in the event of a conviction of any such
person for a violation relating to the safety and accommodation of inmates,
it shall be the duty of the health officer, and he is hereby authorized and
empowered to close such home and cause its vacation pending the repairs,
alterations or additions necessary to make it safe and proper for the
occupancy of its inmates, and to make it comply with the terms of this
article.



(Code 1969, Ch. 11, Art. 11; Code 1972, § 3-10-13)



Sec. 3-243.  License-Required:



   It shall be unlawful for any person other than the regularly
constituted authorities of the United States, the county, the village or any
association or institution for the care of children which has been
accredited, certified or licensed by the state pursuant to an act of the
legislature, to regulate the treatment and control of dependent, neglected
and delinquent children, to conduct or operate any home within the village,
without first obtaining a license therefor.



(Code 1972, § 3-10-2)



Sec. 3-244.  Same-Application:



   (a)   An application for a license under this article shall be made
in conformity with the general requirements of this code relating to
applications for licenses. The applicant shall also file an application with
the board of health and shall state the location or proposed location of the
home, the purpose for which it is to be conducted, the accommodations for the
inmates thereof, the nature and kind of case, instruction or benefits given
or proposed to be given therein, the names and addresses of the officials or
board of officials conducting, managing or maintaining the home, the name of
the superintendent or person in charge of the home, the name and address of
the chief physician, surgeon or attending physician or surgeon, or the names
and addresses of the board of physicians or surgeons attending therein if
there is such a board.



   (b)   The health officer, upon presentation of such application,
shall make or cause to be made strict inquiry into the facts set out in such
application, to determine whether such home is or is intended to be so
conducted as to afford proper accommodations for the care of the persons
received or proposed to be received therein, and that the officials or board
of officials or intended officials thereof give or are under agreement
thereafter to give such care, instruction or benefits as does or will render
them or him if there is only one (1) personally responsible for the care,
instruction or benefits given or to be given to all inmates therein, that the
superintendent or person in charge thereof is a person of good moral
character and has sufficient knowledge, experience and ability to properly
conduct such home, and that such home complies or is intended to comply with
all laws, provisions of this code, and rules and requirements which shall be
in force concerning the management and control of such homes.



(Code 1972, § 3-10-3)



Sec. 3-245.  License Fee Exemption:



   (a)   Homes which are operated without a charge being made for the
care of inmates shall be exempt from the payment of a license fee. Operators
of such homes shall apply for the license, which application shall be
accompanied by an affidavit stating that no charge is made for the care of
inmates.



   (b)   After investigation by the health officer and upon his
recommendation any home that is not operated for gain, but where a charge is
made for the care of patients, shall be exempt from payment of the annual
license fee provided. Such exemption shall continue only for the duration of
the license period.



(Code 1972, § 3-10-4)



Sec. 3-246.  Frontage Consents:



   (a)   No village license shall be issued to any person to operate or
conduct a home in any block in which two-thirds of the buildings fronting on
both sides of the street on or along which the proposed home may face are
devoted exclusively to residence purposes, unless the owners of a majority of
the frontage in such block and the owners of a majority of the frontage on
the opposite side of the street on or along which the building faces, consent
in writing to the operation or conducting of any such home in such block;
provided, however, that no new frontage consents shall be required if such
home has heretofore been licensed by the village as a hospital, home or
nursery at the present location.



   (b)   Such written consents of the majority of such property owners
shall be filed with the health officer before a license shall be issued for
the operating or conducting of any such home.



(Code 1972, § 3-10-5)



Sec. 3-247.  Building requirements.



   The building used as a home shall comply with the building provisions
and the fire regulations of the village.



(Code 1972, § 3-10-6)



Sec. 3-248.  Sanitation, living conditions.



   (a)   Every home shall comply with the requirements in the building
provisions of this Code relating to ventilation, floor space per patient,
exits, fire escapes and stairways.



   (b)   Each ward or wing in such home shall have running water
furnished in one (1) or more places either in the ward or convenient thereto
so that the same may be adequate and convenient to occupants thereof. The
plumbing, water closets, bathrooms and other sanitary appliances and
equipment shall be constructed in accordance with the building provisions of
this Code relating thereto. The floor of the cellar or basement in any
building used as a home shall be properly cemented so as to be watertight.



   (c)   All homes, including the culinary department, dining rooms,
laundry, laboratory, morgue and postmortem rooms connected with the same,
shall be equipped from April 15 to November 15 with doors, screens and other
appliances necessary for the exclusion of flies.



(Code 1972, § 3-10-7)



   Cross reference-Health and sanitation, Ch. 5.



Sec. 3-249.  Isolation rooms for diseased persons, temporary care of the
dead.



   (a)   Each home building shall be provided with a suitable room or
rooms, approved by the health officer, to be used for the isolation of cases
of contagious, infectious, epidemic or communicable diseases that may be
found in the home, until such time as the persons suffering from such
contagious diseases shall be removed in accordance with the rules and
regulations of the health officer. The room or rooms thus provided for the
isolation of contagious disease cases shall have separate toilet facilities
and a stationary washstand with a supply of running water.



   (b)   There shall be provided, also, in each such building a
suitable room or rooms approved by the board of health for the proper care of
the dead pending their removal.



(Code 1972, § 3-10-8)



Sec. 3-250.  Removal of the dead.



   No person acting as superintendent or manager, or who is otherwise in
charge or control of any home, nor any person connected with any home in any
capacity whatsoever as nurse, physician or attendant shall order, permit or
allow the body of any inmate or person who has been under care in such home,
and who shall have died therein, to be removed from such home at any time
within twenty-four (24) hours after the hour of death, unless the removal of
such body has been authorized in writing by some member of the immediate
family of such deceased person or by some other person legally authorized to
order or permit such a removal; and no such body shall be removed otherwise
than in accordance with the provisions of this Code concerning the removal of
dead bodies; provided, that no body shall be kept at any home longer than
thirty-six (36) hours after death without permission from the health officer.



(Code 1972, § 3-10-9)



   State law references-Coroner inquests, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 31, § 10 et
seq.; sudden infant death syndrome, autopsy, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 31, § 10.2a.



Sec. 3-251.  Records.



   (a)   Every home shall keep a complete record of all inmates
admitted to the institution, which record shall show the name, address, age,
sex, marital status and the date of admission and discharge or disposition of
each inmate of such home. In the case of infants or children, the records
shall show the name and address of the person from whom received, so far as
can be ascertained, the name, address, nationality, religion and occupation
of the parents of such infant or child, and the reason for its being brought
to such home.



   (b)   In the case of the discharge or disposition of any infant or
child or other dependent person from such home, the record shall show the
name and address of the person or institution to whom or to which such inmate
was given or delivered, and a statement as to whether or not such person to
whom such child was given was the parent or guardian, or had legally adopted
such infant or child.



   (c)   Such records shall be open at all times to the inspection of
the health officer or his duly authorized representatives.



(Code 1972, § 3-10-10)



   State law reference-Records kept by child care facilities, Ill. Rev.
Stat. Ch. 23, § 2225.



Sec. 3-252.  Reports.



   (a)   It shall be the duty of every person conducting or operating
any home within the village to make a report to the health officer daily by
telephone and by mail of all epidemic, communicable or contagious diseases.
Such daily reports shall contain the names and residences of all persons
suffering from any of these diseases, together with such other information as
may be required by the board of health or shall be of use in aiding the board
of health in stamping out the diseases.



   (b)   It shall be the further duty of all such persons conducting or
operating a home to report to the health officer within twenty-four (24)
hours after the disposition, other than by death or discharge in the custody
of a parent, of any infant or child born in or admitted to such home, which
report shall give the name, age and sex of the child thus disposed of, the
name and address of the mother, if known, the name and address of the father,
if known, and the name and address of the person or institution to whom or to
which such child was given or delivered, and a statement as to whether the
person to whom such child was given was the parent or guardian or had legally
adopted such infant or child.



   (c)   It shall be the further duty of all such persons to make
reports to the health officer on or before the fifth day of each calendar
month, showing a complete record of such home during the preceding month,
including the names and addresses of inmates dying during the month, the
cause of each death, and such other information as may be specified by the
board of health, or necessary to an intelligent supervision of the
establishment.



   (d)   All reports required under this section shall be made in full
upon forms furnished for that purpose by the health officer, and shall be
signed by the chief physician, superintendent or officer in charge of such
home.



(Code 1972, § 3-10-11)



Sec. 3-253.  Inspections.



   Every home shall at all times be open to inspection by the health
officer and the commissioner of buildings whenever and as often as they shall
deem proper.



(Code 1972, § 3-10-12)



Secs. 3-254-3-270.  Reserved.



ARTICLE IX. JUNKYARDS1



1  Cross references-Health and sanitation, Ch. 5; abandoned vehicles, §
6-41 et seq.; ratproofing, § 7-226 et seq.
State law references-Junk dealer purchasing from minor, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch.
23, §§ 2366, 2367; municipal powers as to places of business of dealers in
junk, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-42-3; junkyards and scrap processing
facilities near certain highways, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 121, § 461 et seq.;
Copper Purchase Registration Law, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 121 1/2, § 321 et seq.



Sec. 3-271.  Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Junk means old or scrap copper, brass, rope, rags, batteries, paper,
trash, rubber debris, waste, or junked, dismantled or wrecked automobiles, or
parts thereof, iron, steel, and other old or scrap ferrous or nonferrous
material.



   Junkyard 1: Any building where junk is bought, sold, bartered or
exchanged, either at wholesale or retail, or any building where junk is
collected, received, stored or held in possession for resale, barter or
exchange, either at wholesale or retail, or any building where junk is held
for the convenience of the owner of the junk.



(Code 1972, § 3-11-1)



1 415 ILCS 95/2.



Sec. 3-272.  Waiting Period Prior To Disposal Of Items:



   No junkyard shall resell, smelt, vulcanize or change the identity of
any article it has received by purchase or otherwise, until at least five (5)
days after such article was received, unless the junk is held for the
convenience of the owner of the junk.



(Code 1972, § 3-11-2)



Sec. 3-273.  Dealers Acting As Pawnbrokers2:



   No junk dealer shall receive any article in pledge or pawn, nor shall
any such dealer loan or advance any sums of money on the security of any
article or thing.



(Code 1972, § 3-11-3)



2  205 ILCS 510/1.



Sec. 3-274.  Purchases From Minors3:



   No dealer in junk shall receive by purchase or otherwise any article or
thing from any minor.



(Code 1972, § 3-11-4)



3  720 ILCS 345/1; 65 ILCS 5/11-42-3.



Sec. 3-275.  Stolen Property4:



   Persons dealing in junk will refrain from purchasing any article or
thing suspected of being stolen or known by



such dealer to be stolen. Every junk dealer who shall receive or be in
possession of any goods, articles, things or junk which may have been stolen
shall forthwith on demand exhibit the same to any member of the department of
police or to any member of the board of trustees, and if any such articles or
things are suspected by the dealer of having been stolen, and such suspicion
originated after such article or thing was in the possession of the dealer,
he or she will notify the department of police immediately.



(Code 1972, § 3-11-5)



4  720 ILCS 5/15-6, 5/16-1.



Sec. 3-276.  Inspections:



   The places of business of any junk dealer shall be open for inspection
by the police department during reasonable hours. Whenever any owner or agent
of the owner, by written sworn statement filed with the chief of police or
any member of the board of trustees, states that he or she has reason to
believe that certain stolen goods or things specifically described in such
sworn statement are in the possession of the junk dealer, any member of the
police department shall have the right to inspect the premises of the
wholesale junk dealer at a reasonable hour and view all junk which has been
purchased, received, collected or stored in the premises occupied by such
business.



(Code 1972, § 3-11-6)



Sec. 3-277.  License Required; Fee:



   No person shall engage in the business of junkyard until a license is
first obtained from the village board. All applications shall be addressed to
the board of trustees and the location of such junkyard approved by the
board. The fee for such license shall be as set forth in section 13-1 of this
code.



(Code 1969, Ch. 11, Art. 12; Code 1972, § 3-11-8; Ord. 98-12, § 2,
3-23-1998)



Sec. 3-278.  Revocation Of License:



   The license of any junk dealer convicted of receiving stolen property
shall be revoked by the president and board of trustees immediately after
such conviction. If any officer, stockholder or employee of a corporation
licensed to deal in junk is convicted of receiving stolen property, the
license of such corporation will be revoked immediately unless such
corporation shows satisfactory evidence to the president and board of
trustees that such person has disposed of his or her entire interest in such
corporation and has completely severed his or her connection with such
corporation. No person or corporation whose license is revoked under this
section will again receive a license to deal in junk for one (1) year after
conviction of receiving stolen property, and then only upon the approval of
the president and board of trustees.



(Code 1972, § 3-11-7)



Secs. 3-279-3-295.  Reserved:



ARTICLE X.  PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS AND CANVASSERS



DIVISION 1. IN GENERAL



Sec. 3-296.  Introduction:



   This article establishes regulations governing the activities of
peddlers, solicitors and canvassers, which typically involve a single person,
or a group of persons working in tandem, attempting make random but
individualized personal contact with another at a home, commercial
establishment or a public place. The regulations codified herein are the
by-product of the village's efforts to constitutionally harmonize the
interests of all parties engaged in or affected by peddler, solicitor and
canvasser activities. The village approached the subject-matter with a
balanced design, taking into consideration both the significant interests of
government and the rights of individuals to publicly express themselves in a
variety of ways. The objective was to create a scheme that limited the role
of government to those instances deemed necessary to protect its interests,
thereby entrusting to those targeted by speech with the primary
responsibility of electing when and how they will participate in, or be the
recipient of, any particular message. The village implemented four (4)
governmentally-directed proscriptions expedient to this objective: (i) it
removed discretion from decision-makers charged with administering the
process; (ii) it codified clear and unambiguous provisions that were not
susceptible to capricious interpretation; (iii) it eliminated any need to
inquire into the content of any message associated with an activity; and (iv)
it mandated alternative opportunities for communication be made available
when the primary method was unlawful or unavailable.



(Ord. 2014-15, § 1, 10-13-2014)



Sec. 3-297.  Definitions:



   The following words, terms, and phrases, and their derivations, when
used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this
section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Canvasser means any person who attempts to make personal contact of
another, but excluding focused picketing of any sort, for the primary purpose
of (1) attempting to enlist support for or against a particular religion,
philosophy, ideology, political party, issue, candidate, event, idea or other
matter, even if incidental to such purpose the canvasser accepts
contributions for or against such cause, and/or (2) distributes a handbill,
flyer, pamphlet, or any other type of literature, advertising a
non-commercial event, service or ideal. A canvasser shall also include any
person who seeks charitable contributions for a patriotic, philanthropic,
religious, social, health, welfare, benevolent, educational, civic, cultural
or fraternal cause or ideology.



   Canvassing Activities means the actions of a canvasser, excepting those
conducted on the premises of the canvasser.



   Contributions mean and include alms, money, subscriptions, property, or
any other types of donations.



   Corporate Authorities means the mayor and board of trustees of the
Village of Justice.



   Mayor means the mayor/village president of the Village or his or her
designee.



   Peddler means any person who, not having been invited by another,
carries or transports goods, wares, merchandise or personal property of any
nature and offers the same for sale (except on premises where that person is
employed or resides). A Peddler shall also include any person who solicits
orders and, as a separate transaction, makes a subsequent delivery to a
purchaser.



   Peddling Activities means the actions of a peddler.



   Person means any person, firm, corporation, association, club, society
or other organization.



   Peace Officer means a duly appointed police officer of the Village of
Justice.



   Solicitor means any person who, not having been invited by another
(except on premises where that person is employed or resides), takes or
attempts to take orders for the sale of goods, merchandise, wares, or other
personal property of any nature for future delivery, or for services
performed in the future. A solicitor shall also include any person who
distributes handbills and flyers advertising a commercial event or service.



   Soliciting Activities means the actions of a solicitor.



   Street means any public street, highway or other thoroughfare primarily
intended for use by motor vehicles. Street shall mean the entire area between
a curb-cut, including but not limited to any and all medians and crosswalks.



   Street Solicitation means the act of soliciting, peddling or canvassing
in and on streets within the corporate limits of the Village of Justice.



   Village means the Village of Justice.



   Village Clerk means the village clerk of the Village of Justice or his
or her designee.



   Village Official means an appointed official of the Village of Justice
including any duly appointed peace officer, code-enforcement officer or
department head.



(Ord. 2014-15, § 1, 10-13-2014)



Sec. 3-298.  Purpose:



   The regulations codified in this article are intended to:



      (1)   Preserve the peace, tranquility and privacy of the home,
and certain other environments where individuals may be captive or
particularly sensitive to unwanted intrusion;



      (2)   Deter and mitigate unsolicited and unwanted intrusions
to personal space and property;



      (3)   Detect and prevent crime;



      (4)   Prevent damage or destruction of property;



      (5)   Preserve public funds;



      (6)   Conserve the condition of the environment;



      (7)   Prevent visual blight;



      (8)   Reduce distractions to those using the streets;



      (9)   Enable the free and efficient flow of pedestrian and
vehicle traffic; and



      (10)   Protect the health, safety and welfare of all persons
affected by this article.



(Ord. 2014-15, § 1, 10-13-2014)



Sec. 3-299.  Standards of Administration and Enforcement:



   The following provisions are intended to serve as a guideline to
village officials charged with administering or enforcing the provisions of
this article.



      (1)   A village official shall seek clarification from his or
her immediate supervisor if he or she is uncertain as to how or if a certain
provision of this article should be interpreted or enforced. If uncertainty
remains after attempts for clarification have been made, the village official
shall interpret the specific provision at issue in a manner that is least
intrusive to the right to engage in the questioned activity.



      (2)   A village official shall seek acceptable alternatives
when the provisions of this article prohibit an activity from taking place at
a specific time or place, or in the manner requested or proposed.



      (3)   A village official shall not be concerned with the
substance of the content of any particular message to be conveyed through an
activity governed by this article. This does not mean, however, that a
cursory examination would be improper when making a determination as to how
to characterize the activities in question.



      (4)   A village official shall attempt to use, when reasonable
under the circumstances, an escalating response approach to obtain compliance
with the provisions of this article. A village official shall: (i) inform an
individual of his or her non-compliance; (ii) seek voluntary acquiescence to
an alternative; (iii) seek voluntary cessation of the activities; (iv) direct
that the specific activity be stopped, and a warn that a failure to obey may
result in the issuance of a citation or arrest; (iv) issue a citation; and,
(v) make an arrest. A village official should never feel an obligation to
strictly adhere to an escalating response approach when circumstances dictate
that such an approach would be unreasonable, futile, or endanger the safety
of any person or property.



(Ord. 2014-15, § 1, 10-13-2014)



Sec. 3-300.  Penalties:



   Any person found to be in violation of any provision of this article
shall be fined not less two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), nor more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each violation or day
said violation is permitted to continue, shall constitute a separate offense.



(Ord. 2014-15, § 1, 10-13-2014)



Sec. 3-301.  Administration:



   Violations of this article may be administered by any means authorized
by the village code of the Village of Justice, including administrative
adjudication, and by any other means permitted by law. Nothing in this
article shall be interpreted to limit the actions or remedies available to
the village.



(Ord. 2014-15, § 1, 10-13-2014)



DIVISION 2. PERMIT PROVISIONS



Sec. 3-302.  Permit Requirements:



   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in peddling or
solicitation activities within the village without first obtaining a permit
issued by the village clerk.



(Ord. 2014-15, § 1, 10-13-2014)



Sec. 3-303.  Permit Application:



   Any person desirous of engaging in peddling or solicitation activities
in the village shall file with the village clerk an application in writing,
on a form to be furnished by the village clerk, which shall consist of the
following information:



      (1)   Name, address, age and telephone number of the
applicant, which shall be confirmed through the applicant's driver's license
or state identification card, articles of incorporation, or other legally
recognized form of identification;



      (2)   A brief description of the business or activity;



      (3)   If acting as an employee of an employer, the name,
address and telephone number of the employer; or if acting as an agent, the
name, address and telephone number of the principal who is being represented,
with credentials in writing establishing the relationship and the authority
of the employee or agent to act for the employer or principal, as the case
may be;



      (4)   A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been
convicted or pleaded guilty to a felony or misdemeanor, the nature of the
offense, and the date of the conviction or plea;



      (5)   A statement as to whether the applicant has had a permit
denied, suspended or revoked for noncompliance with this article in the past;



      (6)   Proof of possession of any license or permit which,
under federal, state or local law, the applicant is required to have in order
to conduct the proposed business, or which, under any such law, would exempt
the applicant from the licensing requirements of this article; and



      (7)   Two (2) photographs of the applicant which shall have
been taken within sixty (60) days immediately preceding the date of filing of
the application. The photographs shall be of a size common to a passport.



(Ord. 2014- 15, § 1, 10-13-2014)



Sec. 3-304.  Permit Fees:



   At the time the application is filed with the village clerk, the
applicant shall pay a fee to cover the cost of processing the application and
investigating the facts stated therein. The application fee shall be twenty
dollars ($20.00) and the permit fee shall be five dollars ($5.00) for each
solicitor and peddler.



(Ord. 2014-15, § 1, 10-13-2014)



Sec. 3-305.   Application Review and Issuance of Permit:



   (a)   Upon receipt of an application, the village clerk shall review
the application to determine if all of the information required by this
article is present. If the application has listed all of the information
necessary, and there exists no reason to deny the permit for the reasons set
forth in section 3-306, the village clerk shall issue the permit to the
applicant.



   (b)   Any permit issued pursuant to this article shall contain the
name, address and photograph of the permittee, the name of any employer or
principal, the class of permit issued, the date of issuance and the date of
expiration. The permit shall also contain a permit number (which shall be a
number matching a number listed on the application).



   (c)   The village clerk shall complete an application review and
advise an applicant of his or her decision within seventy-two (72) hours of
receipt of the application, excepting weekends and holidays. An applicant may
obtain his or her permit from village hall once advised that a decision to
grant the permit has been issued by the village clerk.



   (d)   If, upon the expiration of the seventy-two (72) hour review
period, the village clerk has not advised an applicant of his or her decision
to grant or deny a permit, an applicant may request, and the village clerk
shall be obligated to issue, a temporary permit.



   (e)   An applicant may commence activities under a temporary permit
once issued. If further review identifies a basis for which a permit should
be denied, an applicant shall be immediately notified by telephone that the
temporary permit is revoked and his or her application has been denied. If no
basis exists to deny a permit, the village clerk shall issue the permit upon
the applicant's return of the temporary permit. The temporary permit shall
expire two (2) days after the applicant is notified that a permit has been
issued. In no event shall an application review take longer than seven (7)
business days. At the expiration of seven (7) business days, and provided no
oral decision has been made concerning the issuance of the permit, the
applicant may request, and the village clerk shall be obligated to issue a
permit to the applicant. Once issued, the permit shall only be subject to
suspension or revocation as provided by sections 3-308 and 3-309 of this
article.



   (f)   The village clerk shall notify the applicant of his or her
decision to grant or deny a permit by the telephone number listed on the
application. The village clerk shall orally advise the applicant of the basis
for the denial.



   (g)   If an application is incomplete, the village clerk shall allow
the applicant an opportunity to provide the information necessary for his or
her review.



   (h)   In the case of a denial, the village clerk shall issue a
written decision advising the applicant why the permit was denied. The
written decision shall be mailed to the applicant via U.S. Mail at the
address contained on the application. The written decision shall be
postmarked no later than three (3) business days subsequent to the expiration
of the seventy-two (72) hour review period, or the oral advisement of a
denial of a permit, whichever is later.



   (i)   A denial of a permit may be appealed in the manner provided in
section 3-310 of this article.



   (j)   A record of all permits issued and denied pursuant to this
article shall be maintained by the village clerk for a period of two (2)
years.



(Ord. 2014-15, § 1, 10-13-2014)



Sec. 3-306.   Permit Denial:



   The village clerk may deny a permit for any of the following reasons,
which shall be noted in writing on the application:



      (1)   An investigation reveals that the applicant falsified
information on the application;



      (2)   The applicant has been convicted or pleaded guilty to a
felony or misdemeanor involving a sex offense, trafficking in controlled
substances, crimes of dishonesty (e.g. theft, fraud, deceit,
misrepresentation, etc.), or any violent acts against persons or property,
within the five (5) years preceding the date of application;



      (3)   The applicant's refusal or failure to provide proof of
authority to act on behalf of an employer or principal;



      (4)   The applicant's denial of a permit issued under this
article within the immediate past year, unless the applicant can and does
show that the basis for the previous denial no longer exists.



(Ord. 2014-15, § 1, 10-13-2014)



Sec. 3-307.   Permit Expiration:



   Permits for solicitation and peddling activities shall expire one (1)
year from the date of issuance, but shall not permit the applicant to engage
in street solicitation activities.



(Ord. 2014-15, § 1, 10-13-2014)



Sec. 3-308.   Permit Suspension and Revocation:



   (a)   Any permit issued under this article may be suspended or
revoked by the village clerk after notice and a hearing for any basis
identified in section 3-309 of this article. Notice and a hearing prior to a
suspension or revocation shall not be given if village clerk determines that
an immediate suspension or revocation is necessary due to an unreasonable
risk posed to the public health, safety or welfare. In such cases, a
post-deprivation hearing will be provided. The suspension or revocation of a
permit by the village clerk may be appealed in the manner provided in section
3-310 of this article.



   (b)   In the case of a pre-deprivation hearing, the village clerk
shall provide notice to the permittee via U.S. Mail setting forth the time
and place of the hearing. The notice shall consist of the charges for which
the permit's suspension or revocation is being considered. The notice shall
contain the date(s) on which any charge is alleged to have occurred along
with the name(s) of any witness(es) that will testify at the hearing. Any
written or tangible evidence of the occurrence shall be identified in the
notice. A hearing pursuant to this section shall occur no earlier than seven
(7) days nor later than fourteen (14) days from the date the notice of
hearing is postmarked. The permittee shall be responsible for obtaining a
court reporter in order to preserve the record for appeal. After the hearing,
the village clerk shall orally advise the permittee of his or her decision to
suspend or revoke a permit under this article and the reasons therefor. If
the decision is to suspend or revoke, said suspension/revocation shall take
effect immediately. The village clerk shall issue a written decision setting
forth his or her decision and the basis for the ruling. The written decision
shall be mailed to the permittee via U.S. Mail at the address contained in
the application. The written decision shall be postmarked no later than three
(3) business days subsequent to the hearing.



   (c)   In the case of a post-deprivation hearing, the village clerk
shall provide oral and written notice to the permittee via U.S. Mail setting
forth the time and place of the hearing. The notice shall consist of the
charges for which the permit's suspension or revocation is being considered.
The notice shall contain the date(s) on which any charge is alleged to have
occurred along with the name(s) of any witness(es) that will testify at the
hearing. Any written or tangible evidence of the occurrence shall be
identified in the notice. A hearing pursuant to this section shall occur no
later than three (3) business days after the village clerk has suspended or
revoked the permit. The permittee shall be responsible for obtaining a court
reporter in order to preserve the record for appeal. After the hearing, the
Village Clerk shall orally advise the permittee of his or her decision to
reinstate the permit, or sustain the suspension or revocation of the permit,
and the reasons therefor. If the decision is to sustain the suspension or
revocation, said suspension/revocation shall continue in full force and
effect. The Village Clerk shall issue a written decision setting forth his or
her decision and the basis for the ruling. The written decision shall be made
available for pick-up and mailed to the permittee via U.S. Mail at the
address contained in the application, no later than two (2) business days
subsequent to the hearing.



(Ord. 2014-15, § 1, 10-13-2014)



Sec. 3-309.   Basis for Suspension or Revocation:



   Any permit may be suspended or revoked for the following reasons:



      (1)   Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in
an application;



      (2)   Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made by the
permittee in the course of conducting solicitation or peddling activities;



      (3)   Conducting peddling or solicitation activities contrary
to the provisions contained in the permit or this article;



      (4)   A conviction of any crime which would otherwise be a
basis for denying a permit application; or



      (5)   Conducting peddling or solicitation activities in such a
manner so as to create a public nuisance, constitute a breach of the peace,
or endanger the health, safety or welfare of the public.



(Ord. 2014-15, § 1, 10- 13-2014)



Sec. 3-310.   Appeals:



   Any person aggrieved by the action or decision of the village clerk to
deny, suspend or revoke a permit under this article shall have the right to
appeal such decision as follows: (a) to the mayor; (b) to the corporate
authorities; or (c) to a court of competent jurisdiction. This section is
designed to provide three (3) separate and distinct means of effectuating
review. Exhaustion of remedies before one shall not preclude review by
another. Provided, however, once a method of review has been selected, the
election shall be exclusive and final, and the remedy shall be exhausted
before any further appeal may be initiated, unless otherwise provided by law.



      (1)   Appeals to Mayor:



         a.   Any person aggrieved by the action or decision of
the village clerk to deny, suspend or revoke a permit under this article may
appeal such decision to the mayor. An appeal to the mayor shall be filed
within fourteen (14) days from the date on which the village clerk's decision
has been mailed to the applicant/permittee. The date of filing shall be
measured from the date on which the written decision was postmarked. In the
event the village clerk fails to issue a written decision, the appellant
shall have seventeen (17) calendar days from the date on which he or she was
orally informed of the village clerk's decision to deny, suspend or revoke a
permit to appeal that decision.



         b.   An appeal shall be perfected by filing a written
statement with the village clerk setting forth the grounds for the appeal. If
a written decision was provided to the appellant from the village clerk, a
copy of that decision shall be attached to the appellant's written statement.
In the event that no written decision was provided, an applicant must set
forth the basis for the village clerk's action as was transmitted orally.
After the receipt of said appeal, the village clerk shall schedule the appeal
with the mayor.



         c.   A hearing shall be set by the mayor no later than
five (5) business days from the date on which an appeal is received. Notice
of the time and place of the hearing shall be given to the appellant both by
telephone and by an alternative convenient to the applicant (i.e., e-mail,
facsimile, personal delivery) as provided on the person's application. An
appellant shall be given notice of the hearing at least one (1) business day
before the hearing.



         d.   The village clerk's decision to deny, suspend or
revoke a permit shall be presumed valid.



         e.   A hearing before the mayor shall be de novo. An
applicant may be represented by an attorney, issue subpoenas, and present
documentary evidence and witness testimony. An applicant shall have the right
to cross-examine witness testifying in opposition to his or her case. The
formal rules of evidence will not apply at the hearing.



         f.   A court reporter will be provided by the village in
order to preserve the record for appeal.



         g.   The mayor's decision to affirm or reverse the
decision of the village clerk shall be limited to the facts presented at the
hearing. The decision to affirm or reverse the village clerk's decision must
be based upon the reasons contained in this article but may not be limited to
the reason stated by the village clerk.



         h.   A decision to affirm or reverse a decision of the
village clerk shall be made by the mayor orally at the conclusion of the
hearing. A written decision setting forth the mayor's findings of fact and
determination shall be issued within two (2) business days of the hearing.
Any person aggrieved by a decision of the mayor may appeal that decision to a
court of competent jurisdiction as provided by law. The time period by which
an applicant has the right to appeal the decision of the mayor shall begin to
run upon receipt of the written decision but not later than three (3) days
after the written decision is post-marked.



      (2)   Appeals to Corporate Authorities:



         a.   Any person aggrieved by the action or decision of
the village clerk to deny, suspend or revoke a permit under this article
appeal such decision to the corporate authorities. An appeal to the corporate
authorities shall be filed within fourteen (14) days from the date on which
the village clerk's decision has been mailed to the applicant/permittee. The
date of filing shall be measured from the date on which the written decision
was postmarked. In the event the village clerk fails to issue a written
decision, the appellant shall have seventeen (17) days from the date on which
he or she was orally informed of the village clerk's decision to deny,
suspend or revoke a permit to appeal that decision.



         b.   An appeal shall be perfected by filing a written
statement with the village clerk setting forth the grounds for the appeal. If
a written decision was provided to the appellant from the village clerk, a
copy of that decision shall be attached to the appellant's written statement.
In the event that no written decision was provided, an applicant must set
forth the basis for the village clerk's action as was transmitted orally.
After the receipt of said appeal, the village clerk shall schedule the appeal
for the next regularly scheduled meeting of the corporate authorities.
Provided, however, if said appeal is received within ninety-six (96) hours of
a regularly scheduled meeting, said appeal shall be heard at the following
regularly scheduled meeting.



         c.   A hearing shall be set no later than thirty (30)
days from the date on which an appeal is received. Notice of the time and
place of the hearing shall be given to the appellant both by telephone and
via U.S. Mail at the address provided on the person's application. An
appellant shall be given notice of the hearing at least five (5) days before
the hearing.



         d.   The village clerk's decision to deny, suspend or
revoke a permit shall be presumed valid.



         e.   A hearing before the corporate authorities shall be
de novo. An applicant may be represented by an attorney, issue subpoenas, and
present documentary evidence and witness testimony. An applicant shall have
the right to cross-examine witness testifying in opposition to his or her
case. The formal rules of evidence will not apply at the hearing.



         f.   A court reporter will be provided by the village in
order to preserve the record for appeal.



         g.   The corporate authorities decision to affirm or
reverse the decision of the village clerk shall be limited to the facts
presented to it at the hearing. The decision to affirm or reverse the village
clerk's decision must be based upon the reasons contained in this article but
may not be limited to the reason stated by the village clerk.



         h.   A decision to affirm or reverse a decision of the
village clerk shall be made by a majority vote of the corporate authorities
present at the meeting. A written decision setting forth the corporate
authorities' findings of fact and determination shall be issued within five
(5) days of the hearing. Any person aggrieved by a decision of the corporate
authorities may appeal that decision to a court of competent jurisdiction as
provided by law. The time period by which an applicant has the right to
appeal the decision of the corporate authorities shall begin to run upon
receipt of the written decision but not later than three (3) days after the
written decision is post-marked.



      (3)   Appeals to Judiciary: Any person aggrieved by the action
or decision of the village clerk to deny, suspend or revoke a permit under
this article may appeal such decision to a court of competent jurisdiction as
provided by law.



(Ord. 2014-15, § 1, 10-13- 2014)



Sec. 3-311.  Exemptions:



   Any person claiming to be legally exempt from the application of this
division shall cite to the village clerk the legal authority under which the
exemption is claimed and shall present to the village clerk proof of
qualification for such exemption.



(Ord. 2014-15, § 1, 10-13-2014)



Sec. 3-312.  Transfer of Permits:



   No permit issued to any one (1) person shall be transferable to another
regardless of affiliation.



(Ord. 2014-15, § 1, 10-13-2014)



Sec. 3-313.  Canvassers:



   Canvassers shall be exempt from the permit requirements of this
article, but shall be subject to all other time, place and manner regulations.



(Ord. 2014-15, § 1, 10-13-2014)



DIVISION 3. TIME, PLACE AND MANNER



Sec. 3-314.  Carrying of Permits:



   (a)   Every person required to obtain a permit under this article
shall carry that permit on himself or herself at all times while engaging in
activities so permitted.



   (b)   It shall be unlawful for any person to carry or display a
permit issued to another person while engaging in activities governed by this
article.



(Ord. 2014-15, § 1, 10-13-2014)



Sec. 3-315.  Entry and Staying Upon Private Premises Unlawful:



   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any solicitor, peddler or canvasser
to enter upon any private premises in the village which has posted at the
entry to the premises, or at the entry to the principal building on the
premises, a sign bearing the words "No Trespassers," "No Peddlers" or "No
Solicitors," or words of similar import.



   (b)   It shall be unlawful for any solicitor, peddler or canvasser
to remain on any private premises once requested to leave by an owner or
occupant. Once requested to leave, a solicitor, peddler or canvasser shall be
obligated to do so immediately and peacefully.



(Ord. 2014-15, § 1, 10-13-2014)



Sec. 3-316.  Permitted Hours:



   (a)   Permitted hours for canvassing activities, peddling
activities, and soliciting activities upon residential property are Monday
through Sunday between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m.



   (b)   Permitted hours for canvassing activities, peddling
activities, and soliciting activities upon commercial and public property,
other than streets, are Monday through Saturday between the hours of 9:00
a.m. and 7:00 p.m. and on Sunday from 9:00 a.m. until 5:00 p.m.



   (c)   No person shall engage in solicitation activities, peddling
activities, or canvassing activities other than during permitted hours.



(Ord. 2014-15, § 1, 10-13- 2014)



Sec. 3-317.  Handbills, Flyers and Other Materials:



   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any solicitor, peddler or canvasser
to leave a handbill, flyer or other material upon any private premises where
the owner or occupants have posted at the entry to the premises, or at the
entry to the principal building on the premises, a sign bearing the words "No
Trespassers," "No Peddlers" or "No Solicitors," or words of similar import.



   (b)   It shall be unlawful for any solicitor, peddler or canvasser
leave a handbill, flyer or other material upon any private premises which is
not securely attached thereto. Provided, however, it shall be unlawful to
damage any property in an attempt to securely attach any handbill, flyer, or
other material to a premises.



   (c)   It shall be unlawful for any solicitor, peddler or canvasser
to leave a handbill, flyer or other material upon any private premises
without the owner's express permission which is temporarily or continuously
uninhabited or vacant in any of the following circumstances: (i) it is
apparent that such property is unoccupied or vacant; or (ii) a distribution
from any date prior has not been removed.



   (d)   It shall be unlawful for any solicitor, peddler or canvasser
to leave a handbill, flier, or other material upon any sidewalk, crosswalk,
curb or curbstone, flagstone or any other portion or part of any public way
or public place, or any lamppost, electric light, sign, hydrant, mailbox,
tree, or upon the piers, columns, trusses, girders, railings, gates or other
