any room used for human habitation, any establishment or room where food is
prepared, any hair salon, or any other such activity that may cause potential
contamination of work surfaces. Each body art establishment shall have an
area that may be screened from public review for clients requesting privacy.
Dividers, curtains or partitions, at a minimum, shall be available to
separate multiple work stations.



      (b)   The floor of the workroom shall be constructed of
impervious materials and shall be, at all times, maintained in a clean
condition. Floors shall be swept and wet-mopped daily. The walls and ceilings
shall be of light color and be maintained in good repair and shall be of such
materials to be easily cleanable. Floors, walls, or ceilings shall not be
swept or cleaned while anyone is being tattooed or pierced. Carpeting is
prohibited in the workroom(s) and toilet room(s).



      (c)   The establishment shall have adequate light to provide
at least thirty (30) foot-candles of illumination, and have good ventilation.



      (d)   Light fixtures, decorative materials, and similar
equipment attached to the walls or ceilings shall be kept clean.



      (e)   The building and equipment shall be maintained in good
repair at all times. All parts of the shop and its premises shall be kept
clean, neat, and free of litter and rubbish.



      (f)   A lavatory, with hot and cold running water, shall be
located in the workroom. The lavatory shall be for the exclusive use of the
artists for washing their hands and preparing the customer. It shall be
equipped with controls which provide for wrist action, soap, approved
germicidal solution, individual hand brushes, and fingernail files for each
artist.



      (g)   A toilet and hand sink shall be located in the
establishment and be accessible to patrons. All plumbing shall meet the
requirements of the Illinois Department of Public Health Plumbing Code and
the plumbing codes adopted by the village of Justice. The plumbing fixtures
and toilet room shall be maintained in a sanitary manner and in good repair.



      (h)   Single service paper towels or mechanical means for hand
drying shall be provided.



      (i)   Adequate cabinets for the storage of instruments, dyes
and pigments, carbon, stencils, and other materials used in the procedures
shall be provided.



      (j)   An adequate number of worktables shall be provided for
each artist. The surface of all worktables shall be constructed of metal or
other material which is easily cleanable, smooth, light colored,
non-absorbent, corrosive-resistant, and easily sanitized.



      (k)   All furniture in the workroom shall be non-porous and of
such nature as to be chemically sanitized and maintained in a clean and
sanitary condition.



      (l)   The shop shall have sufficient covered waste receptacles
with disposable plastic liners for the disposal of waste materials.



      (m)   Animals shall not be permitted in the tattoo and body
piercing establishment, except for guide or service animals accompanying
persons with disabilities.



      (n)   Smoking and the use of tobacco in any form shall be
prohibited in the tattooing and body piercing establishment.



      (o)   Any other business or dwelling shall be completely
separated from the tattoo and body piercing establishment by at least a solid
partition from the floor to the ceiling.



   (6)   Restrictions:



      (a)   A body artist/apprentice shall be eighteen (18) years of
age prior to being issued a valid license. Tattoo artists and persons
performing body piercing must complete approved courses as noted below in
(b)1., (b)2., (b)3., and (b)4. prior to opening for business. Existing body
art establishments shall have three (3) months after the effective date of
this section to comply, subject to Illinois law and the rules and regulations
promulgated by the Illinois Department of Public Health.



      (b)   The operator shall maintain procedures ensuring that all
persons performing tattooing or body piercing services for the business shall
have received training, as evidenced by records of completion, courses or
seminars provided by nurses, organizations such as the American Red Cross,
accredited learning institutions, appropriate governmental entitles, or other
authorities recognized by the board of health as being qualified to provide
training in the following:



         1.   Basic training in first aid and advanced CPR as
well as proof of attendance at required renewal courses.



         2.   Safety and sanitation requirements for preventing
transmission of infectious diseases.



         3.   Universal precautions against blood-borne pathogens.



         4.   Appropriate tattoo and piercing procedures and
aftercare.



      (c)   The operator shall maintain written records of equipment
utilized by the business, including manufacturer and model numbers.



      (d)   The operator shall maintain procedures acceptable to the
Illinois Department of Public Health ensuring that persons performing
tattooing or body piercing services on the premises of the business shall
disinfect and sterilize all non-disposable equipment or parts of equipment
used in performing procedures, by utilizing methods meeting disinfection and
sterilization requirements.



      (e)   No tattooing or body piercing shall be performed in any
place other than a body art establishment having a valid license and a valid
certificate of registration from the Illinois Department of Public Health.



      (f)   No tattooing or body piercing shall be performed on any
person who appears to be or admits to being under the influence of
intoxicating substances, including, but not limited to, alcohol, drugs,
paints and glues, nor shall any tattoo artist practice his or her trade while
in an intoxicated state.



      (g)   No tattooing or body piercing shall be performed on the
person of anyone having a history of jaundice or similar disease, and each
patron shall be questioned.



      (h)   No tattooing or body piercing shall be performed on any
person suffering from any rash, sunburn, skin lesion or any skin disease or
possible communicable disease. The skin surface shall be free from rash,
sunburn, pimples, infection or recent scar tissue.



      (i)   No person with any disease in a communicable form or
suspected of having such a disease shall perform the application of tattooing
or body piercing. Such disease may include, but shall not be limited to, the
common cold, influenza, tuberculosis, scabies, shingles, impetigo, syphilis,
chickenpox, measles (rubella), mumps, whooping cough, hepatitis, infection on
the hands or arms, sore throat or jaundice of the skin or sclera. The health
officer may require a certificate signed by a duly licensed physician stating
the person is free from communicable diseases before permission to resume
operation is granted.



      (j)   No person shall perform any tattoo procedure upon a
person under the age of eighteen (18) year that is prohibited by Sections
12-10 through 12(c) of the Criminal Code of 1961. Age verification shall be
obtained by government issued identification containing a birth date and
photograph. In any procedure other than tattooing, the parent or legal
guardian shall sign a consent form in the presence of an operator/body
artist. The consent form shall indicate that the parent or legal guardian has
read and understood the disclosure warning statement required under Title 77,
Part 797, Section 797.600(c) of the Illinois Administrative Code.



      (k)   Any person who is an owner or employed by a business
that performs tattooing or body piercing, other than a person licensed to
practice medicine in all its branches, may not permit a person under eighteen
(18) years of age to enter or remain on the premises where tattooing or body
piercing is being performed, unless  the person under eighteen (18) years of
age is accompanied by his or her parent or legal guardian. A violation of
this subsection is a Class A misdemeanor.



      (l)   Before the oral cavity of a person under eighteen (18)
years of age may be pierced, the written consent form signed by the parent or
legal guardian must contain a provision in substantially the following form:
“I understand that the oral piercing of the tongue, lips, cheeks, or any
other area of the oral cavity carries serious risk of infection or damage to
the mouth and teeth, or both infection and damage to those areas, that could
result in but is not limited to nerve damage, numbness, and life-threatening
blood clots (Section 12-10.1 of the Criminal Code of 1961).”



      (m)   No establishment licensed under this section shall
attempt to remove a tattoo from any person or allow such a procedure to take
place on its premises.



   (7)   Procedural Requirements:



      (a)   Record keeping: The operator shall maintain proper
records on each patron. These records shall be entered in ink or indelible
pencil in a bound book kept solely for this purpose. This book shall be
available at a reasonable time for examination by the health officer. The
records shall be preserved for at least three (3) years from the date of the
last entry. The records shall contain the following information.



         1.   The date the procedure was performed.



         2.   The name, address, date of birth and age of the
patron. Valid state driver’s license or state ID number recorded.



         3.   The branch of service, rate or rank and serial
number of the patron if in the armed services.



         4.   The design and location of the tattoo applied.



         5.   The location where body piercing is performed.



         6.   The manufacturer, dye lot, and expiration date of
the dye or pigment injected into the client.



         7.   The name of the artist.



         8.   The signature of the patron.



         9.   Special instructions.



         10.   Medical history of patron conditions, including:
diabetes, allergies, cold sores and fever blisters, epilepsy, heart
conditions, hemophilia, hepatitis, use of blood thinners, moles or freckles
at the site of service, psoriasis or eczema, pregnancy or
breastfeeding/nursing, scarring or other medical or skin conditions.



      (b)   Patron Information: Before applying a tattoo, a
discussion of the risks involved and possible complications shall be
conducted by the artist or operator. The patron must be advised that the
procedure should be considered permanent and that it can be removed only by a
surgical procedure and that any effective removal may leave permanent
scarring. A written cautionary notice to that effect shall be furnished to
and signed by the patron and a copy retained on file at the establishment. A
list of ingredients should be included in the cautionary notice, along with a
statement that any adverse reaction should be referred to a physician.



      (c)   After the procedure is complete, written (printed or
photocopied) instructions, on the care of the skin to prevent infection,
shall be given to each patron. A copy of these instructions along with
ingredients shall also be posted in a conspicuous place in the establishment.



   (8)   Required Equipment: Articles And Materials:



      (a)   The studio shall provide and maintain at the place of
business an adequate supply of disinfecting or sterilizing equipment,
tools/implements, and other necessary materials for business needs, taking
into account volume of business.



      (b)   All forceps, tubes, and the like must be pre-sterilized
stored in sterile indicator bags, sealed and dated, used on one person, in
one sitting. After one (1) such use, they must be autoclaved and stored in
sterile indicator bags, sealed and dated.



      (c)   Only single-service pre-sterilized needles are to be
used on one (1) person, in one (1) sitting. Assemblies designed to be
disposable shall be used one (1) time, on one (1) person only, and then
discarded in the appropriate manner.



      (d)   All dyes or pigments used in tattooing shall meet the
United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) certification standards for
foods, drugs, and cosmetics as prescribed in the Federal Food, Drug and
Cosmetic Act, Title 21, U.S.C. and the Food and Drug Administration
Regulations as published in the Federal Register.



      (e)   Each tattoo artist shall be provided with adequate
storage cabinets for the exclusive storage of instruments, dyes, pigments,
carbon, stencils and other paraphernalia used in the parlor.



   (9)   Tattooing And Body Piercing Procedure: All tattoo artists
shall comply with the following.



      (a)   Hand Washing: Prior to performing tattooing or body
piercing individuals shall wash their hands, using good mechanical action
with soap or detergent and warm water, and shall dry their hands using clean
single service or single use towels or other approved method before and after
tattooing. Use of bar soap is prohibited.



      (b)   Protective Gloves: Tattooing or body piercing artists
shall observe and adhere to the following protective glove standards when
serving clients:



         1.   A fresh pair of disposable gloves should be worn
during the treatment of each client;



         2.   Hands must be washed in accordance with the hand
washing standards as stated in subsection (a) of the rule before putting on
gloves and immediately after gloves are removed.



      (c)   The area of the client’s skin to be tattooed or
pierced shall be adequately cleaned. Shaving, if done, shall be performed
with a single service razor.



      (d)   Before placing the design on the client’s skin, the
tattoo artist shall treat the skin area with seventy percent (70%) alcohol or
other effective germicidal solution, which shall be applied using aseptic
technique.



      (e)   If petroleum jelly or other substances are used in
applying stencil designs to the skin, they shall be dispensed from
collapsible metal or plastic tubes.



      (f)   Stencils for transferring the design to the skin shall
be single use and discarded after use.



      (g)   Only sterilized tubes or tips, in good condition, shall
be used for tattooing.



      (h)   Single service or individual portions of dyes or
pigments in sterilized containers or single service containers shall be used
for each client. After tattooing, the remaining unused dyes or pigments in
the single service or individual containers shall be discarded.



   (10)   Sterilization Procedure:



      (a)   Before Sterilization: All instruments requiring
sterilization shall be thoroughly washed to remove dyes, blood clots and
other foreign matter according to manufacturers’ and OSHA’s
recommendations; rinse instruments thoroughly; dry instruments. Cleansing
with ultrasonic cleaners should be the rule for removal of bacitracin or
other triple antibiotic solutions, blood and other particles from a used
contaminated implement (i.e. jewelry, forceps, insertion tapers, and pliers)
followed by steam autoclave.



      (b)   Steam autoclave must be used on all equipment that may
come in contact with the client or the jewelry (i.e. receiving tubes) rubber
bands, insertion tapers, forceps, files, gauge wheels, pliers, etc.).
Equipment shall be packed in packages approved for the sterilization unit.
Instruments shall be packed individually, or as a set provided, such set is
intended to be used for a single procedure. Each package shall be labeled
with the date of sterilization and the initials of the person sterilizing the
instruments. Packaged sterilized instruments shall be kept in a sterile
condition and stored in a clean dust-tight container when not in use. Spore
indicators shall be used with each load to ensure spore eradication.
Instruments shall be autoclaved at a temperature of:



         1.   One hundred twenty- one degrees (121°) Centigrade
(two hundred fifty degrees (250°) Fahrenheit) for not less than twenty (20)
minutes after the chamber of the autoclave has been evacuated of air and has
reached temperature; or



         2.   As specified in the manufacturer’s operator’s
manual.



         3.   Autoclaves shall be spore tested by independent
laboratories at least once every month to induce efficiency. Documentation of
spore test must be kept on file.



   (11)   Disposal Of Infectious Waste: Used tattoo needles and other
infectious waste shall be stored, treated and disposed of in accordance with
the provisions of Title XV of the Environmental Protection Act, which
regulates the management and disposal of infectious waste. Disposal
documentation shall be provided upon request to the health officer.



   (12)   Denial, Suspension, Revocation, Nonrenewal Of Licenses: A
license may be suspended, revoked or the renewal of a license may be denied
for any of the following reasons:



      (a)   Violation of any of the provisions of this section.



      (b)   Conviction of an applicant or licensee of an offense
arising from false, fraudulent, deceptive, or misleading advertising. The
record of conviction or a certified copy shall be conclusive evidence of the
conviction.



      (c)   Aiding or abetting an unlicensed person, knowingly
combining or conspiring with an unlicensed person, allowing one’s license
to be used by an unlicensed person, or acting as agent or associate of an
unlicensed person, in order to enable the unlicensed person to evade the
restrictions on use of title imposed by this division.



   Upon denial of an application, refusal to renew a license, suspension
of a license or revocation of a license, the village clerk shall notify the
applicant in writing. The notice shall specify the charges or reasons for the
contemplated action. If a license is suspended or revoked and such suspension
or revocation is disputed by the license holder, the license holder must
request a hearing within ten (10) days of receipt of the notice. Failure to
request a hearing within ten (10) days shall constitute a waiver of the right
to a hearing. The procedures set forth by the village of Justice for the
suspension or termination of a business license shall begin to run after the
complaint and investigation procedures have been performed by the village of
Justice health officer.



   (13)   Conduct Of Hearing:



      (a)   Upon suspension or revocation of a license, should a
license holder request a hearing, such hearing shall be conducted by the
village of Justice board of trustees or an individual designated in writing
by the village of Justice as a hearing officer. The village of Justice or
hearing officer may compel by subpoena or subpoena duces tecum, the
attendance and testimony of witnesses and the production of books and papers,
and administer oaths to witnesses. The hearing shall be conducted at a place
designated by the village of Justice or hearing officer. The procedures
governing hearings in the issuance of final decisions under this division
shall be in accordance with rules adopted by the village of Justice.



      (b)   All subpoenas issued by the village of Justice or
hearing officer may be served as provided for in civil actions. The fees for
witnesses for attendance and travel shall be the same as the fees for witness
before the circuit court and shall be paid by the party to the proceedings at
whose request the subpoena is issued. If a subpoena is issued at the request
of the village of Justice or hearing officer, the witness fee shall be paid
as an administrative expense.



      (c)   In cases of refusal of a witness to attend or testify,
or to produce books or papers, concerning any matter upon which he might be
lawfully examined, the circuit court of the county wherein the hearing is
held, upon application of any parry to the proceeding, may compel obedience
by proceeding as for contempt as in cases of a like refusal to obey a similar
order of the court.



      (d)   The village of Justice or hearing officer shall make
findings of fact and conclusions of law in a hearing, and the village of
Justice or the hearing officer shall render a decision within forty-five (45)
days after the termination of the hearing. A copy of the final decision shall
be served upon the applicant or licensee in person or by certified mail.



      (e)   Upon the revocation of a license, a license holder shall
be required to surrender the license to the village of Justice and upon his
or her failure or refusal to do so, the village of Justice shall have the
right to seize the same.



   (14)   Penalty For Violation: The violation of any provision of this
section shall be a misdemeanor punishable by a term of imprisonment up to six
(6) months or a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or both.



   The village of Justice shall refer to the appropriate district
attorney, attorney general, or other law enforcement official any incidents
of unauthorized practice of body art. Any person found by a court who has
been operating without a business license is subject to a business offense
with a fine up to five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) or one (1) year in
prison. Any person who knowingly furnished false or misleading information to
the village’s health officer, upon conviction, shall be subject to a fine
not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for any one (1) offense.



   (15)   A valid business license shall be valid from the date of
issuance and shall automatically expire on December 31 of each year, unless
revoked sooner by the village. Renewals shall be in accordance with the
requirements of this section and submitted prior to the expiration date of
the current business license. A person who files a renewal application after
the expiration date must pay an additional one hundred dollars ($100.00) as a
delinquency fee. The business license shall be prominently placed in the
studio location. Business license fees shall be non-refundable for each place
of business. Business license fees shall be those that are established in
Chapter 13, Section 3-61 of this code.



   (16)   Number Of Licenses: No more than two (2) body art
establishments shall be licensed to do business in the village at the same
time.



(Ord. 2008-10, §§ 3, 4, 3-10-2008; Ord. 2010-17, §§ 2 - 7, 8-23-2010;
Ord. 2011-16, § 2, 10-17-2011)



Secs. 5-44-5-60.  Reserved:



ARTICLE III.  FOOD AND FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS1,2



1  See also chapter 3, "Business Regulations"; and chapter 11, "Utilities",
of this code.



2  65 ILCS 5/11-20-2, 5/11-42-5.



DIVISION 1 TEMPORARY FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENTS



Sec. 5-61.   Temporary Food Service Establishments:



   A temporary food service establishment is any food service
establishment that operates at a fixed location for a period of time not to
exceed fourteen (14) consecutive days in conjunction with a single special
event or celebration.



   (a)   Application Required:



      1.   All operators of a temporary food service establishment
shall complete and submit an application as prescribed from time to time by
the health officer for such activities, to the village of Justice building
department. All information as requested in the application shall be
provided, including but not limited to, the date of the event,



         location dates and times of operation, vendor’s name,
business address, phone, vendor’s home address, number and expiration date
of food handlers certification and copies of food handlers certification,
foodstuffs to be served, names and address of all approved sources of
foodstuffs, equipment that will be used to maintain hot or cold temperatures
during the event, and the operators and organizer’s signature.



      2.   Approval shall be by the health officer.



   (b)   Fees:



      1.    A health inspection fee, as set forth in section 13-1 of
this code, shall be charged for each day that the temporary food service
establishment is in operation.



      2.   The health inspection fee shall be paid by the
organizer/event sponsor or the temporary food service establishment operator
as determined prior to the event and submitted with the application. Any
application received without the health inspection fee shall be denied.



   (c)   Application Deadline: All completed applications, with the
appropriate copies of licenses and fees attached, shall be filed in the
building department, no later than fourteen (14) days prior to the event.
Late entries shall be handled on a case by case basis by the health officer
whose decision shall be final.



(Ord. 2012-26, § 1, 9-24-2012)



Sec. 5-62.   Adoption Of State Regulation:



   The Illinois Food, Drugs, and Cosmetics Act, 410 ILCS 620; Food
Handling Regulation Enforcement Act, 410 ILCS 625; the Sanitary Food
Preparation Act, 410 ILCS 650; and Title 77 Public Health, Chapter 1:
Department of Public Health; Subchapter m: Food, Drugs, and Cosmetics, part
750 Food Service Sanitation Code of the Illinois Administrative Code, are
adopted as the regulations governing the sanitation procedures and controls
for the storage, preparation and display of food sold or offered for
consumption, within the village of Justice.



(Ord. 2012-26, § 1, 9-24-2012)



Sec. 5-63.   State Of Illinois Food Handler Certificate, Required:



   Temporary food service establishments, not staffed by a certified food
supervisor that are able to prove their identity, will be closed.



(Ord. 2012-26, § 1, 9-24-2012)



Secs. 5-64–5-70.   Reserved:



DIVISION 2. RETAIL FOOD DISPENSERS



Sec. 5-71.  Definitions:



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Food dispenser means any person that keeps for sale, sells and serves
to the public for consumption, on the premises or on the public way
contiguous to such premises, any article of food or drink for human
consumption. Restaurants, drive-in restaurants, coffeehouses, lunchrooms,
tearooms, lunch stands, box lunch deliveries, luncheonettes, cafeterias and
retail drugstores serving counter lunches and for drinks shall be included
among food dispensers.



   Serves means the placing of such food for the convenience of the patron
into any cup, glass, dish, plate or other receptacle from which the patron
may conveniently consume it.



   Service accommodations means the seating place whereon patrons or
customers to be served can be seated or, in lieu of seating space, two (2)
lineal feet of counter space which may be used or occupied by one (1) patron
or customer to be served while standing, provided that for the purpose of
computing the number of service accommodations at a counter where no fixed
seats or stools are provided, each such counter shall be considered as a
separate unit and any fractional part of two (2) lineal feet at a side or end
shall be excluded.



(Code 1972, §§ 3-5-1, 3-5-3)



Sec. 5-72.  License-Required:



   It shall be unlawful to engage in the business of a food dispenser
without first obtaining an annual license therefor.



(Code 1972, § 3-5-2)



Sec. 5-73.  Same-Application:



   Applications for a license under the division shall be made to the
village president, and shall be referred to the health officer for such
inspections as may be necessary to see that the provisions of this division
are complied with.



(Code 1972, § 3-5-3; Ord. 2009-15, § 24, 6-22-09)



Sec. 5-74.  Same-Revocation:



   Any restaurant license may be revoked by the president for repeated
violation of the provisions of this division, or for any violation of any
provision of this code, relating to the conduct of the business, the
condition of the premises, the article sold or to the license required.



(Code 1972, § 3-5-4)



Sec. 5-75.  Unwholesome Food:



   No person shall offer for sale or keep for the purpose of selling or
offering for sale any food of any kind intended for human consumption which
is spoiled or is unwholesome and unfit for human consumption, for any reason.



(Code 1972, § 3-5-5)



Sec. 5-76.  Employees:



   (a)   All persons engaged in handling or coming in contact with food
intended for sale for human consumption shall keep themselves clean, both as
to person and clothing, and shall be examined for all communicable infectious
and venereal diseases not less than once in any twelve (12)-month period or
whenever required by the board of health.



   (b)   It shall be unlawful for any person who is afflicted with or a
carrier of any infectious or contagious disease to handle or be engaged in
the care or preparation of any such food; and it shall be unlawful to permit
any such person to be employed in or about any premises where food is stored,
prepared or sold, or to deliver such food.



(Code 1972, § 3-5-6)



   State law reference-Person with contagious or venereal disease working
in food establishment, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 56 1/2, § 76.



Sec. 5-77.  Examination Of Food And Drink; Condemnation:



   Samples of food, drink and other substances may be taken and examined
by the health officer as often as may be necessary for the detection of
unwholesomeness or adulteration. The health officer may condemn and forbid
the sale of, or cause to be removed or destroyed, any food or drink which is
unwholesome or adulterated.



(Code 1972, § 3-5-7)



   State law reference-Inspection of food in municipalities, Ill. Rev.
Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-20-3.



Sec. 5-78.  Inspection Of Restaurants; Records:



   (a)   At least once every six (6) months the health officer shall
inspect every restaurant located within the village. In case the health
officer discovers the violation of any item of sanitation, he shall make a
second inspection after the lapse of such time as he deems necessary for the
defect to be remedied. Any violation of the same requirement of this division
found on such second inspection shall authorize immediate revocation.



   (b)   One (1) copy of the inspection report shall be posted by the
health officer upon an inside wall of the restaurant, and the inspection
report shall not be defaced or removed by any person except the health
officer. Another copy of the inspection report shall be filed with the
records of the health department.



   (c)   The person operating the restaurant shall, upon request of the
health officer, permit access to all parts of the establishment and shall
permit copying any or all records of food purchased.



(Code 1972, § 3-5-8)



Sec. 5-79.  Toilet Facilities:



   Every restaurant shall be provided with adequate and conveniently
located toilet facilities for its employees, conforming with the provisions
of this code. In restaurants constructed after the effective date of the
ordinance from which this section derives, toilet rooms shall not open
directly into any room in which food, drink or utensils are handled or
stored. The doors of all toilet rooms shall be self-closing. Toilet rooms
shall be kept in a clean condition, in good repair, and well-lighted and
well-ventilated. Hand-washing signs shall be posted in each toilet room used
by employees.



(Code 1972, § 3-5-9)



   State law reference-Toilet rooms and lavatories in food establishments,
Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 56 1/2, § 71.



Sec. 5-80.  Water Supply:



   Running water under pressure shall be easily accessible to all rooms in
which food is prepared or utensils are washed, and the water supply shall be
adequate and of a safe, sanitary quality.



(Code 1972, § 3-5-10)



Sec. 5-81.  Lavatory Facilities:



   Adequate and convenient hand-washing facilities shall be provided,
including hot and cold running water, soap and approved sanitary towels. The
use of a common towel is prohibited. No employee shall resume work after
using the toilet without first washing his hands.



(Code 1972, § 3-5-11)



   State law reference-Toilet rooms and lavatories in food establishments,
Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 56 1/2, § 71.



Sec. 5-82.  Utensils, Equipment-Construction, Materials:



   All multiuse utensils and all show and display cases or windows,
counters, shelves, tables, refrigeration equipment, sinks and other equipment
or utensils used in connection with the operation of a restaurant shall be so
constructed as to be easily cleaned and shall be kept in good repair.
Utensils containing or plated with cadmium or lead shall not be used;
provided, that solder containing lead may be used for jointing.



(Code 1972, § 3-5-12)



Sec. 5-83.  Same-Cleaning.



   (a)   All equipment, including display cases or windows, counters,
shelves, tables, refrigerators, stoves, hoods and sinks shall be kept clean
and free from dust, dirt, insects and other contaminating material. All
cloths used by waiters, chefs and other employees shall be clean.
Single-service containers shall be used only once.



   (b)   All multiuse eating and drinking utensils shall be thoroughly
cleaned and effectively subjected to an approved bactericidal process after
each usage. All multiuse utensils used in the preparation or serving of food
and drink shall be thoroughly cleaned and effectively subjected to an
approved bactericidal process immediately following the day's operation.
Drying cloths, if used, shall be clean and shall be used for no other purpose.



   (c)   No article, polish or other substance containing any cyanide
preparation or other poisonous material shall be used for the cleaning or
polishing of utensils.



(Code 1972, § 3-5-13)



Sec. 5-84.  Same-Storage, Handling:



   After bactericidal treatment, utensils shall be stored in a clean, dry
place protected from flies, dust and other contamination, and shall be
handled in such a manner as to prevent contamination as far as practicable.
Single-service utensils shall be purchased only in sanitary containers, shall
be stored therein in a clean, dry place until used, and shall be handled in a
sanitary manner.



(Code 1972, § 3-5-14)



Sec. 5-85.  Disposal Of Wastes:



   All restaurant wastes shall be properly disposed of, and all garbage
and trash shall be kept in suitable receptacles, in such manner as not to
become a nuisance.



(Code 1972, § 3-5-15)



   State law reference-Removal of refuse from food establishments, Ill.
Rev. Stat. Ch. 56 1/2, § 68.



Sec. 5-86.  Refrigeration:



   All readily perishable food and drink shall be kept at or below fifty
(50) degrees Fahrenheit, except when being prepared or served. Wastewater
from refrigeration equipment shall be properly disposed of.



(Code 1972, § 3-5-16)



Sec. 5-87.  Serving Of Wholesome Food, Drink:



   All food and drink shall be clean, wholesome, free from spoilage, and
so prepared as to be safe for human consumption. All milk, fluid milk
products, ice cream and other frozen desserts served shall be from approved
sources. Milk and fluid milk products shall be served in the individual
original containers in which they were received from the distributor or from
a bulk container equipped with an approved dispensing device; provided, that
this requirement shall not apply to cream, which may be served from the
original bottle or from a dispenser approved for such service. All oysters,
clams and mussels shall be from approved sources and if shucked shall be kept
in the containers in which they were placed at the shucking plant until used.



(Code 1972, § 3-5-17)



Sec. 5-88.  Storage, Display Of Food, Drink:



   All food and drink shall be so stored, displayed and served as to be
protected from dust, flies, vermin, depredation and pollution by rodents,
unnecessary handling, droplet infection, overhead leakage and other
contamination. No animals or fowl shall be kept or allowed in any room in
which food or drink is prepared or stored. All means necessary for the
elimination of flies, roaches and rodents shall be used.



(Code 1972, § 3-5-18)



Sec. 5-89.  Premises.



   The premises shall be kept clean and free of litter or rubbish. None of
the operations connected with a food dispenser shall be conducted in any room
used as living or sleeping quarters. Adequate lockers or dressing rooms shall
be provided for employees' clothing and shall be kept clean. Soiled linens,
coats, and aprons shall be kept in containers provided for this purpose.



(Code 1972, § 3-5-19)



   State law reference-Sleeping in workroom of food establishment, Ill.
Rev. Stat. Ch. 56 1/2, § 75.



Sec. 5-90.  License To Be Posted In Establishment:



   Every person licensed to engage in the business of food dispenser shall
immediately post the license, or cause it to be posted, and at all times keep
it posted in a conspicuous place within the premises where such business is
thereby authorized to be kept.



(Code 1969, Ch. 11, Art. 5; Code 1972, § 3-5-20)



Secs. 5-91-5-105.  Reserved:



DIVISION 3. FOOD DEALERS* 1



* State law reference—Municipal regulation of markets and markethouses,
III. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-20.1.



Sec. 5-106.  Definitions:



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Food means any food or beverage intended for human consumption.



   Food dealer means every person, firm or corporation engaged in
conducting or operating any or all of the following businesses: fruit store
or establishment for the retail sale of fresh fruits and berries; grocery
store or establishment for the sale of butter, cheese, vegetables or other
provisions; ice cream parlor; meat market or establishment for the retail
sale of fresh meats, poultry or fish; retail beverage store or establishment
for the sale at retail of any malted, cereal, carbonated or vinous
nonintoxicating beverages as defined by law; bakery as defined in section
5-131; confectionery store or establishment for the sale of candy and not for
human consumption on the premises.



(Code 1972, § 3-6-1)



Sec. 5-107.  License-Required:



   It shall be unlawful for any food dealer to engage in or do business in
the village without having first secured a license therefor. Applications for
such license shall be made in compliance with the general provisions of this
Code relating thereto, and shall state the kind of food intended to be sold
or handled.



(Code 1972, § 3-6-2)



Sec. 5-108.  Same-Application:



   All applications for a license to conduct a business connected with the
storage, handling, sale or preparation of food or drink intended for human
consumption shall be referred by the village to the health officer for
investigation before a license shall be issued. The health officer shall
inspect or cause to be inspected the premises used or intended to be used,
and shall report thereon, recommending or advising against the issuance of
the license.



(Code 1972, § 3-6-8; Ord. 2009-15, § 25, 6-22-2009)



Sec. 5-109.  Same-Revocation:



   Any such food dealers' licenses may be revoked by the village board for
any violation of the provisions of this division, or for any violation of any
other provisions relating to the conduct of the business, the condition of
the premises or the licenses.



(Code 1972, § 3-6-3)



Sec. 5-110.  Unwholesome Food:



   No person shall sell, offer for sale or keep for the purpose of selling
or offering for sale, any food of any kind which is spoiled or tainted or is
unwholesome and unfit for human consumption for any reason. All tainted or
unwholesome food intended for human consumption may be condemned by the board
of health, and shall thereupon be seized and destroyed by the board of health
or any police officer of the village.



(Code 1972, § 3-6-4)



Sec. 5-111.  Adulterations:



   It shall be unlawful to sell, offer for sale or keep for such purposes,
any food or drink intended for human consumption which has been adulterated
by any material harmful in any way, or which does not comply with the state
statutes governing the same.



(Code 1972, § 3-6-5)



Sec. 5-112.  Sanitation Of Premises:



   Premises used for the sale or storage of food intended for human
consumption must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. It shall be
unlawful to permit any accumulation of refuse, or waste of any kind thereon
for more than twenty-four (24) hours. It shall be unlawful to permit any
decaying animal or plant matter or waste to remain on any such premises at
all.



(Code 1972, § 3-6-6)



Sec. 5-113.  Inspections:



   The health officer shall inspect, or cause to be inspected, every
place, building or establishment used for the storage, handling, sale or
preparation of food or drink intended for human consumption. It shall be the
duty of every food dealer to give to the health officer such samples of such
food or drink as may be necessary for the purpose of making an analysis of
the same to determine whether it is clean and wholesome.



(Code 1972, § 3-6-7)



Sec. 5-114.  Flies, Vermin:



   Premises used for the storing of food intended for human consumption
shall be kept free from flies and vermin of all kinds.



(Code 1972, § 3-6-9)



Sec. 5-115.  Employees:



   All persons engaged in handling or coming in contact with food intended
for human consumption shall be clean and shall keep their clothes clean. It
shall be unlawful to permit any person afflicted with a contagious or
venereal disease to handle any food intended for sale for human consumption,
or for any such person to handle any such food.



(Code 1969, Ch. 11, Art. 6; Code 1972, § 3-6-10)



Sec. 5-116.  Mobile Food Vendors:



   (a)   Mobile food vending vehicles, including, but not limited to,
ice cream vendors, shall not approach or stop for the purpose of selling any
food or beverage closer than one block from any school building or school
playground while school is in session, including one hour before the school
day begins and one hour after the school day ends.



   (b)   Mobile food vending vehicles, including, but not limited to,
ice cream vendors, shall not stop closer than one hundred feet (100') from
the nearest intersecting road, street or highway for the purpose of selling
any food or beverage.



   (c)   Sales from such mobile food vending vehicles shall be made
from the right-hand curb side of the vehicle only when the vehicle is legally
parked. Any bells, whistles, horns, or musical noisemaking devices shall not
be sounded while the vehicle is parked. Stops shall be made only to service
customers and shall not exceed a total of thirty (30) minutes in any one
block.



   (d)   No mobile food vending vehicle shall park or stand within one
hundred feet (100') of any customer entrance to any retail or commercial
business.



   (e)   Sales from any mobile food vending vehicle are permitted only
between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) P.M.
In residential areas of the Village, sales from any mobile food vending
vehicle are permitted only between the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) noon
and eight o'clock (8:00) P.M.



   (f)   The penalty provisions of Section 1-7 of this Code shall apply
to any violation of this Section.



(Ord. 98-32, § 1, 7-27-1998)



Secs. 5-117-5-130.  Reserved:



DIVISION 4. BAKERIES



Sec. 5-131.  Definition:



   Any place or establishment used for any process of mixing, compounding
or making, for sale or the purpose of a restaurant, bakery or hotel, any
bread, biscuits, pretzels, crackers, buns, rolls, macaroni, cakes, pies or
any food product of which flour or meal is the principal ingredient, shall be
deemed a "bakery" for the purpose of this Division; provided, that
restaurants in which any of the foregoing food products are mixed and baked,
on or in an ordinary kitchen stove or range, shall not be considered to be
bakeries.



(Code 1972, § 3-7-1)



Sec. 5-132.  License Required:



   It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate a bakery in the Village
without having first obtained a license therefor. Applications for such
licenses shall be referred to the health officer for such inspections as may
be necessary to see that the provisions of this Division are complied with.



(Code 1972, § 3-7-2)



Sec. 5-133.  Sanitary Regulations; Lighting And Ventilation1:



   Every place used as a bakery shall be kept in a clean and sanitary
condition. All parts of the bakery shall be adequately lighted at all times
and shall be ventilated by means of windows or skylights or airshafts or
ducts or mechanical apparatus if necessary, to ensure a full circulation of
fresh air at all times. Such ventilation constructed and equipment shall be
of such character that a complete change of air in all parts of the bakery
may be made at least four (4) times each hour; provided, however, that it
shall not be necessary to ventilate at such times or in such a manner that
the process of mixing or raising dough shall of necessity be interfered with
or prevented.



(Code 1972, § 3-7-3)



1  410 ILCS 650/1.



Sec. 5-134.  Floors1:



   The floor of every place used as a bakery, if below street level, shall
be constructed of concrete, cement, asphalt or other impervious material or
of tile laid on cement. Such floors may if desired be covered with a hardwood
floor having tight joints or may be of any impervious material, as provided
in this Section.



(Code 1972, § 3-7-4)



1  410 ILCS 650/3.



Sec. 5-135.  Flies, Rodents, Vermin:



   Every place used as a bakery shall be kept free from flies, rodents and
vermin of all kinds.



(Code 1972, § 3-7-5)



Sec. 5-136.  Sleeping Facilities2:



   No person shall sleep, and no sleeping accommodations shall be
maintained, in any bakery or in the rooms where flour and meal used in
connection therewith, or the food products made therein, are handled or
stored.



(Code 1972, § 3-7-6)



2  410 ILCS 650/9.



Sec. 5-137.  Animals3:



   No animal shall be permitted in a bakery or where flour or meal is
stored in connection therewith.



(Code 1972, § 3-7-7)



3  See § 7-86 et seq., of this Code.



Sec. 5-138.  Employee Wearing Apparel:



   All workmen and employees, while engaged in the manufacturing or
handling of bakery products in a bakery, shall provide themselves with
slippers or shoes and a suit of washable material which shall be used for
that purpose only. These garments shall be kept clean at all times.



(Code 1972, § 3-7-8)



Sec. 5-139.  Use Of Tobacco4:



   The use of tobacco in any form in a bakery is prohibited. Notice to
this effect shall be placed in a prominent place in every bakery by the
proprietor thereof, but the absence of such notice shall not excuse any
person for such violation of this provision.



(Code 1972, § 3-7-10)



4  410 ILCS 650/8.



Sec. 5-140.  Storage Of Materials:



   All rooms for the storage of flour or meal for use in connection with
any bakery shall be dry and well ventilated, and every bakery and room used
for storage of materials and food products in connection therewith shall be
so arranged that shelves, cupboards, trays, triangles, bins and cases shall
be easily removed and cleaned.



(Code 1972, § 3-7-11)



Sec. 5-141.  Labels On Bread5:



   All bread sold or offered for sale at retail shall bear on each loaf a
tag or wrapper showing the true weight of such loaf.



(Code 1972, § 3-7-12)



5  225 ILCS 470/45.



Sec. 5-142.  Inspection:



   It shall be the duty of the health officer to make or cause to be made
such inspections as may be necessary to see to it that the provisions of this
Division are fully complied with.



(Code 1969, Ch. 11, Art. 7; Code 1972, § 3-7-13)



Secs. 5-143-5-155.  Reserved:



DIVISION 5. AUTOMATIC FOOD VENDING MACHINES



Sec. 5-156.  Definitions1:



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this Division,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this Section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Automatic Food Vending Machine: Any mechanical container or device used
for the sale of any article of food, the operation of which is governed or
controlled by the deposit of a coin or token.



   Food: Any cooked or uncooked article of food, drink, condiment or
confection used for or intended to be used for human consumption.



   Multiple Automatic Food Vending Machine: An automatic food vending
machine equipped with or containing a plural number of magazines, columns,
shelves or other compartments for the holding of food.



   Single Automatic Food Vending Machine: An automatic food vending
machine equipped with or containing one magazine, column, shelf or other
compartment for the holding of food.



(Code 1972, § 3-8-1)



1  410 ILCS 620/2.29.



Sec. 5-157.  License-Required:



   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person to deliver or install any
automatic food vending machine within the Village without first having
obtained a license to do so.



   (b)   It shall be unlawful for any person to install, keep, maintain
or use or permit the installation, keeping, maintenance or use upon his
premises of any automatic food vending machine for which a license has not
been issued for the current year.



(Code 1972, § 3-8-2)



Sec. 5-158.  License-Application:



   An application for an automatic food vending machine license shall be
made in conformity with the general requirements of this Code relating to
applications for licenses. In addition, the applicant shall set forth the
number of automatic food vending machines intended to be installed and a
description of each, which description shall contain the manufacturer's name,
the make and factory number thereof, whether a single or multiple machine,
together with the monetary value of the coin or coins used to operate the
machine. The application shall also set forth such further information as may
be required by the health officer in order to inform him fully as to the type
or types of machines and the kind or kinds of food to be dispensed therefrom.
Before any license shall be issued, the board of health shall cause an
inspection to be made to determine the character and fitness of the machine
or machines from the standpoint of ensuring protection of food from improper
handling, dust, dirt, flies, vermin or other contamination.



(Code 1972, § 3-8-3)



Sec. 5-159.  Installation Of Additional Machines:



   Upon the filing of a supplemental application and the payment of the
prescribed fees, a licensee shall be entitled to install additional machines
at the location or locations designated in such supplemental application.



(Code 1972, § 3-8-4)



Sec. 5-160.  Change Of Location:



   Change of location of any licensed vending machine during any license
period may be authorized by the village upon application therefor.



(Code 1972, § 3-8-5; Ord. 2009-15, § 26, 6-22-2009)



Sec. 5-161.  Location Of Machines:



   No automatic food vending machine shall be installed or kept for use in
any toilet room or washroom.



(Code 1972, § 3-8-6)



Sec. 5-162.  Condition Of Food In Machines; Periodic Inspection:



   (a)   All articles of food purveyed by means of automatic food
vending machines shall be clean, wholesome, free from taint, decay or
infection, and shall contain no poisonous, deleterious or injurious
ingredients in kind and quantities so as to render such article injurious or
detrimental to health.



   (b)   The health officer shall make periodic inspections of all
automatic food vending machines and articles of food purveyed therefrom for
the purpose of determining the purity and wholesomeness of the products
vended, the preparation, wrapping and handling of the same and to see that
all requirements of this division and the health provisions of this Code are
met and complied with, including the operation and use of such machines, to
guard against improper handling, distribution and contamination of food
purveyed thereby.



(Code 1969, Ch. 11, Art. 8; Code 1972, § 3-8-7)



Secs. 5-163-5-175.  Reserved:



DIVISION 6. DRIVE-IN RESTAURANTS



Sec. 5-176.  Definition:



   The term "drive-in" as used in this division shall mean any
establishment as such where automobile parking is available on the premises
and food is served to such automobiles by attendants (carhops).



(Code 1972, § 3-17-1)



Sec. 5-177.  License-Required:



   It shall be unlawful to establish or operate any drive-in restaurant,
snack shop or refreshment stand in the village without first having secured a
license therefor as herein provided. Application for such license shall
comply with general provisions relating to applications for licenses and
permits.



(Code 1972, § 3-17-2)



Sec. 5-178.  Same-Fee:



   The license fee for a drive-in restaurant, snack shop or refreshment
stand shall be seventy-five dollars ($75.00).



(Ord. No. 61-12, 10-5-1961; Code 1972, § 3-17-3)



Secs. 5-179-5-190.  Reserved:



DIVISION 7. MILK* 2



*  State law reference—Power of village to adopt by reference codes for
the production, pasteurization and sale of milk and milk products, Ill. Rev.
Stat. Ch. 85, § 1001 et seq.



Sec. 5-191.  Definition; Standards:



   (a)   Milk is the whole, fresh, clean lacteal secretion obtained
from the milking of one (1) or more cows. Unless the context otherwise
indicates, the term "milk" when used in this division shall include whole
milk, skimmed milk, sour milk, cream, sour cream, buttermilk, cultured
buttermilk and milk beverages.



   (b)   All milk shall conform to the standards fixed by the Grade A
Pasteurized Milk and Milk Products Act, as amended.



   (c)   It shall be unlawful under this division for anyone to sell,
offer for sale or have in his possession with intent to sell any milk not
conforming to such standards.



(Code 1972, § 7-3-1)



   State law references-Grade A Pasteurized Milk and Milk Products Act,
Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 56 1/2, § 2201 et seq.; definitions relating to milk and
milk products, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 56 1/2, § 2203.



Sec. 5-192.  Colostrum Prohibited:



   No milk that contains colostrum in any amount whatsoever shall be sold,
offered for sale, exposed for sale, delivered or distributed within the
village.



(Code 1972, § 7-3-2)



Sec. 5-193.  Sale In Original Container:



   (a)   No milk, cream, skimmed milk, buttermilk, sour milk or any
other milk product shall be peddled or sold at retail in quantities of one
(1) gallon or less except in original containers bearing the true name of the
article, the name and address of the producer, dealer or distributor and the
net volume of the contents.



   (b)   All milk must be sealed in sterilized containers immediately
after pasteurization and retained in these original containers until
delivered to the ultimate consumer.



   (c)   No person shall sell milk in any bottle or container other
than those bearing the seller's name or to which he has acquired title.



   (d)   It shall be unlawful to sell any milk containing any
artificial color or preservative or to which water or any foreign substance
has been added or which has been handled or transported in unclean or
unsanitary vessels or containers.



(Code 1972, § 7-3-3)



Sec. 5-194.  Contagion In Handling:



   All persons handling or in contact with the milk in dairies or other
places shall be free from contagious or infectious diseases, and shall not
have been exposed to any person having a contagious disease.



(Code 1972, § 7-3-4)



Sec. 5-195.  Contagion In Production:



   (a)   No person who is a typhoid, paratyphoid, diphtheria or septic
sore throat carrier shall be employed in the production of or handling of
milk.



   (b)   It shall be the duty of every person with the knowledge of the
facts to notify the committee on health or other legally qualified
authorities at once by telephone or otherwise of the occurrence of any
sickness in any person living or employed in any place where milk is
produced, handled or sold. Milk and milk derivatives which have been exposed
to contagion or which are suspected of having been so exposed, shall not be
shipped into or sold in the village unless the consent of the committee on
health or other legally qualified authority has been secured.



(Code 1972, § 7-3-5)



Sec. 5-196.  Pasteurization:



   (a)   The term "pasteurization" is hereby defined as a process by
which all milk is heated to a temperature of one hundred forty-three (143)
degrees to one hundred forty-five (145) degrees Fahrenheit and all held at
this temperature for a period of not less than thirty (30) minutes or heating
to at least one hundred sixty (160) degrees Fahrenheit and holding at such
temperature for thirty (30) seconds in pasteurizers approved by the committee
on health. Pasteurized milk shall be promptly cooled to a temperature of
fifty (50) degrees Fahrenheit or below and shall be held at or below fifty
(50) degrees Fahrenheit until delivered to the consumer.



   (b)   There shall be attached to each milk pasteurizing machine an
automatic recording device by which the temperature of the milk and the
length of time heated shall be recorded upon a chart. These charts shall be
available for inspection by the committee on health. Each pasteurizer shall
be equipped with an accurate indicating thermometer with which the recording
device must be frequently checked.



   (c)   All pasteurized milk or cream shall carry a label on which
plainly appears the word "pasteurized," the date of pasteurization in
conjunction with the words "milk," "cream," "buttermilk" or "skimmed milk,"
as the case may be.



   (d)   All bottling and capping must be done by a machine of an
approved type.



(Code 1972, § 7-3-6)



Sec. 5-197.  Sale Of Milk:



   (a)   No milk, cream, buttermilk, or other milk products shall be
sold in the village which have not been pasteurized according to this
division and which do not conform to the standards set by the Grade A
Pasteurized Milk and Milk Products Act, as amended.



   (b)   No milk shall be sold that has more than a perceptible amount
of sediment or stain other than that of natural butterfat when one (1) pint
is filtered through a cotton disc one (1) inch in diameter.



   (c)   No milk or milk products shall be put into bottles or other
containers except those which have been subjected to boiling water or live
steam or other approved methods sufficient to destroy pathogenic bacteria.



(Code 1972, § 7-3-7)



   State law reference-Grade A Pasteurized Milk and Milk Products Act,
Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 56 1/2, § 2201 et seq.



Sec. 5-198.  Cleaning Of Containers; Quarantined Premises:



   (a)   Any person licensed under this division who receives from any
other person any fresh milk in cans, bottles or other containers of any kind
shall cause the cans, bottles or other containers to be emptied before the
milk contained therein shall become sour, and shall cause the cans, bottles
or other containers to be immediately washed and thoroughly cleaned and aired.



   (b)   When a communicable disease appears on premises where milk is
produced, handled or sold, the exchange, removal or distribution in any
manner whatsoever of milk, cream or milk products found, produced or handled
on such premises is strictly prohibited, until the quarantine has been
terminated and the premises and contents thereof, including all milk
utensils, have been disinfected under the supervision of the health officer.



   (c)   Milk may be delivered at quarantined premises, provided that
there is no contact of any kind between the inmates and contents of the
quarantined premises and the delivery agents.



   (d)   The householder may place a thoroughly clean container (a
freshly scalded bottle or pail) to receive the milk at some convenient place
outside the house out of reach of dogs or cats. The milkman shall then place
the milk therein without handling the receiving container. No milk bottle,
basket or any other article whatsoever shall be taken out of or away from the
quarantined premises during the period of quarantine. Before milk bottles are
removed from the premises after the quarantine is raised, they must be
sterilized under the direction of the health officer.



(Code 1972, § 7-3-8)



Sec. 5-199.  Milk Plants:



   (a)   All milk and milk products must be handled in a milk plant
approved by the village health officer. This plant is to be properly lighted,
screened and ventilated, with watertight floor, smooth and tight side walls
and ceilings, good drainage, proper toilet facilities, with equipment so
constructed as to permit easy cleaning and sterilizing daily. Such premises
shall not be directly connected with any dwelling house or stable. Such milk
plant shall meet the requirements laid down in the Grade A Pasteurized Milk
and Milk Products Act, as amended.



   (b)   All premises where milk is handled must be kept in a clean and
sanitary condition, free from contaminating surroundings, and all equipment
used for handling of the milk to be cleaned daily as prescribed by the health
officer.



   (c)   No such place shall employ any operative, clerk or other
employee who has a communicable disease or who is a carrier of such disease.
Persons who have previously had typhoid or paratyphoid fever must show to the
satisfaction of the health authorities that they are not carriers of typhoid
or paratyphoid bacilli.



(Code 1972, § 7-3-9)



   State law reference-Grade A Pasteurized Milk and Milk Products Act,
Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 56 1/2, § 2201 et seq.



Sec. 5-200.  Delivery Vehicles:



   (a)   Any person who shall engage in the wholesale or retail milk
business shall have each vehicle from which milk is vended conspicuously
marked with the name and address of the vendor on both sides of the vehicle
and shall have attached to the vehicle the license tag issued for the purpose
by the health officer.



   (b)   All vehicles in which milk is transported must be kept in a
clean and sanitary condition and no bottling shall be done in transit.



(Code 1972, § 7-3-10)



Sec. 5-201.  Violation; Hearing:



   When it appears from the records that this division has been violated,
the health officer or other legally qualified authority shall cause notice of
such fact to be given to the party or parties concerned. The party or parties
so notified shall be given an opportunity to be heard. The notice shall
specify the date, hour and place of the hearing, which shall be private. If,
after such hearing the health officer or other legally qualified authority
shall believe this division has been violated, the health officer or other
authority shall cause the party or parties concerned to be prosecuted.



(Code 1972, § 7-3-11)



Sec. 5-202.  License Required:



   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a store known
as a milk store or a vehicle or vehicles for the delivery of milk without
first obtaining a license to do so.



   (b)   The owner or the representative of the firm or corporation
shall make application to the village in writing. The village shall refer the
application to the health officer. If the health officer is satisfied that
the owner has met with all requirements of the state and village health laws,
he shall recommend at the next regular board meeting the issuing of a license.



   (c)   The fee for the license for a milk store or a milk delivery
vehicle shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per year for each store or
vehicle. The fee for a milk pasteurization plant shall be two hundred dollars
($200.00) a year.



(Code 1969, Ch. 11, Art. 9; Code 1972, § 7-3-12; Ord. 2009-15, § 27,
6-22-2009)



Secs. 5-203-5-220.  Reserved:



ARTICLE IV. AIR POLLUTION CONTROL*



*  Cross reference—Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 4.



State law references—Municipal air contamination control, Ill. Rev. Stat.
Ch. 24, § 11-19.1-11; air pollution generally, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 1111/2,
§ 1008 et seq.; municipal waste incineration emission standards, III. Rev.
Stat. Ch. 111%, § 1009.4.



Sec. 5-221.  Purpose:



   The intent and purpose of this article is to promote and to protect the
public health, safety, comfort, convenience and the general welfare of the
people; to protect the village from the harmful effects of airborne
pollutants; to ensure high standards of light and air in areas where people
live and work; to maintain and improve accepted air pollution control
practices; to control emissions from all potential hazards or nuisances.



(Code 1972, § 7-4-1)



Sec. 5-222.  Smoke And Particulate Matter:



   (a)   Compliance with standards. Any use of equipment, devices or
processes which emits smoke and/or particulate matter into the atmosphere
shall comply with the performance standards governing smoke and particulate
matter set forth hereinafter for the control zone in which such use shall be
located, as established in section 5-223. In addition to the performance
standards specified herein, the smoke and particulate matter shall meet the
standards for toxic matter and noxious and odorous matter indicated in
sections 5-224 and 5-225 respectively.



   (b)   Smoke density opacity standards; method of measurement.
Density or equivalent opacity of smoke shall be measured by the Ringelmann
chart, published and used by the United States Bureau of Mines. Measurements
shall be taken at the point of greatest density, which shall usually be at
the point of emission.



      (1)   Maximum density allowed. The emission of smoke or
particulate matter of a density greater than No. 2 on the Ringelmann chart is
prohibited at all times, except as provided for hereinafter.



      (2)   Performance standards by control zone. Smoke density
emission shall conform to the requirements of section 5-223 according to the
control zone location of the source.



   (c)   Particulate matter standards. Particulate matter emission into
the atmosphere shall be relative to lot size and location.



      (1)    Size limitations. The emission from all sources within
any lot area of particulate matter containing more than ten (10) percent by
weight of particles having a diameter larger than forty-four (44) microns is
prohibited.



      (2)    Maximum weight of emission. The total emission weight
of particulate matter from all fuel-burning, combustion or process equipment
or devices within the boundaries of any lot shall not exceed those values
given in section 5-223. In addition, the dust loading of gas leaving an air
pollution source, when measured in accordance with the provisions of ASME PTC
27-Determining Dust Concentrations in a Gas Stream, 1957 Edition, shall not
exceed thirty-five hundredths grain per cubic foot of gas (S.T.P.). For
combustion processes this measurement shall be computed at fifty (50) percent
excess air.



      (3)    Method of measurement. Determination of the total net
rate of emission of particulate matter within the boundaries of any lot shall
be made as follows:



         a.    Determine the maximum emission in pounds per hour
from each source of emission and divide this figure by the number of acres of
lot area, thereby obtaining the gross hourly rate of emission in pounds per
acre.



         b.    From each gross hourly rate of emission derived in
paragraph a. above, deduct the correction factor (interpolating as required)
for height of emission set forth in section 5-223, thereby obtaining the net
rate of emission in pounds per acre per hour from each source of emission.



         c.    Add together the individual net rates of emission
derived in paragraph b. above, to obtain the total net rate of emission from
all sources of emission within the boundaries of the lot. Such total shall
not exceed the limitations established in section 5-223.



   (d)   Open fires. The open burning of refuse, paint, oil,
automobiles, debris or any other combustible material within the village
shall be prohibited, with holiday and festive celebrations and other special
occasions, or the burning of dead or diseased vegetation or similar debris
when no other method of disposal is feasible, set and attended by personnel
trained in firefighting techniques, fire containment and the use of
firefighting equipment. Such fires shall be allowed only by special permit
issued by the village board.



   (e)   Materials subject to becoming windborne.



      (1)    Generally. Dusts and other types of air pollution borne
by the wind from such sources as storage areas, yards, roads and so forth
within lot boundaries shall be kept to a minimum by such measures as wetting
piles, landscaping, paving, oiling or other acceptable means.



      (2)    Handling. It shall be unlawful for any person to cause
or permit the handling, loading, unloading, reloading, storing, transferring,
transporting, placing, depositing, throwing, discarding or scattering of any
ashes, fly ash, cinders, slag or dust collected from any combustion process,
any dust, dirt, chaff, wastepaper, trash, rubbish, waste or refuse matter of
any kind or any other substance or material whatever which is likely to be
scattered by the wind, or is susceptible to being windborne without taking
reasonable measures or precautions so as to minimize atmospheric pollution or
nuisance to other property.



      (3)    Storage. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate
or maintain or cause to be operated or maintained any building, structure or
premises, open area, right-of-way, storage pile of materials, vessel or
vehicle, or construction, alteration, building, demolition or wrecking
operation or any other enterprise which has or involves any matter, material
or substance likely to be scattered by the wind or susceptible to being
windborne, without taking reasonable precautions or measures so as to
minimize atmospheric pollution nuisance to other property.



      (4)    Surfacing of roads and vehicle areas. No person shall
maintain or conduct, or cause to be maintained or conducted, any parking or
automotive or machinery sales lot or any private roadway unless such real
property is covered or treated with a surface or substance or otherwise
maintained in such manner as to minimize atmospheric pollution or nuisance to
other property.



      (5)    Trucking. Trucks carrying material subject to becoming
airborne shall be operated in such a manner as to keep such airborne
materials to a minimum by such measures as wetting the load, covering the
load with canvas, lessening the load or other acceptable means.



(Code 1972, § 7-4-2)



   State law reference-Acts causing air pollution prohibited, Ill. Rev.
Stat. Ch. 111 1/2, § 1009.



Sec. 5-223.  Performance standards by control zone.



   In all residential and business districts and the industrial district,
as established and defined in Chapter 12 of this Code:



      (1)    The emission of more than twenty (20) smoke units per
hour per stack is prohibited, including smoke of a density in excess of
Ringelmann No. 2. However, once during any six-hour period each stack may
emit up to thirty-five (35) smoke units, not to exceed Ringelmann No. 2, when
blowing soot or cleaning fires. Only during fire-cleaning periods, however,
shall smoke of Ringelmann No. 3 be permitted, and then for not more than four
(4) minutes per period.



      (2)    The rate of emission of particulate matter from all
sources within the boundaries of any lot shall not exceed a net figure of one
(1) pound per acre of lot area during any one (1) hour, after deducting from
the gross hourly emission per acre the correction factor set forth in the
following table:



 




Allowance for Height of Emissions*
