ARTICLE I.  IN GENERAL



Secs. 8-1-8-15.  Reserved:



ARTICLE II.  BUILDINGS



DIVISION 1. GENERALLY



Secs. 8-16-8-30.  Reserved:



DIVISION 2. BUILDING CODE



Sec. 8-31.  General Provisions:



   (a)   Title: This division shall be known and may be cited as the
BUILDING CODE OF THE VILLAGE.



   (b)   Building Officers: The title "building officers" when used in
this division shall mean the building commissioner, the chief of police, the
fire chief, the health officer and all inspectors and assistants, as provided
herein or by the board of trustees. All such inspectors and assistants are
under the jurisdiction of and subject to the control of the building
commissioner.



   (c)   Right To Enter Premises: Building officers and their duly
authorized inspectors are hereby empowered, during reasonable hours, to
lawfully enter upon any premises or into any building or structure or portion
thereof, whether completed or in the process of construction, alteration or
repair, when necessary to do so in performance of any duty imposed upon them
by the laws of the village or the provisions of the zoning chapter1, or any
order or resolution of the board of trustees. It is hereby made unlawful for
any person to hinder or prevent, or attempt to hinder or prevent, any such
building officers or their duly authorized inspectors from performing their
respective duties. Any person hindering or attempting to hinder, resisting or
attempting to resist, any building officer in the performance of duty, shall
be charged with resisting an officer. The person convicted of such offense
shall be subject to the general penalty provided for violations of this code.



   (d)   Definitions: Words and terms used in this division, not
otherwise defined, shall have the meanings defined in the zoning chapter.



   (e)   Adoption Of Building Codes: The following codes are hereby
adopted and incorporated into this division as though fully set forth herein,
and all such rules and regulations shall apply to all buildings, structures
and appurtenances in the village:



      (1)   The 2012 International Building Code, with the exception
of the International Fire Code provisions contained therein.



      (2)   The 2012 International Residential Building Code, with
the exception of the International Fire Code provisions contained therein.



      (3)   The 2013 Electrical Code of the City of Chicago.



      (4)   The 2014 Illinois Plumbing Code, with the exception of
local code for allowable materials.



      (5)   The 2012 National Fire Protection Association (NFPA)
Fire Prevention and Life Safety Code.



      (6)   The 2012 International Property Maintenance Code.



      (7)   The rules, regulations and recommendations of the office
of the Illinois State Fire Marshal.



      (8)   The 2012 International Existing Building Code.



      (9)   The 2012 International Mechanical Code.



      (10)   The 2012 International Energy Code.



      (11)   The 2012 International Fuel Gas Code.



   (12)   The 2012 International Swimming Pool and Spa Code.



   (f)   Conflicting Provisions: If there is any conflict in the codes
adopted in this section and other village ordinance provisions, the more
restrictive provision shall apply. (Code 1972, §§ 4-1-1, 4-1-5; Ord. 82-7,
8-19-1982; Ord. 95-9, § 1, 5-22-1995; Ord. 97-33, §§ 1, 2, 10-13-1997;
Ord. 98-17, §§ 1, 5, 4-27-1998; Ord. 2000-33, § 1, 7-24-2000; Ord.
2003-20, § 1, 5-27-2003; Ord. 2005-24, § 1, 11-14-2005; Ord. 2013-01, § 1,
2-11-2013; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



1  See chapter 12 of this code.



Sec. 8-32.  Permits; Fees; Traffic Control:



   (a)   When Permit Required: Before proceeding with the erection,
construction, alteration, addition, repair, removal or excavation of any
building or structure in the village, a permit for such erection,
construction, alteration, addition, repair, removal or excavation shall first
be obtained by the owner or his agent from the building commissioner as
provided herein. As evidence that such permit has been issued, the building
permit card must be posted on the street side of the building when excavation
is started, kept posted during the entire time of construction, and for ten
(10) days after completion of the building.



   (b)   Time Limit Of Permit: If, after such permit shall have been
granted, the operation covered by the permit shall not be begun within six
(6) months after the date thereof, or if such operations are not completed
within one year from such date, then such permit shall expire by the terms
thereof, and no operations thereunder shall be begun or completed until a
renewal of the permit shall be obtained, as provided in subsection (h) of
this section.



   (c)   Permit Waived For Ordinary Repair Work: A permit will not be
required for ordinary repair work incidental to the upkeep of a building or
structure, provided there is not contemplated, nor involved, any change in
the classification or use or any increase in the fire hazard thereof; nor the
removal or installing of any external wall; nor the removal of any supporting
wall, column, poles, truss, girder or beam; nor the installing, closing or
changing of any stairs, exits, scuttles, skylights or fire escapes; nor
changing the number, location or connections of the fixtures, traps, vents,
waste, soil or drainpipes of the plumbing system; nor changing the number,
location or connections of the electrical system; nor reshingling or
recovering of roofs or the renewing of the exterior woodwork of any frame
building, structure or portion thereof. Nothing in this subsection shall be
interpreted or construed to allow any work included in the permit exemptions
thereof to be done in any manner contrary to the requirements of the building
code and other laws of the village.



   (d)   Application For Permits; Plans:



      (1)   Application for building permits shall be made by the
owner or his agent to the building commissioner on forms prepared and kept on
file in the office of the building commissioner. Such application shall
describe the location of the proposed work by setting forth the correct legal
description of the land upon which the building, structure or part thereof is
to be erected, constructed, added, altered or repaired and the street name
and number assigned to the site; the purpose for which the building or
structure is designed to be used; the length, width and height thereof, the
number of rooms; the total cost of the work proposed to be done under the
permit sought; the name and address of the owner or his authorized agent or
architect; the names of the licensed general contractors and subcontractors
such as mason, carpenter, sewer builder, plumber, heating and air
conditioning contractor, fire sprinkler contractor, fire alarm contractor,
and electrician. The application for a building permit shall also be
accompanied by a plat of survey, showing the proposed location of the
building to be erected on the lot, piece or parcel of land. The application
shall also contain an agreement to be signed by the owner, his agent or
architect conditioned that he or his duly authorized agent or architect, if
granted the permit sought, will construct the work in accordance with the
description set forth in the application and accompanying plans and
specifications.



      (2)   Application for building permits shall be accompanied by
plans and specifications which shall be sufficiently complete that the
proposed structure could be constructed therefrom by a competent contractor,
builder or engineer, without further direction of any kind.



      (3)   All such plans and drawings shall be drawn to the scale
of not less than one quarter  of an inch to the foot (1/4":1') on paper, in
ink, or by some process that will not fade or obliterate. All distances and
dimensions shall be accurately figured, and drawings made explicit and
complete, showing the lot lines and the location of the exterior lines of the
building in relation thereto, and the entire ventilating, sewerage and
drainpipes and the location of all plumbing fixtures within such building.



      No person shall be granted or plans approved unless such plans
are made and signed by such persons, licensed or registered architects or
registered structural engineers, as are permitted under the statutes of the
state to make plans for buildings.



      True copies of so much of the plans as may be required, in the
opinion of the building commissioner, to illustrate the features of the
construction and equipment of the building referred to, shall be filed with
the building commissioner, and shall remain on file in his office for a
period of six (6) months after the occupation of such building, after which
such plans may be returned only to the person by whom they have been
deposited with him, upon demand. It shall not be obligatory upon the building
commissioner to retain such plans in his custody for more than six (6) months
after the occupation of the building to which they relate.



      Complete plans and specifications of buildings for public or
business use for which permits are granted shall remain on file permanently
in the building commissioner’s office.



      In all cases, the approved plan or plans, together with building
permits, must be kept on the premises while the work is in progress.



      (4)   The building commissioner shall not issue any permit
authorizing the erection, construction, alteration, addition or repair of any
building or structure unless the plans submitted for his approval clearly
show that such building or structure with all its appurtenances, foundations
and attachments can be erected entirely within the limits of the lot or tract
of land upon which it is proposed to erect such building or structure, except
as provided by the building code and chapter 12 of this code, and no permit
to construct or alter any building or structure shall authorize the use of
any part of any public highway or other public ground unless permits therefor
have been obtained from the village board pursuant to an ordinance
specifically authorizing the same, nor, in the case of subdivisions where no
alleys are provided to service the lot, shall a permit be issued unless the
building or structure is so constructed on the lot to provide room for a side
drive.



      (5)   A contour map of the proposed lot or lots based upon a
permanent bench mark which can be reproduced at any time during or
immediately following completion of construction shall be submitted with the
application for building permit. This contour map shall show the following:



         a.   Foundation elevations of any existing adjacent
buildings and dimensions to the buildings.



         b.   Street and ditch elevations existing prior to
construction.



         c.   If the proposed lot or lots are located in a flood
zone, an elevation certificate shall also be provided.



   (e)   Issuance Of Permits:



      (1)   Permits authorized to be issued and required to be
obtained under this division shall be promptly issued by the building
commissioner when the application, approval of plans, filing of frontage
consents (if any required) and giving of notices are all completed as in this
division. But this shall not be construed to deny to the building
commissioner ample time to investigate any matters.



      (2)   No permits herein provided to be issued for the
erection, construction, alteration, addition, repair or excavation for any
wall, structure, building or any portion thereof, for which a fee is
prescribed by this division shall be in force until the fees prescribed
therefor shall have been paid.



   (f)   Alterations In Plans: It shall be unlawful to alter or in any
way modify plans which have been approved by the building commissioner, as
hereinbefore provided. If, during the progress of such work, it is desired to
deviate, in any manner affecting the construction or other essentials of the
building, from terms of the application or drawing, notice of such intention
to alter or deviate shall be given to the building commissioner, and his
written assent shall first be obtained before the alteration or deviation may
be made. Alterations in buildings which do not involve any change in their
structural parts, or of their stairways, elevators, fire escapes or other
communications of ingress or egress, or in lighting or ventilation or in
plumbing or electric wiring, and that are not in violation of any of the
provisions of this division, or the provisions of chapter 12 of this code,
may be made without the permission of the building commissioner.



   (g)   Temporary Permit: Where in the judgment of the building
commissioner it is justified, the building commissioner may authorize
building operations to commence and proceed for such limited time, not
exceeding ten (10) days, and the building commissioner may deem and fix as
sufficient to allow the owner, his architect or authorized agent to complete
the filing of detailed plans and other data required for the issuance of the
final permit. The applicant for a temporary permit shall furnish the building
commissioner with sufficient plans and data to enable the building
commissioner to determine that the work to be commenced, and proposed
subsequently to be done, is of a lawful nature. Temporary permits shall be
revocable at the will of the building commissioner.



   (h)   Permit Fees: The fees to be charged for building permits for
erecting, altering, repairing or adding to buildings shall be paid to the
village before issuance of any permits provided herein and as follows:



      (1)   For buildings, structures and additions of property
located in zoning districts R-1 and R-2, shall be as set forth in section
13-1 of this code with a minimum fee as set forth in section 13-1 of this
code.



      (2)   For buildings, structures and additions of property
located in zoning districts R-3, B-1, C-1, I-1, I-1-R and I-2 in accordance
with the fees in section 13-1 of this code.



      (3)   For residential garages only, shall be as set forth in
section 13-1 of this code which shall include electrical work.



      (4)   For wrecking or removal of buildings, shall be as set
forth in section 13-1 of this code per square foot with a minimum fee as set
forth in section 13-1 of this code.



      (5)   For certificate of occupancy, shall be as set forth in
section 13-1 of this code for garages only. Occupancy bonds shall be
refundable upon appropriate completion of the project subject to final
inspection by the appropriate authority. The full amount of the cash bond or
equivalent shall be forfeited to the village at the rate of ten percent (10%)
of such deposit per day that this section has been violated.



      (6)   For miscellaneous building permits, including but not
limited to, foundation installment; shingle roof repair or replacement; flat
roof repair or replacement; siding; gutters; soffit and fascia; window and
door replacement; furnace installation; air conditioning installation;
fireplace installation; concrete flat work (patios, aprons, and stoops), and
placement of dumpsters; the permit and inspection fee shall be as set forth
in section 13-1 of this code.



      (7)   At the time a foundation permit is applied for, the
applicant shall post a cash bond as set forth in section 13-1 of this code.
At time of completion of the foundation, all work will cease, until a spot
survey has been submitted to the village engineer for approval and said
approval has been acknowledged by the building commissioner.



      Additionally, the building commissioner shall require a copy of
the approved spot survey and shall review and confirm the approval of the
village engineer before work may proceed and the portion of the bond
associated with the foundation is released.



      If the spot survey is found to be in error, all monies will be
forfeited to the village and either removal of the foundation or submittal of
a petition for variance of zoning may be required, at the option of the
village.



      (8)   In addition to the permit fees named in this section,
there shall be paid such charges for water, used in connection with building
operations, as are fixed by the schedule of water rates in force, or as the
same may be amended from time to time by the board of trustees.



      (9)   For renewal of a building or foundation permit issued as
herein provided and which has expired by the terms thereof as provided for in
subsection (b) of this section, payment of an additional fee of fifty percent
(50%) of the original fee shall be required.



      All fees shall be forfeited to the village upon expiration of the
permit and within six (6) months thereafter either: a) a failure to commence
operations, b) a failure to renew permit, or c) a failure to file a request
for permit fee refunds.



   (i)   Issuance Denied To Violators: No person applying for a
building permit under the provisions of this division shall be entitled to
the issuance of a building permit if such person shall be in violation of any
of the provisions of this code, including this division or any provisions of
the zoning chapter or shall be indebted unto the village in any amount.



   (j)   Surety Bond (License Or Permit Bond): (Repealed)



   (k)   Penalty: Any owner or agent who is required to obtain a permit
under subsection (a) of this section and begins any work prior to obtaining
said permit shall pay a penalty to the village in the amount of twice the
permit fee specified in subsection (h) of this section, unless the permit fee
is over one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), then the penalty shall be limited
to fifty percent (50%) of the permit fee, exclusive of other costs or cash
donations. The permit shall not be issued until the original permit fee plus
the penalty is paid in full to the village.



   (l)   Building Development Fee: Each applicant for a building permit
of new construction, or for a tear down/rebuild, or for conversion of any
unit from multi-family to single-family, or vice versa, shall, prior to the
issuance of such building permit, pay in addition to the amounts specified
elsewhere in this article, the amount as set forth in section 13-1 of this
code.



(Ord., 8-5-1965; Ord. 70-10, 7-16-1970; Code 1972, § 4-1-2; Ord. 74-3,
2-7-1974; Ord. 74-14, 7-18-1974; Ord. 86-8, 3-10-1986; Ord. 86-35, 11-8-1986;
Ord. 86-45, 12-29-1986; Ord. 91-16, § 1, 6-24-1991; Ord. 91-29, § 1,
9-9-1991; Ord. 93-16, § 1, 7-12-1993; Ord. 93-30, §§ 2-4, 9-13-1993; Ord.
94-6, §§ 1, 2, 5-23-1994; Ord. 94-21, § 1, 10-24-1994; Ord. 95-3, § 1,
2-27-1995; Ord. 95-29, § 1, 11-13-1995; Ord. 98-6, § 2, 2-9-1998; Ord.
98-12, §§ 1, 2, 3-23-1998; Ord. 99-12, § 1, 4-12-1999; Ord. 2000-54, § 1,
10-9-2000; Ord. 2002-22, § 1, 6-24-2002; Ord. 2003-41, §§ 2, 3,
12-22-2003; Ord. 2004-27, § 2, 11-8-2004; Ord. 2006-02, § 1, 1-9-2006; Ord.
2010-01, § 2, 1-11-2010; Ord. 2014-20, § 1, 10-13-2014; Ord. 2016-20, § 1,
5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-33.  Certificate Of Occupancy:



   (a)   Required: No building or structure shall be occupied or used,
in whole or in part, until a certificate of occupancy shall have been issued
by the building commissioner and posted on the premises stating the purpose
for which the building may be used in its several parts, the maximum
permissible live loads on the several floors, the number of occupants that
may be accommodated in the several stories, in case such number is limited by
a provision of law or by the permit and all special stipulations of the
permit, if any.



   (b)   Temporary Certificate Of Occupancy: Upon request of the holder
of a permit, or of the owner if the holder of the permit is legally dissolved
or in legal bankruptcy, the building commissioner may issue a temporary
certificate of occupancy for part of a building or structure; provided, that
such temporary occupancy or use would not jeopardize life or property and the
following terms and conditions for final grading have been met. The request
for a temporary occupancy permit must be turned in to the building department
no later than two (2) weeks prior to a contractor's closing on the property.
In no event shall a certificate of temporary occupancy remain valid for a
period beyond six (6) months from the date of issuance. Failure to complete
any of the terms and conditions for final grading within the six (6) month
period of the temporary occupancy forfeits the cash bond required under this
section to the village of Justice. A violation of the Village engineer's
recommendations and approved plans and specification as well as the lapse of
the temporary occupancy certificate shall be a violation of this section. The
building commissioner shall have the ability to determine if a violation of
this section exists at any given time. Once the cash bond has been forfeited
under this section, it shall be the village of Justice's responsibility to
finish completion of the landscaping and grading in accordance with the
approved plans and specifications.



In order to secure compliance with this section, there shall be deposited
with the building commissioner, at the time of filing of an application for a
temporary certificate of occupancy, a cash bond or equivalent in an amount of
the estimated cost of final grading and landscaping as determined by the
building commissioner's sole judgement, or in the amount of six thousand
dollars ($6,000.00) per unit. The full amount of the cash bond shall be
forfeited to the village for violation of this section as determined by the
reasonable judgment of the building commissioner. Such forfeiture shall not
impair the village's right to enforce any and all other remedies available to
it by reason of such violation of this section, including the right to
recover a fine or penalty or seek injunctive relief. Completion of final
grading shall consist of two inches (2") of black dirt graded per the
approved site plan, maintained four inches (4") below the top of the
foundation. All grading must be landscaped or sodded completely to the
satisfaction of the building commissioner. Any amounts of the deposit that
remain due and owing to depositor shall be returned to depositor upon
completion of the final grading and landscaping and the issuance of a
certificate of occupancy.



   (c)   Altered Buildings Or Structures: No building or structure
enlarged or extended, or so altered, wholly or in part, as to change its
classification of occupancy, and no altered building or structure for which a
certificate of occupancy has not been heretofore issued, shall be occupied or
used, in whole or in part, until a certificate of occupancy shall have been
issued by the building commissioner; provided, that if the occupancy or use
of such building was not discontinued during the work or alteration, the
occupancy or use of the building or structure shall not continue for more
than thirty (30) days after completion of the alteration unless such
certificate shall have been issued.



   (d)   Certificate For Change Of Occupancy:



       (1)    No change of occupancy shall be made in a building or
structure that is not consistent with the last issued certificate of
occupancy for such building or structure, unless a new certificate of
occupancy is secured.



      (2)    The occupancy of a building or structure shall not be
deemed to have changed because of a temporary vacancy or change of ownership
or tenancy. The reestablishment in a building or structure, after a change of
occupancy has been made, of a prior use that is not permitted in a new
building or structure of the same type of construction is prohibited. The
change from a specifically prohibited use to another specifically prohibited
use shall not be made.



   (e)   Issuance: A certificate of occupancy shall be issued within
five (5) days after written application therefor, if the building or
structure at the time of such application shall be entitled thereto. Copies
of certificates of occupancy shall be furnished, on request, to persons
having a proprietary interest in the building or structure.



   (f)   Certificate Of Complete Installations: When a certificate is
specifically required by a provision of this code for an installation,
extension or alteration of equipment or appliances, it shall be unlawful to
use or permit the use of such equipment or appliances to which such provision
applies until the appropriate certificate has been issued.



   (g)   Deposit Of Bond: In order to secure compliance with this
section, there shall be deposited with the building commissioner, at the time
of filing of an application for building permit for construction or
improvements in excess of one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00), a
cash bond or equivalent in an amount equal to one percent (1%) of the
estimated cost of construction of the improvement up to and including fifty
thousand dollars ($50,000.00) and one-half of one percent (0.5%) over fifty
thousand dollars ($50,000.00). The full amount of the cash bond or equivalent
shall be forfeited to the village at the rate of ten percent (10%) of such
deposit per day for each day that this section has been violated in the
reasonable judgment of the building commissioner. Such forfeiture shall not
impair the village's right to enforce any and all other remedies available to
it by reason of such violation of this section, including the right to
recover a fine or penalty or seek injunctive relief. The deposit shall be
returned to depositor upon the issuance of a certificate of occupancy.



(Ord. 69-17, 8-7-1969; Code 1972, § 4-1-3; Ord. 81-7, 2-5-1981; Ord.
2003-04, § 1, 2-24-2003; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-34.  Classification Of Buildings:



   (a)   Establishment Of Classification: For the purpose of this
division, buildings shall be classified as follows:



      Class A buildings used as single-family dwellings;



      Class B buildings used as apartment houses;



      Class C buildings used as private garages;



      Class D buildings used for commercial or industrial purposes;



      Class E buildings used for the purpose of class D buildings and
in which are located one or more apartments;



      Class F buildings used as public garages or automobile filling
stations.



   (b)   Other Classifications: Buildings not included within any of
the above classes shall be fireproof construction unless such requirement is
modified by resolution of the board of trustees on recommendations of the
building commissioner.



   (c)   Change Of Classification Of Buildings: If buildings erected
for or converted to the uses of any classification mentioned in this section
are to be applied to the uses of any other class for which a better system of
construction is required by this division, the construction and equipment of
such buildings shall be first made to conform to the requirements of this
division as specified for their intended use. It shall be unlawful to use any
such building for a new or different purpose from that to which its structure
and equipment adopt it under this division, unless the provisions of this
division and the provisions of the zoning chapter1 for such new or different
use shall first have been complied with.



(Code 1972, § 4-1-4; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



1  See chapter 12 of this code.



Sec. 8-35.  Construction; Repair; Compliance With Division:



   (a)   Every building or structure or part thereof, hereafter
constructed, erected, altered, enlarged, maintained or repaired within the
village shall be so constructed, erected, altered, enlarged, maintained or
repaired in accordance with the provisions of this division, the zoning
chapter1, and other provisions of the laws of the village.



   (b)   The following building materials and repairs are prohibited in
the village of Justice:



      (1)    No exposed smooth cinder or concrete block on any
building.



   (2)   No boarded up windows or doors unless ordered by the building
commissioner to prevent further damage to abandoned or disaster struck
buildings; all boarded up windows and doors must be replaced with materials
equivalent to that which existed prior to the need for repair.



   (3)   No opaque windows may replace nonopaque windows.



   (4)   No oriental strand board (OSB) shall be allowed to be used as
roofing material.



(Code 1972, § 4-1-6; Ord. 77-52, 9-29-1977; Ord. 2001-14, § 1, 4-23-2001;
Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



1  See chapter 12 of this code.



Sec. 8-36.  Height, Area And Foundation Grades Of Buildings:



   (a)   Height And Area: The height and area of every building or
structure or part thereof, hereafter constructed, erected, altered, enlarged,
maintained or repaired within the village shall conform with the requirements
of the zoning chapter in respect to height and area.



   (b)   Foundation Grades: The height of the top of the foundation
wall shall be set at a maximum of eighteen inches (18") over the crown of the
street at the front of the property. Where there are existing buildings in
the block, foundation grades shall be set to equalize the height of all
buildings in the block where practicable, unless the existing buildings in
the block are set too low in relation to the existing or proposed curb
elevations where it then becomes necessary to place a new building foundation
grade higher than the existing buildings in the block. Provision shall then
be made to protect the lower elevation buildings from the water runoff of the
new buildings. Parts of the foundation which are placed at a higher elevation
for architectural effect shall not extend for more than forty percent (40%)
of the perimeter of the building.



   (c)   Basements: All basements shall be constructed in compliance
with subsection 8-31(e) of this division and all building codes adopted
thereunder.



No basement shall have more than thirty percent (30%) of its area separated
by dividers or walls from the total area of the basement. The enclosed or
separated areas may include a utility room, laundry room, a mechanical room
for a heating and air conditioning unit, electrical service, and water
heater, a storage room divided by the number of rental units in a
multi-family residence, one bathroom and at least one staircase. An open
stairway will be allowed outside the enclosed area in the open seventy
percent (70%) of the basement.



(Code 1972, § 4-1-7; Ord. 79-26, 10-4-1979; Ord. 96-22, § 1, 8-12-1996;
Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-37.  Alterations Of Existing Buildings:



   (a)   In construing the several sections of this division, such
sections shall not be construed as requiring alterations in the construction
or equipment of buildings or structures in existence at the time of the
passage of this division, unless specific provision is made to the contrary,
or unless the provision is expressly made retroactive, or unless such
building shall not have sufficient or adequate means of egress or ingress.



   (b)   It shall be the duty of every owner or occupant of a building
to keep it in safe and sanitary condition and to comply with the zoning
chapter.



(Code 1972, § 4-1-8; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-38.  Reserved:



Sec. 8-39.  Fire Limits:



   (a)   Districts Included: For the purpose of guarding against the
calamities of fire, commercial and manufacturing districts are hereby
declared to be within the fire limits, and the fire limits are hereby
established to include all of such area and, except as hereinafter provided,
no wooden buildings hereafter shall be erected, placed, added to or enlarged
within such fire limits; provided, that within areas where more than fifty
percent (50%) of the available lot area has been used for the erection of
wooden buildings, wooden buildings may be erected, placed, added to or
enlarged but only when and after permission so to do has been obtained from
the village board of trustees upon application made to it therefor and then
only upon such reasonable terms and conditions as the village board of
trustees may prescribe with due regard to the protection of life and property
from the calamities of fire.



   (b)   Ordinary Repairs Allowed: Nothing contained in this section
shall be construed to prevent the making of ordinary repairs for the purpose
of maintenance of any existing wooden building.



   (c)   Fire Resistance: The provisions of this section shall apply to
all multi-family structures containing three (3) or more living units and
structures containing any type of use such as business or industrial and also
one or more living units. The fire resistance rating of all structural
elements (including walls, floors, and roof) and tenant separation or party
walls shall be a minimum of two (2) hours and shall be constructed of
noncombustible materials. Exterior and load bearing wall construction shall
be of masonry. All floors shall be of precast concrete, poured concrete or
other type having a minimum of two (2) hour fire resistance rating1.



(Ord., 8-5-1965; Code 1972, § 4-1-10; Ord. 85-1, 2-7-1985; Ord. 2016-20, §
1, 5-23-2016)



1  See chapter 4 of this code.



Sec. 8-40.  Minimum Area Of Class A Buildings:



   Buildings of class A shall have the following minimum area: Residences
shall have at least one thousand (1,000) square feet of floor space. These
areas are exclusive of all porches, bays, furnace rooms, laundry rooms and
attached garages.



(Ord., 8-5-1965; Code 1972, § 4-1-11; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-41.  Class C Private Garages:



   (a)   Compliance With Provisions: Every structure erected for or
converted to the purpose of class C shall comply with the following special
provisions, in addition to the general provisions of this division.



   (b)   Permits: No work shall begin until a building permit has been
issued for the garage, according to section 8-32 of this code. No permit
shall be issued for garage unless a scaled drawing, drawn in professional
manner is presented. Plans shall show size, roof pitch, window and door
openings and front and side elevations. A plat plan will also be required
showing locations of the garage in relation to residence.



   (c)   Construction:



      (1)   Generally: No structure erected for or converted to the
purpose of class C detached garage shall exceed nine feet (9') in total wall
height from the single plate on the floor to the double plate on the top, and
not exceed fourteen feet (14') in total height of structure. No overall
dimension shall measure over thirty six feet (36') in length. The maximum
area of such structure shall be eight hundred sixty four (864) square feet,
as measured along outside walls.



      No second story, loft, or living quarters is permitted to be
constructed on a class C (detached) garage.



      Patios under a common roof shall not exceed the length of the
common wall and ten feet (10') in width. The common wall shall also extend to
the ridge closing the garage from the patio. All garages shall have a glass
area of three percent (3%) of floor area.



      No garage shall be built closer than ten feet (10') to the rear
of the lot nor closer than five feet (5') to the side of the lot line. No
private garage shall be erected on the front of the lot, unless attached to
the dwelling. The setback from the back of home shall be a minimum of twelve
feet (12').



      Walls may be eight inches (8") thick and foundations shall be at
least eight inches (8") wide and two feet (2') below grade.



      Flooring shall be a minimum of four inches (4") of concrete with
wire mesh and gravel base.



      Gas ledges will be required on any attached garage. Such curbs
shall be on walls adjacent to a structure and shall be a minimum of three
inches (3") in height.



      No wood floors shall be allowed in any private garages.



      (2)   Materials: It shall not be permissible to build garages
on wooden posts or piers of any form of material. It shall not be permissible
to build garages out of skids, forms or any boxes. Wooden shingles shall not
be permitted for a roof covering material.



(Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-42.  Hotels And Motels:



   (a)   Compliance With Provisions: All hotel and motel buildings
shall comply with the following special provisions, in addition to the
general provisions of this code.



   (b)   Definitions: The following terms shall have the meaning
ascribed them herein unless the context clearly evinces a different meaning:



   Hotel.  Any building of forty five (45) or more units on not less than
three floors, designed for the temporary occupancy of individuals who are
lodged for compensation, with or without meals; providing a private bathroom
for each guest unit which includes a toilet, sink, and shower/tub; whereby
access to all guest units is through a fully heated and air conditioned
hallway accessible by elevators between floors; which may provide meeting
rooms, common dining facilities, including banquet rooms; and all other uses
customarily and historically associated thereto, for the comfort,
accommodation and entertainment of patrons, including the service of
alcoholic beverages.



   Motel.  Any building or series of buildings that is not a hotel in
which temporary lodging is open to the general public for compensation. For
the purpose of this code, a motel is not a boarding house or multi-family
dwelling. A motel shall be no more than thirty five (35') feet above grade;
which provides primary access to some or all guest units through an
independent exterior door. Other terms include tourist homes or courts,
lodging houses, rooming houses, bed and breakfast inns, and motor lodges.



   Adult Motel.  A motel or similar commercial establishment which: a)
offers accommodations to the public for any form of consideration, provides
patrons with closed circuit television transmissions, films, motion pictures,
videocassettes, slides or other electronic or photographic reproductions
which are characterized by the depiction or description of specified sexual
activities or specified anatomical areas, and has a sign visible from the
public right of way which advertises the availability of such transmissions,
films, motion pictures, videocassettes, slides or other photographic
reproductions; and/or b) offers a sleeping room for rent for a period of time
that is less than twelve (12) hours; and/or c) allows a tenant or occupant of
a sleeping room to sub-rent the room for a period of time that is less than
twelve (12) hours. Rent and sub-rent when used in reference to an adult
motel, shall mean the act of permitting a sleeping room to be occupied for
any form of consideration.



   Dwelling Or Guest Unit.  Any room or unit of a hotel or motel used or
intended to be used as a unit for living, sleeping, cooking and eating,
containing sanitary facilities.



   Extended Stay Hotel Facility.  Any hotel with rooms specifically
designed for extended stays over thirty (30) days, improved with sleeping and
bathroom areas, a dedicated kitchen area with cooking appliances,
refrigerator, and sink.



   Sight Triangle.  The area of the corner lot closest to the street or
driveway intersection which must be kept free of visual impairment to allow
full view of both pedestrian and vehicular traffic. The area shall be marked
by a point at which the two (2) curb lines intersect, measuring back 15 feet
on each street front, and drawing a line across the two (2) back points to
form a triangulated area. No signs may be permitted within a sight triangle
except for public safety-related signs.



   (c)   Building Design:



      (1)   Bulk And Mass: All building and parking areas shall be
designed with treatments to reduce the appearance of improvement's bulk and
mass. Buildings shall include vertical architectural treatment to reduce the
appearance of the building's scale into smaller components. Any facade with a
plain wall shall be screened through landscaping, berming, and/or fencing.
Architectural details shall continue on all facades. The following design
elements should be incorporated to interrupt the monotony of the horizontal
plane of a building or wall:



         a.   Change in color, texture, or materials;



         b.   Projections, recesses, and reveals, structural
bays, entrances;



         c.   Grouping of windows or doors; and/or



         d.   Awnings.



      (2)   Materials And Color:



         a.   Minimum of fifty percent (50%) of all facade
(excluding windows and doors), shall be covered with brick, stone, textured
masonry block, or some other masonry product of similar quality to add
texture, color and visual interest to the walls, roofs and facades.



         b.   Ribbed metal siding is prohibited as a primary
exterior surface material. It may be used as trim covering no more than
fifteen percent (15%) of the facades.



         c.   Smooth faced gray concrete block and tilt-up
concrete panels are prohibited on all facades.



         d.   Facade colors should be earth tone with low
reflectance. High intensity, metallic, mirrored, or fluorescent colors are
prohibited.



      (3)    Mechanical Equipment: Roof mounted heating,
ventilation, and air conditioning equipment (excluding roof vents), duct
work, air compressors, and other fixed operating machinery shall be fully
screened from public view with architectural treatments that complement the
overall design of the structure.



   (d)   Parking And Loading Areas:



      (1)   Parking garages for hotels, having multiple floors,
either enclosed or partially enclosed, shall be built according to the most
recent codes adopted by the village.



      (2)   Computation: When a determination of the number of
off-street parking spaces required by this section results in a requirement
of a fractional space, any fraction of one-half (1/2) or less may be
disregarded while a fraction in excess of one-half (1/2) shall be counted as
one parking space.



      (3)   Size: Off-street parking space shall be at least ten
feet (10') in width and at least twenty feet (20') in length, exclusive of
access drives or aisles, ramps, columns, or office or work areas. Each
required off-street parking space shall have a vertical clearance of at least
seven feet (7'). Handicapped parking spaces shall be provided in accordance
with the most current edition of the American with Disability Act (ADA).



      (4)   Number: The number of required parking spaces for a
hotel shall be equal to one space per guest room and one space per every two
(2) employees; plus any spaces required for restaurant, lounge, banquet
areas, and meeting rooms as required under section 12-88 of this code.
Handicapped parking spaces shall be provided in accordance with the most
current edition of the Americans with Disability Act (ADA).



      (5)   Access:



         a.   Each required off-street parking space shall open
directly to an aisle or driveway of at least the widths identified below,
based upon the angle of the parking stalls provided, and whether the aisle
serves one or two (2) rows of parking spaces:



 


Parking Angle

 

1 Row

 

2 Rows




Parallel

 

12 Feet

 

12 Feet




30 Degrees

 

12 Feet

 

12 Feet




45 Degrees

 

13 Feet

 

14 Feet




60 Degrees

 

18 Feet

 

19 Feet




90 Degrees

 

20 Feet

 

24 Feet




 



         b.   All off-street parking facilities shall be designed
with appropriate means of vehicular access to a street in a manner which will
least interfere with traffic movements. No driveway across public property or
curb cut shall exceed a width of thirty (30) feet.



         c.   An off-street loading space of at least ten (10)
feet by thirty (30) feet shall be provided for each building and shall be
adjacent to a receiving space within the building.



      (6)   Construction/Surfacing/Draina ge:



         a.   All surface off-street parking areas and driveways
shall be improved with a compacted stone base, not less than six inches (6")
thick, surfaced with asphalt, concrete, brick or some comparable all-weather
dustless material.



         b.   In the event permeable parking surfaces are used,
they shall be of a six inch (6") porous asphalt or concrete course with a six
inch (6") inch perforated PVC SDR-26 under drain; twenty-four inches (24")
graded CA-5 stone reservoir; with non-woven geotextile fabric layer over an
un-compacted sub-grade.



         c.   Driveway aprons accessing streets shall be six inch
(6") thick concrete, with welded wire fabric placed on six inch (6W) minimum
well compacted gravel base. All driveway aprons shall have curb and gutters
made of cement, upon each side of the driveway and parking areas excepting at
entrance or exit thereto. Curb and gutters shall be subject to IDOT Bureau of
Local Roads requirements.



         d.   All surface off-street parking areas shall have
storm water drainage either through an underground sewer system tied into the
existing storm water systems of the village, or a detention pond as denoted
in section 11-11 of this code, pursuant to any Metropolitan Water Reclamation
District of Greater Chicago (MWRD) permit requirements.



         e.   All off-street parking areas shall be shall be
striped.



      (7)   Location Of Accessory Off-Street Parking Facilities: All
required parking spaces shall be within one thousand feet (1,000') of the
principal use in business and industrial districts.



   (e)   Landscaping And Screening:



      (1)   Parking Lot Street Yards: Where parking lots providing
for five (5) or more parking spaces are in view of the public right of way,
there shall be installed within a ten foot (10') wide street yard between the
parking area and the street, a minimum of, three (3) one and three quarter
inch (1-3/4") caliper canopy trees and one (1) one and three quarter inch
(-3/4") caliper understory trees per one hundred fifty (150) linear feet of
frontage. The substitution of one (1) understory tree for each required shade
tree that would conflict with overhead utilities will be permitted within
street yards. In conjunction with the planting standards described above, the
following screening techniques are encouraged:



         a.   Masonry walls compatible with proposed building
design, and landscaped as a foundation wall;



         b.   Screen fencing of wrought iron or approved
material. Chain link fencing is prohibited;



         c.   An earthen berm between the right of way and the
building, not to exceed a slope of two to one (2:1) (vertical: horizontal).



      (2)   Landscape Parking Islands: To break up large expanses of
parking and provide a minimum five percent (5%) landscape area, landscape
islands shall be required such that no parking space may be located more than
ninety (90) linear feet away from a landscape island containing a canopy
tree. Landscape islands must be a minimum of four feet (4') wide from back of
curb to back of curb, and a minimum of one hundred (100) square feet in area.



      (3)   Landscaping Between Buildings: There shall be sufficient
quantities of canopy, understory and evergreen trees, shrubs and ground
covers to screen unattractive views of the side and rear of adjacent
buildings.



      (4)   Foundation Planting:



         a.   At a minimum, a four foot (4') wide landscape area
shall be provided adjacent to all building walls (excluding driveways,
entrance areas, covered walkways, service and delivery areas).



         b.   The landscape area shall be planted with a balance
of understory and evergreen trees, shrubs and ground covers.



         c.   The plantings shall deemphasize large expanses of
building wall length and height, accent building entrances and architectural
features, and screen mechanical equipment adjacent to buildings.



   (f)   Outdoor Lighting:



      (1)   All areas intended for pedestrian use shall be well
lighted by fixtures that focus on lighting walkways and sitting areas.



      (2)   Decorative lighting fixtures that supplement general
lighting are strongly encouraged in all developments.



      (3)   To minimize hazardous glare, all fixtures visible from
the public right of way (with the exception of general street lighting) with
output greater than fourteen thousand (14,000) initial lumens, shall be
designed without lenses or globes protruding below the shell of the fixture,
and shall generally be parallel with the ground.



   (g)   Signs:



      (1)   The colors and materials of signs shall be similar to
and compatible with the architectural style, colors and materials of the
related building. Every sign shall be designed as an integral architectural
element of the building and site to which it relates.



      (2)   The number of graphic elements on a sign shall be held
to the minimum needed to convey the sign's message and shall be composed in
proportion to the area of the sign face.



      (3)   Signs should be oriented to vehicular traffic as well as
pedestrians, and scaled appropriately.



      (4)   Sign height is limited to the height of the building or
45' whichever is less.



      (5)   Line Of Sight: The lowest point on any sign face of a
free-standing sign may not be less than forty eight inches (48") from ground
level to provide a clear line of sight for vehicles entering or exiting a
driveway. Ground signs require a minimum set back from the right-of-way
property line of not less than five feet (5'). Signs shall not be permitted
in parkways. No signs shall be permitted within a sight triangle except for
safety-related signs.



   (h)   Minimum Lot Size: No hotel shall be constructed on a lot less
than two (2) acres in size without a special use permit in accordance with
the terms and provisions of this title. Hotels may be constructed on lots
less than two (2) acres if they are part of a larger master planned project,
provided the sum of all contiguous lots within the master planned project is
greater than ten (10) acres.



   (i)   Density: Maximum density requirements for hotels are
calculated on a sliding floor area ratio (FAR) system which is dependent on
the size of the site. FARs for master planned projects are calculated based
on the sum of all contiguous lots within the project.



      The following FARs shall apply:



         0.25 for sites less than ten (10) acres;



         0.40 for sites between ten to (10-15) acres; and



         0.70 for sites greater than fifteen (15) acres.



   (j)   Height: No hotel shall be less than three (3) stories above
grade. No hotel hereafter erected or structurally altered shall exceed
federal aviation administration (FAA) regulations.



   (k)   Refuse, Rubbish And Garbage: All hotels and motels shall
provide a refuse room within the principal building or an enclosed refuse
stall outside the building. Exterior refuse stalls shall be constructed of
the same principal material as the building and shall be located in an area
approved by the building commissioner.



   (l)   Minimum Room Size: No guestroom, including the bathroom, shall
be less than three hundred (300) square feet of heated/air conditioned space.



   (m)   Amenities: All hotels shall be required to provide guests with
the following facilities/improvements:



      (1)   On site food service including either a restaurant,
café, and/or in house or contracted room service;



      (2)   Elevator service to all floors;



      (3)   Twenty four (24) hour on site private security; security
cameras with recording capabilities in all common areas and exterior of the
building.



      (4)   Handicapped accessible facilities as required per the
provisions of this code.



   (n)   Prohibited Acts And Conditions:



      (1)   No hotel or motel shall provide rates for any period
less than one full night's stay.



      (2)   Adult motels as defined in this code are prohibited.



      (3)   It shall be unlawful to permit any violation of any
ordinance or law on the premises or in any motel or hotel.



      (4)   Parking of vehicles, including but not limited to
trucks, buses, road equipment, or other vehicles in parking lots of hotels
and motels, where vehicle owners/operators are not patrons of the hotel or
motel, is prohibited.



(Ord. 2013-04, § 2, 3-25-2013; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-43.  Reserved:



Sec. 8-44.  Salary Of Building Commissioner:



   See chapter 2, section 2-34 of this code for provisions concerning the
salary of the building commissioner. 



(Code 1972, § 4-1-15; Ord. 79-33, 12-6-1979; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-45.  Work Permit:



   (a)   No person shall build any new building nor shall remodel any
old building without first securing a work permit as herein provided for; nor
shall any such person desirous of soliciting work for the pursuit of business
as a building tradesman or building contractor, where work is to be performed
outside of the home, within the corporate limits of the village do so without
securing such work permit.



   (b)   Application for a work permit shall be made with the building
commissioner who shall issue such work permit upon receipt of the appropriate
insurance documentation, proper licenses, and a payment as set forth in
section 13-1 of this code, which shall not be refundable.



   (c)   Any person securing such a work permit shall keep such permit
on his person or in their vehicle before any work is started.



   (d)   All work permits issued by the village shall expire one year
from date of issue.



(Ord. 71-23, 11-4-1971; Code 1972, § 4-1-16; Ord. 91-29, § 2, 9-9-1991;
Ord. 92-15, § 1, 3-23-1992; Ord. 92-48, § 1, 12-28-1992; Ord. 98-6, § 2,
2-9-1998; Ord. 98-12, § 2, 3-23-1998; Ord. 2009-15, § 34, 6-22-2009; Ord.
2009-28, § 2, 11-23-2009; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2014)

for construction of a public facility, as defined in section 3 of the
Environmental Barriers Act, must meet the requirements of that Act.



(Code 1972, § 4-1-18; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-48.  Accessibility Standards Act:



   In accordance with the procedures required by state law, the
Accessibility Standards Act2 published by the Capital Development Board3 of
this state is hereby adopted into this code, copies of such act having been
on file with the village for more than fifteen (15) days prior to the passage
and approval of this section.



(Code 1972, § 4-1-19; Ord. 80-2, 1-3-1980; Ord. 2009-15, § 34, 6-22-2009;
Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



2  20 ILCS 3105/1 (art. I).

Sec. 8-49.  Telecommunication And Fiber Optic Installations:



   (a)   Permit Required: It shall be unlawful to construct or erect
any portion of a telecommunication or fiber optic system prior to obtaining a
permit from the village. An application shall be filed with the office of the
building commissioner upon such forms as he shall deem necessary. The
application shall be accompanied by a complete set of plans showing the
location of all work to be performed, a copy of the contract reflecting the
total cost of the project and the linear feet covered; and the certification
of a licensed electrical contractor that the plans and specifications comply
with the applicable village electrical ordinances.



   (b)   Contractors: Any and all persons constructing or erecting a
telecommunication or fiber optic  system shall obtain a license as a general
contractor under section 8-45 of this code.



   (c)   Occupation Of Streets: No street shall be blocked or occupied
by any person constructing or erecting any portion of a telecommunication or
fiber optic system without obtaining a street occupation permit. For the
purposes of telecommunication or fiber optics, the locations to be blocked or
occupied shall be given to the building commissioner and the public works
director at least two (2) business days prior to their blockage or
occupation. Adequate warning devices, including barricades, shall be supplied
to direct traffic to other areas by the contractor.



   (d)   Permit Fee: The permit fee for the construction and erection
of a telecommunication or fiber optic system shall be one percent (1%) of the
total cost of the project attributable to the village of Justice.



   (e)   Restoration: All disturbed areas within the village due to a
telecommunications or fiber optic installation shall be restored back to its
original condition within ninety (90) days of the completion of the project.
Failure to restore any disturbed area shall be subject to a fine not to
exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for any one offense. A separate
and distinct offense shall be held to have been committed each day any person
or entity continues to violate any of the provisions hereof. 



(Code 1972, § 4-1-20; Ord. 81-5, 2-5-1981; Ord. 81-9, 3-19-1981; Ord. 98-6,
§ 2, 2-9-1998; Ord. 98-12, § 2, 3-23-1998; Ord. 2001-05, § 2, 2-26-2001;
Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-50.  Inspection Fees:



   (a)   Scope: This section hereby establishes the fees for inspection
by all building department administrators, as described in chapter 2, article
XI of this code, and the health officer, as described in section 5-113 of
this code, and their duly authorized agents.



   (b)   Fee Schedule: The fees to be charged for inspections by each
building department administrator, fire inspector, and health officer or his
duly authorized agent for new construction, major renovation, and all other
inspections shall be set forth in section 13-1 of this code for each
inspection. For the purpose of this section, major renovation shall include
at least one of the following, but shall not be limited to, the following: 1)
addition of a footed foundation; 2) an increase of thirty three percent (33%)
in living space; 3) the removal or installation of an external wall; 4) the
removal of any supporting wall, column, poles, truss, girder or beam; and 5)
the installation, closing or changing of stairs or existing ingress/egress
exit(s).



   (c)   Reinspection: The fees to be charged for reinspections by each
building department administrator,  fire inspector, and health officer or
their duly authorized agent for new construction, major renovation, and all
other inspections shall be set forth in section 13-1 of this code for each
reinspection.



(Code 1972, § 4-1-21; Ord. 85-8, 6-24-1985; Ord. 91-29, § 3, 9-9-1991; Ord.
98-6, § 2, 2-9-1998; Ord. 98-12, § 2, 3-23-1998; Ord. 2000-28, 6-12-2000;
Ord. 2006-02, § 2, 1-9-2006; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-51.  Chimneys For Wood Burning Appliances, Fireplaces And Stoves:



   The provisions of this section shall apply to all single-family
structures. Chimneys for wood burning appliances in all residences shall be:
a) capable of withstanding two thousand one hundred degrees Fahrenheit
(2,100°F) for thirty (30) minutes without any structural failure or any
temperature rise above the maximum temperature rises for materials as per UL
103; or b) built of noncombustible masonry construction with a vitrified clay
flue liner.



(Code 1972, § 4-1-22; Ord. 83-29, 8-18-1983; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-52.  General Building Provisions:



   No permits shall be issued unless the following criteria are met to the
satisfaction of the building commissioner:



      (1)    Buildings shall have good scale and be in harmonious
conformance with permanent neighboring development.



      (2)    Materials shall have good architectural character and
shall be selected for harmony of the building with adjoining buildings.



      (3)    Monotony of design in single or multiple building
projects shall be avoided. Variation of detail, form and siting shall be used
to provide visual interest.



(Code 1972, § 4-1-23; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-53.  Suitable Architectural Design:



   (a)   No permit shall be issued for any new building, or for any
addition to an existing building, if the architectural design of the new
building or addition is such that the same is obviously inferior or radically
different so as to impair the marketability or property values of existing
buildings in the same immediate vicinity.



   (b)   All new buildings shall be of an architectural design so as to
prevent the deterioration of values in residential neighborhoods.



(Code 1972, § 4-1-24; Ord. 84-10, 4-19-1984; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5- 23-2016)



Sec. 8-54.  Certificate Of Housing Inspection:



   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person who is the new lessee or
purchaser of a residential housing unit to occupy the same until a
certificate of housing inspection without any deficiencies has been issued
for the subject unit, within the prior three (3) months.



   (b)   The certificate of housing inspection shall be provided by the
owner of the housing unit. At the time of inspection, the owner must provide
the building commissioner a copy of all paid bills showing no arrearages,
including sewer, water and garbage bills. No certificate shall be issued
until all such bills have been paid.



   (c)   For the purpose of this section, the following words shall
have the meanings set forth below:



      Lease: The transfer of occupancy rights of real property for
consideration even if no written agreement is entered into.



      Owner: The titleholder of the real property, including, but not
limited to, the beneficiaries of a land trust, all partners in a partnership,
the officers of a corporation or any agent thereof, and the owner of shares
in a cooperative association.



      Sale: The transfer for consideration of the title to real estate
and includes the purchase of a condominium unit or the share in a cooperative
apartment association or a corporation.



   (d)   All applications for a certificate of housing inspection shall
be made on such forms as prescribed by the building commissioner. The
building commissioner shall issue a report within fourteen (14) days after
gaining access to the subject property, whether by consent or by warrant, and
after the payment of the following inspections fees:



      (1)    For a single-family dwelling as set forth in section
13-1 of this code.



      (2)    For cooperative apartment or condominium as set forth
in section 13-1 of this code per apartment unit.



      (3)    For buildings containing more than one dwelling unit as
set forth in section 13-1 of this code per apartment unit.



   (e)   The building commissioner may order additional inspections,
including, but not limited to, plumbing, electrical, health and fire
protection. Each such inspection will be made after payment of a fee as set
forth in section 13-1 of this code, for each inspection. All deficiencies
shall be noted on the report.



   (f)   All deficiencies shall be corrected prior to occupancy.



   (g)   Upon all inspections being passed, the building commissioner
shall issue a certificate of inspection.



   (h)   No evidence obtained in a consented inspection of real
property pursuant to this section shall be used in the prosecution of any
criminal or ordinance violation against the owner of the property when
inspection was made.



   (i)   Where no consent has been given to enter or inspect any
property, no entry or inspection shall be made without procurement of a
warrant from the circuit court of the county. The court may consider any of
the following factors along with such other matters as it deems pertinent in
its decision as to whether a warrant shall issue:



      (1)    Eyewitness account of violation;



      (2)    Citizen complaints;



      (3)    Tenant complaints;



      (4)    Plain view violations;



      (5)    Violations apparent from village records;



      (6)    Property deterioration;



      (7)    Age of property;



      (8)    Nature of alleged violation;



      (9)    Similar properties in the area;



      (10)    Documented violations of similar properties in the
area;



      (11)    Passage of time since last inspection;



      (12)    Previous violations on the property.



Cause for issuance of a warrant shall be deemed to exist in light of
reasonable legislative and administrative standards which show that there is
reason to believe that a condition of nonconformity exists with respect to a
particular property in violation of a village ordinance.



   (j)   If the lessee or purchaser occupies the property without the
certificate of inspection, the village does not guarantee the condition of
the subject property and is not responsible for any claims arising out of the
subject property or the condition thereof. The village does not warrant that
all deficiencies are listed in a certificate and does not warrant anything as
to the condition of the property or the habitability thereof.



(Ord. 86-27, § 1, 8-11-1986; Ord. 93-45, § 1, 12-13-1993; Ord. 98-6, § 2,
2-9-1998; Ord. 98-12, § 2, 3-23-1998; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-55.  MSD Permit Review Fee:



   (a)   If an MSD sewer permit is required by the metropolitan
sanitary district according to the latest edition of the “Manual of
Procedures for the Administration of Sewer Ordinance”, the developer shall
submit such permit along with the plans and specifications for the proposed
sewer hookup, and all supporting documentation, to the village. A fee as set
forth in section 13-1 of this code shall accompany all such documents. The
fee is the minimum fee to be charged for review of such plans by the village
engineer.



   (b)   If the engineer’s fee for such review exceeds the fee as set
forth in section 13-1 of this code, the village shall bill the developer for
such charges.



   (c)   All fees must be paid prior to the issuance of an occupancy
permit.



(Ord. 88-3, § 1, 2-22-1988; Ord. 98-6, § 2, 2-9-1998; Ord. 98-12, § 2,
3-23-1998; Ord. 2009-15, § 34, 6-22-2009; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-56.  Sprinkler Systems:



   There shall be a sprinkler system permit fee as provided in section
8-69 of this chapter.



(Ord. 90-13, § 1, 8-13-1990; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-57.  Plan Review, Inspection And Reinspection Fees For Elevators,
Escalators, And Other Lift Devices:



   (a)   All new installations of elevators, escalators, dumbwaiters,
dock lifts, freight lifts, wheelchair lifts and other similar elevation lift
escalation devices and their components shall pay a plan review fee and an
inspection fee as set forth in section 13-1 of this code.



   (b)   Each such installation shall be inspected semiannually by the
building commissioner or his authorized representative and semiannually pay a
reinspection fee as set forth in section 13-1 of this code.



(Ord. 90-13, § 1, 8-13-1990; Ord. 91-29, § 4, 9-9-1991; Ord. 98-6, § 2,
2-9-1998; Ord. 98-12, § 2, 3-23-1998; Ord. 2002-07, § 1, 3-25-2002; Ord.
2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-58.  Definitions:



   Storage Shed: A permanent manmade structure having four (4) enclosing
walls and a roof and which is not a part of any building or structure and is
more than two feet (2') in height over existing grade. Portable pavilions or
other temporary structures shall not be used for storage of any kind in any
zoning district in the village, may not be bolted down in any manner, and may
only be maintained in the village on a temporary basis, not to exceed
fourteen (14) days in duration without special approval by the building
commissioner.



(Ord. 91-29, § 15, 9-9-1991; Ord. 2001-19, § 1, 5-14-2001; Ord. 2016-20, §
1, 5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-59.  Permit; Inspection; Regulations:



   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person to construct any storage
shed within the village without a construction permit from the building
commissioner.



   (b)   The application for a storage shed construction permit shall
be accompanied by a plat of survey showing the proposed location of the
storage shed in relation to the lot lines, existing permanent improvements,
the type of construction, the material to be used and the proposed dimensions
of the storage shed. These must be approved by the building commissioner.



   (c)   There shall be a building permit charge as set forth in
section 13-1 of this code, for a storage shed construction permit.



   (d)   All such new installation shall also pay an inspection fee as
set forth in section 13-1 of this code.



   (e)   The space used for a storage shed cannot decrease the number
of required parking spaces in commercial or multi-family zoning districts.



   (f)   Shed must be anchored as recommended and approved by the
building commissioner.



(Ord. 91-29, § 15, 9-9-1991; Ord. 94-18, § 1, 10-10-1994; Ord. 98-6, § 2,
2-9-1998; Ord. 98-12, § 2, 3-23-1998; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-60  Vision Clearance:



   On corner lots, no storage shed shall obstruct any motor vehicle
driver’s view of any intersecting street as such vehicle is approaching the
intersection, so as to prevent the driver’s ability to halt his vehicle
with safety.



(Ord. 91-29, § 15, 9-9-1991; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-61  Materials:



   Any new normal storage shed material may be used for a storage shed.
However, all material shall be first approved by the building commissioner
when the permit is applied for.



(Ord. 91-29, § 15, 9-9-1991; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-62  Storage Shed Size And Number Requirements:



   (a)   No storage shed shall exceed twelve feet (12') in width by
twelve feet (12') in depth; nor shall it exceed eight feet (8') in total wall
height from the floor to the top of the wall, and not exceed ten feet (10')
in total height of structure, at the discretion of the building commissioner.



   (b)   Only one storage shed per residential lot is permitted.



(Ord. 91-29, § 15, 9-9-1991; Ord. 92-24, § 1, 6-22-1992; Ord. 2001-19, §
2, 5-14-2001; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-63  Location:



   No storage shed shall be constructed in violation of building setback
requirements of this division.



(Ord. 91-29, § 15, 9-9-1991; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-64  Requirements For Roof Construction:



   (a)   Contractors: All roofing shall be performed by a certified
roofing contractor, with a valid state license, or the homeowner who performs
the work themselves. The roofing contractor shall apply at the village
building department for a work permit as per section 8-45 of this code.



   (b)   Construction: Roofing construction shall meet the standards
set forth in section 8-31(e) of this code. No more than two (2) layers of
roofing material are allowed. If more than twenty five percent (25%) of the
roof sheeting area must be replaced, five-eighths inch (5/8") plywood
sheeting must be installed on the entire roof area.



   (c)   Inspection: For any roofing construction project requiring
only reshingling (second layer), one inspection is required at completion of
the project. For any roofing construction project requiring the tear-off of
roofing material or the replacement of roof sheeting, two (2) inspections are
required, one after the tear-off of the old roofing material or installation
of the new sheeting and the ice and water shield is installed and one at
completion of the project.



(Ord. 92-25, § 1, 6-22-1992; Ord. 98-26, § 1, 6-22-1998; Ord. 2016-20, §
1, 5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-65  Architect Required; Certain Additions:



   A licensed architect must be employed by any property owner adding more
than fifty percent (50%) of square footage to the original square footage of
any structure, or for any second story addition. A licensed engineer or
architect must certify that the load bearing capacity of the existing
foundation is sufficient to bear the load of the new second story addition.
All building permits for such addition(s) must be issued in the
contractor’s name, if a contractor is employed.



(Ord. 92-42, § 1, 11-23-1992; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)

Sec. 8-67  Permit; Required:



   No person shall install or alter any plumbing within the village unless
he is a licensed plumber and until a permit has been secured for such
installation or alteration from the plumbing inspector or his authorized
designee. The plumbing contractor shall apply to the village building
department for a work permit pursuant to section 8-45 of this code.
Homeowners are only allowed to install fixtures or trim not including moving
or replacement of pipes, or other work as indicated in the plumbing code.



(Code 1972, § 4-2-1; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-68  Permit; Application:



   Application for plumbing permits shall be made upon printed forms to be
furnished by the building commissioner. Each application shall set out the
name of the owner of the premises where the proposed work is to be done, the
location thereof, by street and number, and a detailed description of the
proposed plumbing installation or alteration sufficient to show that the
proposed work is in conformity with this code.



(Ord., 8-5-1965; Code 1972, § 4-2-2; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-69  Permit; Fees:



   The plumbing inspector or his authorized designee shall issue a
plumbing permit upon such application in all cases where the proposed
installation or alteration as described in such application is found in
conformity with this code. The minimum plumbing permit shall be as set forth
in section 13-1 of this code. The following plumbing permit fees shall be
paid to the village before any plumbing work is started:



   New work, shall be as set forth in section 13-1 of this code per
fixture.



   Remodeling or alteration, shall be as set forth in section 13-1 of this
code per fixture.



(Code 1972, § 4-2-3; Ord. 79-12, 7-19-1979; Ord. 91-29, § 5, 9-9-1991; Ord.
98-6, § 2, 2-9-1998; Ord. 98-12, § 2, 3-23-1998; Ord. 2016-20, § 1,
5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-70  Inspections And Tests:



   (a)   All work done by licensed plumbers or homeowners within any
building or structure or part thereof shall be subject to inspection,
supervision and approval of the plumbing inspector or his authorized
designee, and all faulty and defective work which may at any time be
discovered shall be made satisfactory to the plumbing inspector or his
authorized designee and no further permit shall be issued to the party in
default until this section shall have been fully complied with.



   (b)   All work done by licensed plumbers or homeowners shall be
subject to such further inspections and tests as shall be required by the
rules and regulations of the plumbing inspector or his authorized designee.



(Code 1972, § 4-2-4; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



Sec. 8-71  Street Openings:



   No person shall injure or disturb any street pavement, side or
crosswalk, or any part thereof without first having complied with the
applicable provisions of this code.



(Code 1972, § 4-2-5; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 5-23-2016)



   Cross reference–Streets, sidewalks, driveways and parking lots, Ch.
10.

of the village and the building, shall be made in accordance with the rules
and regulations of the building department of the village, or the rules and
