ARTICLE I.  IN GENERAL



Sec. 11-1.  Deposit Of Objectionable Waste:



   It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be
deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the
village or in any area under the jurisdiction of the village, any human or
animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-13)



Sec. 11-2.  Right Of Entry For Inspection:



   The plumbing inspector, public works director, and other duly
authorized employees of the village, the Illinois environmental protection
agency and the United States environmental protection agency, bearing proper
credentials and identification, shall be permitted to enter all properties
for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and
testing in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. The plumbing
inspector or public works director or his representative shall have no
authority to inquire into any processes, including metallurgical, chemical,
oil refining, ceramic, paper or other industries beyond that point having a
direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the sewers or waterway
or facilities for waste treatment.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-42; Ord. 2001-05, § 2, 2-26-2001)



Sec. 11-3.  Conduct Of Inspections, Testing; Liability:



   While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to
in section 11-2 of this article, the plumbing inspector or public works
director or duly authorized employees of the village, the Illinois
environmental protection agency and the United States environmental
protection agency shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises
established by the company and the company shall be held harmless for injury
or death to village employees and the village shall indemnify the company
against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage
asserted against the company and growing out of the gauging and sampling
operating, except as such may be caused by negligence or failure of the
company to maintain conditions as required in section 11-86 of this chapter.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-43; Ord. 2001-05, § 2, 2-26-2001)



Sec. 11-4.  Village Easements:



   The plumbing inspector and public works director or other duly
authorized employees of the village bearing proper credentials and
identification shall be permitted to enter all private properties through
which the village holds a duly negotiated easement for the purposes of, but
not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair and
maintenance of any portion of the sewage works lying within such easement.
All entry and subsequent work, if any, on such easement, shall be done in
full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement pertaining to
the private property involved.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-44; Ord. 2001-05, § 2, 2-26-2001)



Sec. 11-5.  Violations; Notice To Correct:



   Any person found to be violating any provisions of this chapter except
section 11-35 of this chapter, shall be served by the village with written
notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time
limit for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within a
period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations. The
village may revoke any permit for sewage disposal as a result of any
violation of any provision of this chapter.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-45)



Sec. 11-6.  Penalties:



   Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time limit
provided for in the notice of violation provided for in the preceding section
shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and on conviction thereof shall be fined a
minimum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not to exceed seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00), for each violation. Each day in which any such
violation shall continue shall be deemed a separate offense.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-46; Ord. 98-6, § 2, 2-9-1998; Ord. 98-12, § 2, 3-23-1998)



Sec. 11-7.  Owner, Occupant Liability:



   The services of the water and sewer system are furnished to the
respective premises by the village only upon the condition that the owner of
the premises, the occupant thereof and the user of the service are jointly
and severally liable therefor to the village.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-47)



Sec. 11-8.  Billing For Services:



   It shall be the duty of the village president’s duly authorized
designee to cause statements for charges to be delivered to each customer of
the water and sewer system at such intervals as will be determined by the
president and board of trustees but in no event at any greater interval than
three (3) months.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-48; Ord. 2009-15, § 49, 6-22-2009)



Sec. 11-9.  Payments In Arrears:



   No person owing waterworks and sewerage charges and removing to other
premises where there are such connections or where connections shall
afterwards be made shall be served until such charges in arrears are paid in
full.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-49)



Sec. 11-10.  Lowlands:



   (a)   All low, swampy, boggy or undrained lands within the village
limits are hereby declared to be unsanitary and unfit for residential
purposes, and the erection of residential buildings thereon is hereby
prohibited, except as hereinafter provided.



   (b)   No residential building shall be erected or permit issued for
the erection thereof by the village upon any land within the village limits
which the health officer shall reasonably find to be of the character
described in subsection (a) of this section, and so certify by a written
certificate filed with the village, unless upon application by the owner of
such land to the board of trustees which shall, by resolution, determine that
the finding of the health officer is incorrect, or unless or until an
ordinance providing adequate drainage for the proposed building site by
special assessment has been duly enacted by the board of trustees and
confirmed by the judgment of a court of competent jurisdiction or a plan for
the private drainage of the proposed building site has been filed with the
building commissioner, and certified by him and the health officer to be
adequate, and the carrying out and maintenance of such plan by the person or
persons holding legal title to the proposed building site, his personal
representative or assigns, assured by the execution by such owner of a
contract to that effect with the village, with reasonable guarantee and
securities for the performance thereof.



(Code 1972, §§ 8-8-56, 8-8-58; Ord. 2009-15, § 49, 6-22-2009)



Sec. 11-11.  Storm Water Detention:



   In order to provide detention storage to eliminate the excessive water
runoff during heavy storm periods the following requirements shall apply:



      (1)    A combination of storage and controlled release of
storm water runoff is required for all commercial, industrial and residential
developments exceeding ten thousand (10,000) square feet in area. Every
development must have an adequate outlet as signified on the metropolitan
sanitary district permit application by the village engineer, and will be
required to store that portion of the runoff exceeding the outlet capacity.



      (2)    The release rate of storm water from all developments
requiring detention shall not exceed the storm water runoff rate from the
area in its natural undeveloped state.



      (3)    Drainage systems shall have adequate capacity to bypass
through the development the flow from all upstream areas for a storm of
design frequency assuming that the land is in a fully developed state under
present zoning or zoning proposed under a comprehensive plan. The bypass flow
rate shall be computed utilizing a runoff coefficient of not less than thirty
five hundredths. An allowance will be made for upstream detention when such
upstream detention and release rate has previously been approved by the
metropolitan sanitary district of greater Chicago and that evidence of its
construction can be shown.



      (4)    The live detention storage to be provided will be
calculated on the basis of the 100-year frequency rainfall as published by
the United States weather bureau for this area. The detention volume required
will be that necessary to handle the runoff of a 100-year rainfall, for any
and all durations, from the fully developed drainage tributary to the
reservoir, less that volume discharged during the same duration at the
approved release rate.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-59; Ord. 84-24, 8-16-1984)



Sec. 11-11.1.  Privately Built Utility Lines:



   All privately installed utility lines shall be installed and fully
tested by the village for final approval to transfer said utility line to the
village of Justice. The contractor and/or developer owning the utility lines
shall guarantee the materials and labor in the installation of the utility
line to be transferred to the village of Justice for a period of one year
upon the date of initial occupancy of the building by posting a surety
subdivision bond or other financial guarantee in the amount equal to ten
percent (10%) of the cost of the construction of said utility lines. A bill
of sale in a form that meets the approval of the village of Justice building
commissioner shall be issued the village of Justice by the
contractor/developer owning the system prior to final occupancy or the
release of any occupancy permit funds if final occupancy has already occurred.



(Ord. 2004-17, § 2, 8-9-2004)



ARTICLE II.  WATER



Sec. 11-12.  Charges By Water Department:



   All water supplied by the village water department shall be charged at
the following rates:



      (1)    Water Rates; Residential: The customer shall be billed
every two (2) months as follows:



         a.    The first eight thousand (8,000) gallons at a
minimum rate of twenty four dollars twenty four cents ($24.24).



         b.    All water over eight thousand (8,000) gallons at
three dollars thirteen cents ($3.13) per one thousand (1,000) gallons.



      (2)    Water Rates; Commercial: Commercial rates shall apply
to all users other than single-family residential or municipal. The customer
shall be billed every two (2) months as follows:



         a.    The first eight thousand (8,000) gallons at a
minimum rate of twenty four dollars twenty eight cents ($24.28).



         b.    All water over eight thousand (8,000) gallons at
three dollars twenty four cents ($3.24) per one thousand (1,000) gallons.



         c.    Minimum rates of twenty four dollars twenty eight
cents ($24.28) per unit to be charged to commercial accounts that do not
provide a meter reading.



      (3)    Minimum Charge Described: Any person taking water
service by meter from the village shall pay a minimum charge equal to the
charge for eight thousand (8,000) gallons for each period of two (2) months.



      (4)    Charge For No Reading: There will be a charge of three
dollars ($3.00) bimonthly if a meter reading is not obtained by the village.



      (5)    Mandatory Meter Reading: It shall be mandatory that
before June 15 of each and every fiscal year a meter reading shall be
obtained by the village water department for any user that has had no meter
reading during the fiscal year ending June 30.



      (6)    Water Bills; When Due And Payable; Penalty: All water
bills to consumers within the village water department taking water service
by meter from the village shall be due and payable within fifteen (15) days
after receipt of bill for the previous two (2) month period. A penalty of ten
percent (10%) shall be charged to all consumers who pay after the fifteenth
day of the billing month. If a bill remains unpaid more than thirty (30) days
after issuance, the water shall be turned off without further notice, and
shall not be turned on again until the arrears are paid to the village.



      (7)    Shutoff And Reconnection Charges For Nonpayment: Where
water service has been cut off for failure to pay water bills as provided in
subsection (6) of this section, there shall be a charge of five dollars
($5.00) for the shutoff service, which charge shall be added to the unpaid
balance then due. A charge of five dollars ($5.00) will be paid for restoring
of water service after all bills have been paid, such charge to be paid to
the village prior to the restoration of water service.



      (8)    Liability For Payment: The owner of the premises, the
occupant thereof and the user of the service shall be jointly and severally
liable to pay for the service on such premises, and the service furnished to
the premises by the village only upon the condition that the owner of the
premises, occupant and user of the service are jointly and severally liable
therefor to the village.



      (9)    Water Permits: All construction shall require a permit
before using water supplied by the village water department, as follows:



         a.    Water supplied in connection with construction
work may be furnished without a meter, the rate to be twenty five dollars
($25.00) per month payable in advance. Water permit to be issued by the
village at no charge for the permit.



         b.   A water permit is to be obtained before connecting
to the village water department main. The fee for a single-family residence
shall be two hundred thirty one dollars ($231.00) which includes a twenty
five dollar ($25.00) security deposit which is refundable after two (2) years
of constructive payments, and a ten dollar ($10.00) inspection fee. Multiple
and business buildings will be charged by the Justice-Willow Springs water
commission. The village is to issue water permit prior to tap in.



         c.    All taps done on the village water mains are to be
done by a licensed plumber and inspected by the village.



         d.    All procedures for installation of water lines,
mains, meters and tap-ins are to follow the revised rules and regulations of
the Justice-Willow Springs water commission, the county building ordinance
and this code.



      (10)    Tampering With System: It shall be unlawful for any
person to interfere in any manner with any water main, service pipe, water
pipe, fire hydrant, or any other fixture connected with the water department,
or comprising a part of such system. Such interference includes, but is not
limited to, cutting, damaging, tampering with, destroying, or defacing any
fire hydrant or other fixture. It shall be unlawful for any person to
intentionally open any fire hydrant without proper authorization. Any person
who violates any of the provisions of this subsection shall be fined not less
than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00).



(Code 1972, § 8-8-60; Ord. 81-15, 6-4-1981; Ord. 85-12, 7-22-1985; Ord.
88-23, 9-12-1988; Ord. 89-10, 6-12-1989; Ord. 91-20, 7-22-1991; Ord. 92-8,
3-2-1992; Ord. 96-4, 2-12-1996; Ord. 2000-08, 2-14-2000; Ord. 2001-01,
1-8-2001; Ord. 2009-14, § 6, 6-22-2009)



Sec. 11-13.  Water Usage Ordinance Of Justice-Willow Springs Water
Commission:



   The Justice-Willow Springs water commission is hereby granted the
right, permission and authority to construct, operate and maintain in and
through the village of Justice for a new term of fifty (50) years, beginning
with the effective date hereof and continuing until the year 2055, a system
for the supply, storage, distribution and sale of water under the same terms
and conditions specified in the ordinance which was passed on June 3, 1963.



(Ord. 89-15, §§ 1-3, 7-24-1989; Ord. 2005-25, § 2, 11-28-2005)



Sec. 11-14.  Potable Water:



   (a)   Definitions:



      Person: Any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm,
company, limited liability company, corporation, association, joint stock
company, trust, estate, political subdivision, or any other legal entity, or
their legal representatives, agents or assigns.



      Potable Water: Any water used for human or domestic consumption,
including, but not limited to, water used for drinking, bathing, swimming,
washing dishes, or preparing foods.



   (b)   Prohibition: The use of ground water as a potable water supply
is prohibited, except for such uses or methods in existence before the
effective date hereof. The use of, or attempted use of, ground water from
within the corporate limits of the village of Justice, as a potable water
supply, by the installation or drilling of wells or by any other method, is
hereby prohibited. This prohibition expressly includes the village of Justice.



   (c)   Effective Date: The president of the board of trustees of the
village of Justice has hereby authorized this express prohibition in
subsection (b) of this section nunc pro tunc to March 8, 2004, the date of
the original MOU which has been lost.



   (d)   Penalty: Any person violating the terms and conditions of this
section shall be subject to a penalty not exceeding seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00), with each and every day that the violation of this section
is allowed to remain in effect being deemed a complete and separate offense.
In addition, the appropriate authorities of the village may take such other
actions they deem proper to enforce the terms and conditions of this section,
including, without limitation, an action in equity to compel compliance with
its terms. Any person violating the terms of this section shall be subject,
in addition to the foregoing penalties, to the payment of court costs and
reasonable attorney fees of the village.



(Ord. 2004-04, §§ 2, 3, 4, 3-8-2004; Ord. 2006-19, §§ 2, 3, 4, 5,
10-23-2006)



Secs. 11-15-11-30.  Reserved:



ARTICLE III.  WASTEWATER GENERALLY



DIVISION 1. GENERALLY



Sec. 11-31.  Definitions:



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   MSDGC: The metropolitan sanitary district of greater Chicago.



   OM&R: Operation and maintenance plus replacement.



   Sanitary Sewer: A sewer or drain for the drainage of water closets,
sinks, laundry tubs, bathtubs and similar fixtures.



   Storm Water Sewer: A sewer or drain for the drainage of roofs, lands,
foundations and surface water.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-54)



Sec. 11-32.  Treatment Required:



   It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the
village, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the village, any sewage or
other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in
accordance with subsequent provisions of this chapter.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-14)



Sec. 11-33.  Privies, Cesspools, Etc.:



   It shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault,
septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of
sewage.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-15)



Sec. 11-34.  Mandatory Connection To Facilities:



   The owner of all the houses, buildings or properties used for human
occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes situated within the
village is hereby required at his expense to install suitable toilet
facilities therein, and to connect such facilities directly with the proper
public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, within ninety
(90) days after date of official notice to do so.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-16)



Sec. 11-35.  Destruction Of Equipment:



   No unauthorized person shall maliciously, wilfully or negligently
break, damage, destroy, or tamper with any structure, appurtenance, or
equipment which is a part of the sewerage works. Any person violating this
provision shall be subject to immediate arrest under charge of disorderly
conduct.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-41)



Sec. 11-36.  Manual Of Procedures, Studies And Maps Adopted:



   (a)   “The Manual of Procedures for the Administration of the
Sewer Permit Ordinance of the Metropolitan Sanitary District of Greater
Chicago”, adopted September 3, 1970, is hereby adopted by reference as the
manual of procedures of the Village for sewer permits and sewerage systems,
and three (3) copies of such regulations on file with the village shall be
kept available for public use, inspection and examination.



   (b)   The following studies and maps that establish high-water
elevations and limits of flood plain based on the 100-year flood are adopted.
The data which will be used by the village is listed below in descending
order of overall accuracy, completeness and currentness. When data of higher
order becomes available, data of the lower order will not be used.



      (1)   HUD flood insurance studies (FIS), if certified by
Illinois Department of Transportation, Division of Water Resources (IDOT-DWR).



      (2)   (IDOT-DWR) regulatory flood plain maps and profiles.



      (3)   Soil Conservation Service-Metropolitan Sanitary District
of Greater Chicago (SCS-MSDGC) flood water management plans, using the
“without project” data shown therein.



      (4)   Other detailed 100-year flood studies, if certified by
IDOT-DWR.



      (5)   HUD flood hazard boundary maps (FHBM) and approximate
FIS data.



      (6)   USGS maps of flood-prone areas.



      (7)   USGS-NIPC hydrologic investigation atlases (floods of
record).



   (c)   The following requirements are adopted and made a part of the
building code ordinance1 by reference:



      (1)   Building Openings: A doorsill, windowsill, top of
foundation or the bottom of any other opening in the outer walls of a
building or structure shall be constructed at an elevation not lower than
twelve inches (12") above the established high-water elevation of the
100-year flood and not lower than twelve inches (12") above the high-water
elevation of the flood of record, if the 100-year flood information is not
available.



      (2)   Sanitary Manholes: All sanitary sewer manholes
constructed in the flood plain must be provided with watertight, lock-type
covers, or the rims must be raised to an elevation not lower than twelve
inches (12") above the high-water elevation.



   (d)   Any person violating any of the provisions of this section
shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) for each violation and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed for each day on which any such violation occurs or continues.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-52; Ord. 2009-15, § 50, 6-22-2009)



1  See also § 8-31 et seq., of thiscode.



Secs. 11-37-11-50.  Reserved:



DIVISION 2. SERVICE CHARGES; COLLECTION



Sec. 11-51.  Basis For Charges:



   (a)   The wastewater service charge for the use of and for service
supplied by the sewerage system of the village shall consist of a user charge
for operation and maintenance plus replacement and a debt service charge.



   (b)   The debt service charge is computed by dividing the annual
debt service of all outstanding loans and bonds, etc., by the number of users
to the sewer system, exclusive of those on sewers built by special
assessment. Through further divisions, the monthly debt service charge can be
computed.



   (c)   The user charge shall be computed separately for residential
and nonresidential users, so that each user class pays in proportion to its
water usage. The user charge shall be computed as follows:



      (1)   Annual Water Usage: Obtain annual water usage for the
residential and nonresidential user classes from the Justice-Willow Springs
water commission for the most recent one year period.



      (2)   Estimate: Estimate the projected annual revenue required
to operate and maintain the sewerage system including a replacement fund for
the year.



      (3)   Proportion: Proportion the estimated OM&R cost to each
user class by volume.



         Residential Users: Divide OM&R cost by the number of
residential users; or



         Nonresidential Users: Proportion the OM&R cost to each user
according to volume.



   (d)   The adequacy of the wastewater service charge shall be
reviewed, not less often than annually, by certified public accountants for
the village in their annual audit report. The wastewater service charge shall
be revised periodically to reflect a change in debt service costs or a change
in operation and maintenance costs including replacement costs.



   (e)   The users of wastewater treatment services will be notified
annually, in conjunction with a regular bill, of the rate and that portion of
the user charges which are attributable to the sewerage system operation,
maintenance and replacement.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-1)



Sec. 11-52.  Debt Service Charge:



(Rep. by Ord. 93-40, § 2, 10-25-1993)



Sec. 11-53.  User Charge:



   The following user charges shall be and are hereby established for the
use of and for service supplied by the wastewater facilities of the village:



      (1)   Residential User Class: Residential users are those
residential buildings containing one (1) or two (2) residential units. The
rate for sewer usage for residential users shall be charged as set forth in
section 13-1 of this code. The monthly flat rate for senior citizens who are
residential users and who qualify for the senior citizen discount for garbage
collection pursuant to subsection 5-260(b) of this code shall be discounted
by twenty-five percent (25%).



      (2)   Commercial, Institutional/Governmental And Industrial
User Class: The class of commercial users shall include multi-family
residential buildings containing three (3) or more residential units, as well
as institutional/governmental and industrial users of the sewerage system.
The rate for sewer usage for this class shall be charged as set forth in
section 13-1 of this code.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-3; Ord. 93-37, § 1, 9-27-1993; Ord. 93-40, § 1,
10-25-1993; Ord. 98-5, § 4, 2-9-1998; Ord. 2012-25, § 3, 9-24-2012)



Sec. 11-54.  Computation Of Wastewater Service Charge:



   The wastewater service charge shall be computed by the following
formula:



   Residential:



      CW = DS + UC



      Where:    CW = Amount of waste service charge ($) per billing
period



            DS = Debt service charge (section 11-52)



            UC = User charge for operation, maintenance and
replacement (section 11-53(1))



   Commercial, institutional, industrial:



      CW = DW + US x Vol.



      Where:    CW = Amount of waste service charge ($) per billing
period



            DS = Debt service charge (section 11-52)



            US = User charge for operation, maintenance and
replacement (section 11-53(3),(4))



            Vol. = Volume of water used for billing period.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-4)



Sec. 11-55.  Billing:



   (a)   The rates or charges for service set forth in this division
shall be payable bimonthly. The owner of the premises, the occupant thereof
and the user of the service shall be jointly and severally liable to pay for
the service to such premises and the service is furnished to the premises by
the village only upon the condition that the owner of the premises, occupant
and user of the services are jointly and severally liable therefor to the
village.



   (b)   Bills for sewer service shall be sent out by the village on
the first day of the month succeeding the period for which the service is
billed.



   (c)   All sewer bills are due and payable upon receipt. A penalty of
ten percent (10%) shall be charged all consumers who pay after the fifteenth
day of the billing month.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-5; Ord. 93-15, § 1, 7-12-93; Ord. 2009-14, § 7,
6-22-2009)



Sec. 11-56.  Delinquent Bills-Creation Of Lien; Notice.



   (a)   Whenever a bill for sewer service remains unpaid for thirty
(30) days after it has been rendered, the village attorney shall file with
the county recorder of deeds a statement of lien claim. This statement shall
contain the legal description of the premises served, the amount of the
unpaid bill, and a notice that the village claims a lien for this amount as
well as for all charges subsequent to the period covered by the bill and all
fees and costs incurred as a result of filing such lien.



   (b)   If the user whose bill is unpaid is not the owner of the
premises and the village attorney has notice of this, notice shall be mailed
to the owner of the premise, if his address be known to the village, whenever
such bill remains unpaid for the period of thirty (30) days after it has been
rendered.



   (c)   The failure of the village to record such lien or to mail such
notice or the failure of the owner to receive such notice shall not affect
the right to foreclose the lien for unpaid bills as mentioned in subsection
(a) of this section.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-6; Ord. 2009-14, § 7, 6-22-2009)



Sec. 11-57.  Same-Foreclosure Of Lien:



   Property subject to a lien for unpaid charges under this division shall
be sold for nonpayment of the same, and the proceeds of the sale shall be
applied to pay the charges, after deducting costs, as is the case in the
foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be by bill in equity
in the name of the village. The village attorney is hereby authorized and
directed to institute such proceedings in the name of the village in any
court having jurisdiction over such matters against any property for which
the bill has remained unpaid six (6) months after it has been rendered.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-7)



Sec. 11-58.  Disposition Of Revenues:



   (a)   All revenues and moneys derived from the operation of the
sewerage system shall be deposited in the sewer account. All such revenues
and moneys shall be held by the sewer and water treasurer separate and apart
from his private funds and separate and apart from all other funds of the
village and all of such sum, without any deductions whatsoever, shall be
delivered to the sewer and water treasurer not more than ten (10) days after
receipt of the same, or at such more frequent intervals as may, from time to
time, be directed by the president and board of trustees.



   (b)   The sewer and water treasurer shall receive all such revenues
from the sewerage system and all other funds and moneys incident to the
operation of such system as the same may be delivered to him and deposit the
same in the account of the fund designated as the sewer account of the
village. The treasurer shall administer such fund in every respect in the
manner provided in the Illinois Municipal Code, as amended1.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-8)



1  S.H.A. 65 ILCS 5/11-17-13.



Sec. 11-59.  System Of Accounts:



   (a)   The sewer and water treasurer shall establish a proper system
of accounts and shall keep proper books, records and accounts in which
complete and correct entries shall be made of all transactions relative to
the sewerage system, and at regular annual intervals he shall cause to be
made an audit by an independent auditing concern of the books to show the
receipts and disbursements of the sewerage system.



   (b)   In addition to the customary operating statements, the annual
audit report shall also reflect the revenues and operating expenses of the
sewerage system, including a replacement cost, to indicate that sewer service
charges under the sewer user charge system do in fact meet these regulations.
In this regard, the financial information to be shown in the audit report
shall include the following:



      (1)   Flow data showing total gallons of water consumption by
user class for the current fiscal year;



      (2)   Billing data to show total amount billed by user class
under the user charge for the current fiscal year;



      (3)   Numbers of users in each user class (each dwelling unit
shall be counted in the residential class);



      (4)   Debt service for the current fiscal year;



      (5)   Number of users to the sewerage system, excluding those
on sewers provided by special assessment;



      (6)   A list of commercial, institutional and industrial users
and volume of water used in the current fiscal year.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-9)



Sec. 11-60.  Notice Of Rates:



   Each user will be notified by the village in conjunction with a regular
bill, of the rate and that portion of the user charges which are attributable
to sewerage system services, including the financial information of section
11-55 of this division.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-10)



Sec. 11-61.  Village Records Available For Federal Inspection:



   The United States Environmental Protection Agency or its authorized
representative shall have access to any books, documents, papers and records
of the village which are applicable to the village system of user charges for
the purpose of making audit, examination, excerpt and transcriptions thereof
to ensure compliance with the terms of the federal regulations and conditions
of the federal grant.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-11)



Sec. 11-62.  Computation Appeals:



   The method for computation of rates and service charges established for
user charges in this division shall be made available to a user within five
(5) days of receipt of a written request for such. Any disagreement over the
method used or in the computations thereof shall be remedied by the president
and board of trustees within thirty (30) days after notification of a formal
written appeal outlining the discrepancies.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-12)



Sec. 11-63.  Special Fees:



   (a)   The rate to be charged the tollway commission plaza no. 38
under this division shall be five dollars fifty cents ($5.50) per connection
plus forty cents ($0.40) per one thousand (1,000) gallons of water used per
month.



   (b)   All other commercial and industrial (manufacturing,
warehousing, assembling or treating plants) shall be classified as special
users, and shall file application to the village for a special fee to be set
by the president and board of trustees.



   (c)   The rate to be charged to the village of Willow Springs for
sanitary sewers to be constructed and maintained by the village of Willow
Springs on Kean Avenue and extending along the south side of Eighty First
Street, from Kean Avenue to Cork Avenue on the east shall be one dollar
seventy five cents ($1.75) per month for each user and located in the village
of Willow Springs, Illinois. Such amount shall be paid in total on the first
day of each month by the village of Willow Springs. No user shall be granted
permission to hook up to the sanitary sewer line unless approval has been
received from the village.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-50; Ord. 93-40, § 3, 10-25-1993; Ord. 2009-15, § 51,
6-22-2009)



Sec. 11-64.  Sewer Permit Fees:



   (a)   For single-family residences and townhouses, the sewer permit
fee shall be two hundred seventy three dollars ($273.00) per unit plus a ten
dollar ($10.00) inspection fee per unit. If the sewer permit fee is waived,
an inspection fee will still be charged.



   (b)   For condominiums, apartment buildings and business
establishments, the sewer permit fee shall be two hundred seventy three
dollars ($273.00) plus twenty five dollars ($25.00) additional per unit for
sewer permit plus a ten dollar ($10.00) additional inspection charge per
building.



   (c)   The twenty five dollar ($25.00) deposit shall be refundable
after twelve (12) consecutive nondelinquent billings.



   (d)   Permits are good for a period of one year only.



   (e)   The following inspection fees will be charged for all main
sewers constructed in private property and village property:

(Code 1972, § 8-8-51)



Sec. 11-65.  Surcharge:



   (a)   A surcharge of ten dollars ($10.00) per month for each home,
condominium unit or individual apartment in violation according to the
listing of Sewer Systems Evaluations Inc., shall be imposed in addition to
all other charges heretofore authorized and imposed, beginning in June 1988.



   (b)   A sewer user may avoid further liability for payment of the
surcharge by requesting an inspection by the village plumbing inspector to
show that such user is in compliance with the ordinances and regulations
enumerated in ordinance 88-10.



   (c)   The surcharge shall be deemed to run with the land and shall
be binding on the heirs, successors, grantees, agents, lessees,
administrators, assigns or anyone else claiming, asserting or maintaining an
interest in the property of the sewer user and shall not be deemed to be
personal in nature.



   (d)   If a person is found to be in compliance as set forth in this
section and, upon subsequent inspection is found not to be in compliance,
such person shall be liable for payment of an amount equal to the sum of the
months since June 1988, multiplied by the monthly surcharge in effect during
such periods as the case may be; provided that, such liability shall be
reduced to fifty percent (50%) of such amount if such person complies within
a period of ten (10) days after notice by the village of his noncompliance.
If a person is found to be in a state of noncompliance a second or subsequent
time, then such person shall be liable for a sum equal to one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00), plus an amount equal to the sum of the months since June
1988, multiplied by the monthly surcharge in effect during such periods, as
the case may be.



(Ord. 88-10, §§ 2-5, 5-23-1988)



Secs. 11-66-11-75.  Reserved:



DIVISION 3. BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS



Sec. 11-76.  Permit Required:



   No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or
opening into, use, alter or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof
without first obtaining a written permit from the public works director.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-17; Ord. 2001-05, § 2, 2-26-2001)



Sec. 11-77.  Compliance With Federal Discharge Standards:



   All disposal by any person into the sewer system is unlawful except
those discharges in compliance with federal standards promulgated pursuant to
the federal act and more stringent state and local standards.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-18)



Sec. 11-78.  Application:



   (a)   Application for a building sewer permit shall be made by the
owner or his agent on a special form furnished by the village (reference
appendix 2 of the ordinance from which this section derives).



   (b)   The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans,
specifications or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of
the building commissioner.



   (c)   Permit and inspection fees in the following amounts shall be
paid to the village at the time the application is filed:



      (1)    Fees Generally: As of January 9, 2006, the sewer permit
shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00); plus an inspection fee of forty
dollars ($40.00).



         The fee charged will be set from time to time by the
president and board of trustees.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-19; Ord. 94-22, § 2, 10-24-1994; Ord. 95-7, § 2,
4-24-1995; Ord. 2006-02, § 6, 1-9-2006)



Sec. 11-79.  Sufficient Capacity:



   A building sewer permit will only be issued and a sewer connection
shall only be allowed if it can be demonstrated that the downstream sewerage
facilities, including sewers, and pump stations have sufficient capacity to
adequately and efficiently handle the additional anticipated waste load.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-20)



Sec. 11-80.  Costs And Expenses:



   All costs and expenses incident to the installation and connection of
the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the
village from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned
by the installation of the building sewer.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-21)



Sec. 11-81.  Separate Sewer For Each Building:



   A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every
building, except that where one building stands at the rear of another on an
interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the
rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or driveway, the
building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building
and the whole considered as one building sewer.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-22)



Sec. 11-82.  Inspection Of Old Sewers Prior To Use With New Buildings:



   Old building sewers may not be used in connection with new buildings.



   A twenty five dollar ($25.00) inspection fee will be charged for any
new lateral or replacement to be installed. The fee charged will be set from
time to time by the president and board of trustees.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-23; Ord. 95-7, § 1, 4-24-1995)



Sec. 11-83.  Construction Requirements:



   The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building
sewer, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe,
jointing, testing and backfilling the trench, shall all conform to the
requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and
regulations of the village. In the absence of code provisions or in
amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate
specifications of the American society of testing materials, water pollution
control federation manual of practice no. 9, and standard specifications for
water and sewer main construction in Illinois shall apply.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-24)



Sec. 11-84.  Elevations:



   Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building
at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any
building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer,
sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by a means
which is approved by the plumbing inspector in accordance with section 11-57
of this article, and discharged to the building sewer.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-25)



Sec. 11-85.  Surface Runoff, Groundwater Drains Not To Be Connected To
Building Sewers:



   No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation
drains, areaway drains or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a
building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or
indirectly to a public sanitary sewer.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-26)



Sec. 11-86.  Connections To Conform To Applicable Codes, Procedures:



   The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall
conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code, or other
applicable rules and regulations of the village, or the procedures set forth
in appropriate specifications of the American Society of Testing Materials,
Water Pollution Control Federation Manual of Practice No. 9, and Standard
Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction of Illinois. All such
connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Any deviation from the
prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the building
commissioner and plumbing inspector before installation.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-27)



Sec. 11-87.  Inspections.



   The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the plumbing
inspector when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to
the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the
plumbing inspector or his representative.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-28)



Sec. 11-88.  Use Of Barricades, Lights At Excavations; Restoration Of
Property:



   All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately
guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard.
Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the
course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the village.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-29)



Sec. 11-89.  Standards For Connection To Sewer System:



   (a)   All connections shall conform to the following specifications:



      (1)    The house connection shall be at least six (6) inches
in internal diameter, excepting that when cast-iron soil pipe is used, the
house connection shall be at least four (4) inches in internal diameter. The
slope or grade shall be at least one-eighth inch to one (1) foot and not more
than one-quarter inch to one (1) foot.



      (2)    The vitrified pipe in this improvement shall be made of
clay or shale, or a combination of these materials, to be hard-burned,
salt-glazed and free from cracks, flaws and laminations. Pipe shall be of
bell and spigot type and is recommended not less than three (3) feet in
length and shall have a shell thickness of not less than five-eighths inch.



      (3)    The necessary excavation and shoring shall be shaped to
fit the bottom one-half of the pipe.



      (4)    Where vitreous tile is used for the sewer line and
shall pass within ten (10) feet of any well, then the tile shall be laid in
the following manner: Thirty-pound weight building felt material shall be
laid in the trench long enough to extend twenty-five (25) feet in either
direction of the well. The tile pipe shall be laid thereon with an added seal
of the required asphalt material being applied onto the joints and then
wrapping the pipe with the aforementioned felt to envelope the pipe for this
distance.



      (5)    All trenches for house drains where construction has
taken place in roadway and driveway areas shall be backfilled with natural
sand containing not more than four (4) percent clay or with limestone
screenings. Trenches in other areas may be backfilled with the excavated
materials.



      (6)    All materials of every kind and character to be used in
the construction of this improvement shall be of first class quality,
suitable for the purposes for which they are provided and used, and subject
to the inspection of the village sewer inspector.



   (b)   All work in connection of the house service connection shall
be under the control and subject to inspection and approval by the village.
The trench excavation for the house service connection shall not be
backfilled until it has been inspected and approved by a duly authorized
representative of the village.



   (c)   Any connection between rainwater downspouts, surface water or
groundwater drains shall not be permitted with the sanitary sewerage system.



   (d)   Each house, dwelling or commercial establishment shall have a
separate and complete sanitary sewerage service which shall be independent
from that of any other adjacent building or structure, except in the case of
multiple-family dwellings or commercial establishments so arranged as to
cause independent services to be impractical.



   (e)   Each sanitary sewerage connection shall be made at the Y
branch provided for that property. The location of the Y branch shall be
designated by the village.



   (f)   Portions of existing residential sanitary sewerage systems may
be used in connection with the installation of the new sanitary sewerage
service provided such existing piping is approved for reuse by the village
sewer inspector. The sewer inspector may require that portions or all of the
existing pipe to be reused shall be uncovered for inspection purposes. No
cesspool or septic tank shall be connected to any portion of the sanitary
sewerage service connections upon its completion.



   (g)   With respect to commercial establishments, grease
traps/interceptors shall be installed in accordance with section 11-92 of
this code.



   (h)   All sewer taps that are made in the village shall be made by
the village tapper. The village tapper shall be appointed by the village
board. No private contractor shall tap any sewer in the village unless
approved by the building commissioner or appointed inspector.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-53; Ord. 2009-02, § 2, 2-9-2009)



Sec. 11-90.  Manholes.



   (a)   Where it is necessary to make a change in direction of the
house sewer between the building and public sewer, such change of direction
shall be made by means of a manhole to be constructed as the building
commissioner shall direct.



   (b)   All manholes and gravel basins shall be constructed of
concrete, either monolithic or block, composed by volume of one (1) part
portland cement, two (2) parts sand and four (4) parts gravel or crushed
stone, mixed with sufficient water. They shall be circular in section, with
an interior diameter of three (3) feet except that the top shall be drawn in
to two (2) feet beginning at a point three (3) feet below the top, so as to
fit and support the cover. The walls of such manhole or gravel basin shall be
four (4) inches in thickness if built monolithic, or five (5) inches if built
of blocks with full joints of mortar composed of one (1) part portland cement
to two (2) parts of sharp clean sand, mixed with sufficient water. Each
manhole or gravel basin shall be provided with a six-inch concrete floor with
the invert, if any, moulded smoothly in the concrete or formed of section of
vitrified pipe imbedded in the concrete. Each manhole or gravel basin shall
be provided with a cast-iron cover and cast-iron or concrete frame. The floor
of all gravel basins shall be three (3) feet below the flow line of the
outlet.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-55)



Sec. 11-91.  Garage drainage.



   Floor drains of garages shall be connected with the sanitary sewer
system. Such drains shall have intercepting grease traps approved by the
building commissioner.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-57)



Sec. 11-92.  Grease Trap/Interceptor Requirements:



   (1)   Grease trap/interceptor requirements: Grease, oil, and sand
interceptors shall be provided when in the opinion of the village they are
necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes, containing grease in
excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand, or other harmful
ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be required for private
living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and
capacity approved by the village, and shall be located as to be readily and
easily accessible for cleaning and inspection.



   (2)   Definitions: For the purposes of this article, the following
words and terms shall have the meanings prescribed:



      a.   Approved Grease Handler means a vehicle operated by a
licensee that is validly permitted by and is inscribed with such permit
numbers issued by the Illinois Department of Agriculture pursuant to the
Illinois Dead Animal Disposal Act (225 ILCS 610/1.1 et seq.).



      b.   Facility means a place, business or establishment within
the village which may cause the discharge of wastewater.



      c.   Grease Trap/Interceptor means a constructed device,
whether installed inside or outside, and its appurtenant surfaces and working
parts, with the function of removing fats, oils, and grease from wastewaters
before such wastewaters are discharged into village sewers.



      d.   Prohibited Concentration means discharges of wastewaters
from a grease trap/interceptor in the village shall not exceed two hundred
fifty milligrams per liter (250 mg/l) total of fats, oils and grease in any
sample, whether obtained as a composite or grab sample.



   (3)   Required Installations And Use Of Grease Trap/Interceptors:



      a.   Each person or operating facility within the village,
other than a private residence, which is or will be used for the manufacture,
processing or preparation of food or food products must install and use, at
its own expense, an appropriately sized grease trap/interceptor utilizing
industry standards, and calculating the level of wastewater that the facility
is anticipated to generate.



      b.   Exterior grease trap/interceptors and interior grease
trap/interceptors shall not be constructed, repaired, or maintained without a
permit issued by the building department.



   (4)   Required Cleaning, Maintenance, And Inspection of Grease
Trap/Interceptors:



      a.   Each person who owns or operates a grease
trap/interceptor shall cause collected or trapped fats, oils, and grease to
be cleaned and removed from such device on a periodic basis by an approved
and State of Illinois licensed grease hauler, and delivered to a facility
authorized to use, treat, or dispose of such material. Clean out and removal
shall be done on not less than a monthly basis unless the village determines
that a less or more frequent maintenance schedule is required to achieve the
purposes of this article and to minimize the discharge of a prohibited
concentration of fats, oils, or grease. The owner may request a revised
schedule upon written application to the building department.



      b.   The structural integrity of the grease trap/interceptor
shall be considered to ensure that safety and function are maintained.
Inspections performed at the time of the cleaning should note the structural
condition of the grease trap/interceptor, and provide notice of any required
service to the owner. A decaying structure, as determined by the village,
must either be replaced or repaired.



      c.   The village may make, without notice to the owner or
facility, periodic inspections of the grease trap/interceptor to verify
current operating conditions. If the operating condition of the grease
trap/interceptor is found to not be in compliance with village standards, the
owner shall be required to take immediate action to correct such deficiencies
with the grease trap/interceptor.



      d.   If the owner does not correct the deficiencies noted by
the village, the village may cause the grease trap/interceptor and private
sewer lines to be properly cleaned and maintained, either through village
staff or through private parties hired by the village.



      e.   The owner of the grease trap/interceptor will be held
liable for all costs incurred by the village, including labor, materials,
administrative costs, and outside contractors, as a result of the cleaning or
maintenance operation.



      f.   The business license or other annual business related
license may be suspended, revoked, or not renewed if the owner fails to
reimburse the village for incurred expense. In addition to revocation of
business license under this section, the village shall have the right to
record a lien against the premises where the business is located according to
section 11-92(10) of this code.



      g.   No fats, oils, or grease removed from a grease
trap/interceptor may be offered to a person for transportation nor
transported off the site except by an approved grease hauler licensed by the
village.



   (5)   Prohibition Of Discharge Of Fats, Oils And Grease:



      a.   No person shall discharge a prohibited concentration of
fats, oils, or grease into village sewers, from a facility required to
install, use, and maintain a grease trap/interceptor.



      b.   No person shall reintroduce or deposit into a grease
trap/interceptor or village sewer system any water, liquids, fats, oils, or
grease or any other content which have been blocked and removed from entering
into the sewer system by a grease trap/interceptor anywhere in or outside of
the village.



      c.   No person shall recycle, filter, clean or otherwise
process and then deposit any liquids, fats, oils, or grease or any other
content from a grease trap/interceptor back into a grease trap/interceptor or
the sewer system. The use of any on site mobile filtering system which
results in the deposit of any content taken from a grease trap/interceptor or
sewer system is strictly prohibited.



      d.   As a result of a prohibited discharge, the village may
cause the sewer main lines to be cleaned. The owner of the grease
trap/interceptor or person causing the prohibited discharge shall be held
liable for all costs incurred by the village, including labor, materials,
administrative costs, and outside contractors, as a result of the cleaning
operations.



      e.   The business license or other annual business related
license may be suspended, revoked, or not renewed if the owner fails to
reimburse the village for incurred expenses.



   (6)   Prohibitions Of Introduction Of Enzymes And Emulsifiers: No
person shall introduce, nor allow the introduction of physical, chemical or
biological agents into, grease trap/interceptors for the purpose of
suspending, dissolving, emulsifying or rendering soluble any fats, oils or
grease removed from wastewater by such grease trap/interceptors and
reintroducing them into the village sewer system.



   (7)   Licensing Of Grease Haulers: Each business, person, or owner
of any vehicle permitted by the state of Illinois doing business in the
village of Justice shall secure and maintain a village grease transporter
license. Applications for a village grease transporter license shall be filed
with the building department and shall require the payment of a one hundred
fifty dollars ($150.00) annual license fee. No person shall operate a vehicle
used to transport fats, oils, or grease collected from a grease
trap/interceptor within the village except in compliance with the Illinois
Dead Animal Disposal Act and regulations issued thereunder by the Department
of Agriculture. No person shall operate a vehicle used to transport fats,
oils, or grease collected from a grease trap/interceptor within the village
except if licensed as a village grease transporter.



   (8)   Record Keeping Requirements For Grease Trap/Interceptor Owners
And Grease Haulers;



      a.   No person may cause or allow the transportation of fats,
oils, or grease away from the grease trap/interceptor at which such materials
were collected unless such materials are accompanied by a shipping paper
containing the information required by the Illinois Department of Agriculture.



      b.   The grease trap/interceptor owner or operator and
transporter shall each retain a copy of the shipping document for a minimum
of two (2) years, and shall produce the documents upon request of the village.



      c.   Applications for a village grease trap/interceptor
transporter license shall be made upon the usual village license forms.



      d.   Each shipping paper shall, at a minimum, provide the
information required under the Dead Animal Disposal Act and regulations
issued thereunder by the Illinois Department of Agriculture.



      e.   A copy of the shipping paper shall be delivered or faxed
to the building department within five (5) days after each collection.



   (9)   Penalties: Except where otherwise provided in this code, any
person convicted of a violation of any provision of this code shall be fined
in a sum not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for any one
offense. Each day that the owner or operator of a grease trap/interceptor or
grease hauler is in non-compliance, shall be construed as a separate offense
and subject to the fine described above.



   (10)   Creation Of Lien; Notice; Foreclosure Of Lien:



      a.   If the owner fails to reimburse the village for incurred
expenses for the installation or repair of a grease trap/interceptor as noted
in section 11-92(4)e. of this code, within thirty (30) days after notice of
such expense has been rendered, the village attorney shall file with the
county recorder of deeds a statement of lien claim. This statement shall
contain the legal description of the premises served, the amount of the
unpaid bill, and a notice that the village claims a lien for this amount as
well as for all charges subsequent to the period covered by the bill and all
fees and costs incurred as a result of filing such lien.



      b.   If the  business owner whose bill is unpaid is not the
owner of the premises and the village attorney has notice of this, notice
shall be mailed to the owner of the premise, if his address be known to the
collector, whenever such bill remains unpaid for the period of thirty (30)
days after it has been rendered.



      c.   The failure of the village to record such lien or to mail
such notice of the failure of the owner to receive such notice shall not
affect the right to foreclose the lien for unpaid bills as mentioned in
subsection a. of this section.



      d.   Property subject to alien for unpaid charges under this
division shall be sold for nonpayment of the same, and the proceeds of the
sale shall be applied to pay the charges, after deducting costs, as is the
case in the foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be by bill
in equity in the name of the village. The village attorney is hereby
authorized and directed to institute such proceedings in the name of the
village in any court having jurisdiction over such matters against any
property for which the bill has remained unpaid six (6) months after it has
been rendered.



(Ord. 2009-02, § 3, 2-9-2009)



Secs. 11-93-11-105.  Reserved:



DIVISION 4. USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS



Sec. 11-106.  Discharges Generally:



   No person shall discharge, or cause to be discharged, any storm water,
surface water, ground water, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated
cooling water or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-30)



Sec. 11-107.  Storm Sewers:



   Storm water and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to
such sewers as are specifically designated as combined sewers or storm
sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the plumbing inspector. Industrial
cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged on approval of
the plumbing inspector to a storm sewer, combined sewer or natural outlet.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-31)



Sec. 11-108.  Prohibited Discharges-Generally:



   No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the
following described waters or wastes to any public sewers:



      (1)    Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil or other
flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas;



      (2)    Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous
solids, liquids or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by
interaction with other wastes, to injure or interfere with any sewage
treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public
nuisance, or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage
treatment plant;



      (3)    Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5 or
having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to
structures, equipment and personnel of the sewage works;



      (4)    Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such
size capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other
interference with the proper operating of the sewage works such as, but not
limited to, ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags,
feathers, tar, plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure,
hair and fleshings, entrails, paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc.,
either whole or ground by garbage grinders.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-32)



Sec. 11-109.  Prohibited Discharges-Dangerous Substances Enumerated:



   No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following
described substances, materials, waters or wastes if it appears likely in the
opinion of the public works director that such wastes can harm either the
sewers, sewage treatment process or equipment; have an adverse effect on the
receiving stream; or can otherwise endanger life, limb or public property, or
constitute a nuisance. In forming his opinion as to the acceptability of
these wastes, the public works director will give consideration to such
factors as the quantities of subject wastes in relation to flows and
velocities in the sewers, the materials of construction of the sewers, the
nature of the sewage treatment process, the capacity of the sewage treatment
plant and the maximum limits established by regulatory agencies. The
substances prohibited are:



      (1)    Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than
one hundred fifty degrees Fahrenheit (150°F) (65°C);



      (2)    Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous
materials or oils, whether emulsified or not, in excess of one hundred
milligrams per liter (100 mg/l) or containing substances which may solidify
or become viscous at temperatures between thirty two (32) and one hundred
fifty degrees Fahrenheit (150°F) (0° and 65°C);



      (3)    Any garbage that has not been properly shredded; the
installation and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of
three-fourths horsepower (0.76 hp metric) or greater shall be subject to the
review and approval of the plumbing inspector;



      (4)    Any waters or wastes containing strong acid iron
pickling wastes or concentrated plating solution, whether neutralized or not;



      (5)    Any waters or wastes containing iron, chromium, copper,
zinc or similar objectionable or toxic substances, or wastes exerting an
excessive chlorine requirement, to such degree that any such material
received in the composite sewage at the sewage treatment works exceeds the
limits established by the MSDGC for such materials;



      (6)    Any waters or wastes containing phenols or other taste
or odor producing substances, in such concentrations exceeding limits which
may be established by the MSDGC as necessary after treatment of the composite
sewage, to meet the requirements of the state, federal or other public
agencies or jurisdiction for such discharge to the receiving waters;



      (7)    Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half life or
concentration as may exceed limits established by the MSDGC in compliance
with applicable state or federal regulations;



      (8)    Any wastes or waters having a pH in excess of 9.5;



      (9)    Any mercury or any of its compounds in excess of 0.005
milligrams per liter as Hg at the time except as permitted by the MSDGC in
compliance with applicable state and federal regulations;



      (10)    Any cyanide in excess of 0.025 milligrams per liter at
any time as permitted by the MSDGC in compliance with applicable state and
federal regulations;



      (11)    Materials which exert or cause:



         a.    Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids
(such as, but not limited to, fuller's earth, lime slurries and lime
residues) or of dissolved solids (such as, but not limited to, sodium
chloride and sodium sulfate);



         b.    Excessive discoloration (such as, but not limited
to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions);



         c.    Unusual BOD, chemical oxygen demand or chlorine
requirements in such quantities as to constitute a significant load on the
sewage treatment works;



         d.    Unusual volume of flow or concentrations of wastes
constituting slugs.



      (12)    Waters or wastes containing substances which are not
amenable to treatment or reduction by the sewage treatment processes
employed, or are amenable to treatment only to such degree that the sewage
treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of agencies having
jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-33; Ord. 2001-05, § 2, 2-26-2001)



Sec. 11-110.  Remedies For Improper Discharge:



   (a)   If any waters or wastes are discharged or are proposed to be
discharged to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or
possess the characteristics enumerated in section 11-109 of this division
and/or which are in violation of the standards for pretreatment provided in
40 CFR 403, June 26, 1978, and any amendments thereto, and which in the
judgment of the public works director may have a deleterious effect upon the
sewage works, processes, equipment or receiving waters, or which otherwise
create a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the public works
director may:



      (1)    Reject the wastes;



      (2)    Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for
discharge to the public sewers;



      (3)    Require control over the quantities and rates of
discharge; and/or



      (4)    Require payment to cover the added costs of handling
and treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges, under
the provisions of section 11-60 of this article.



   (b)   If the public works director permits the pretreatment or
equalization of waste flows, the design and installation of the plants and
equipment shall be subject to the review and approval of the president and
village board, and subject to the requirements of all applicable codes,
ordinances and laws.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-34; Ord. 2001-05, § 2, 2-26-2001)



Sec. 11-111.  Interceptors:



   Grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be provided when in the
opinion of the building commissioner they are necessary for the proper
handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any
flammable wastes, sand or other harmful ingredients; except, that such
interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling
units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the
building commissioner, and shall be located as to be readily and easily
accessible for cleaning and inspection.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-35)



Sec. 11-112.  Maintenance Of Preliminary Treatment Facilities:



   Where preliminary treatment or flow equalizing facilities are provided,
they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation
by the owner at his expense.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-36)



Sec. 11-113.  Control Manholes; Meters, Other Appurtenances:



   Each industry may be required to install a control manhole and, when
required by the public works director, the owner of any property serviced by
a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control
manhole together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the
building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the
wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located,
and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the building
commissioner. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his expense, and
shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-37; Ord. 2001-05, § 2, 2-26-2001)



Sec. 11-114.  Tests:



   (a)   The owner of any property serviced by a building sewer
carrying industrial wastes shall provide laboratory measurements, tests, and
analyses of waters and wastes to illustrate compliance with this chapter and
any special conditions for discharge established by the village or regulatory
agencies having jurisdiction over the discharge.



   (b)   The number, type and frequency of laboratory analyses to be
performed by the owner shall be as stipulated by the village. The owner shall
report the results of measurements and laboratory analyses to the village at
such times and in such a manner as prescribed by the village. The owner shall
bear the expense of all measurements, analyses, and reporting required by the
village. At such times as deemed necessary the village reserves the right to
take measurements and samples for analyses by an outside laboratory service.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-38)



Sec. 11-115.  Additional Test Requirements:



   All measurements, tests and analyses of the characteristics of waters
and wastes to which reference is made in this chapter shall be determined in
accordance with the latest edition of IEPA division of laboratories' manual
of laboratory methods, and shall be determined at the control manhole
provided, or upon suitable samples taken at the control manhole. If no
special manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to
be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which
the building sewer is connected. Sampling shall be carried out by customarily
accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works
and to determine the existence of hazards to life, limb and property. The
particular analyses involved will determine whether a twenty four (24) hour
composite of all outfalls of a premises is appropriate or whether a grab
sample or samples should be taken. Normally, but not always, BOD and
suspended solids analyses are obtained from twenty four (24) hour composites
of all outfalls, whereas pH is determined from periodic grab samples.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-39)



Sec. 11-116.  Special Agreements:



   No statement contained in this chapter shall be construed as preventing
any special agreement or arrangement between the village or MSDGC and any
industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or
character may be accepted by the village and MSDGC for conveyance and
treatment, subject to payment therefor by the industrial concern, in
accordance with division 2 of this article, and applicable MSDGC ordinances,
provided such payments are in accordance with federal and state guidelines
for user charge system.



(Code 1972, § 8-8-40)



Sec. 11-117.  Discharges Into Storm Sewer Or Drainage Facility:



   No person shall discharge any sanitary waste or industrial wastewater
into any storm sewer or drainage facility.



(Ord. 87-27, § 1, 9-14-1987)



Sec. 11-118.  Footing Drain Discharge; Surface And Subsurface Water Drainage:



   It shall be unlawful for the owner, agent or other person in control or
possession of any premises jointly or severally to permit any eaves trough,
footing drain, drain downspout, piping, sump pump or other device or
appliance, permanent or temporary, above or below grade, for collecting and
discharging surface water, rainwater or any other source of surface runoff
water, ground water or subsurface water to be so designed, located or
constructed over or across any street, alley, public way, or any rights of
way thereof, or public property other than by means of a village approved
storm sewer, drainage swale or other drainage system structure. No such water
shall be collected and discharged on any adjoining property. All such waters
must be discharged on the owner's property, and no such waters shall be
collected and discharged closer than six feet (6') from the side or rear lot
line of the premises unless it is enclosed in a subsurface drainage system
approved by the village which discharges such water at or near the front
property line or at a point no closer than ten feet (10') from the rear
property line; provided, however, if there is a public sidewalk on or
adjacent to the subject property, no such waters shall be collected and
discharged closer than six feet (6') from any such sidewalk. At no point will
the village allow any piping in public right of way, nor any discharging at
the back of curb unless by written approval from the village. During winter
months (November through March) all pipes that are now located in public
rights of way will be disconnected and discharged onto the ground.



(Ord. 91-21, § 1, 7-22-1991)



Sec. 11-119.  Reserved:



ARTICLE IV. EMERGENCY TELEPHONE SYSTEM1 1



1  50 ILCS 750/1.



Sec. 11-120.  System Surcharge; Conditions Of Imposition:



   A surcharge is hereby imposed, subject to the provisions of section
11-121 of this article, upon the monthly billed subscribers of
telecommunication carriers residing within the village for funding of a 9-1-1
emergency telephone system.



(Ord. 91-3, § 1, 1-14-1991)



Sec. 11-121.  Surcharge Referendum:



   A referendum shall be placed by the village clerk on the April 2, 1991,
ballot for all legal voters residing in the village to vote upon the
following question:



   Shall the village of Justice impose a surcharge of up to one dollar
twenty-five cents ($1.25) per month per network connection, which surcharge
will be added to the monthly bill you receive for telephone or
telecommunication charges for the purpose of installing a 9-1-1 emergency
telephone system?



          Yes           No



(Ord. 91-3, § 2, 1-14-1991)



Sec. 11-122.  Majority Vote Imposes Surcharge:



   If a majority of the votes cast upon the question are in favor thereof,
a surcharge is hereby imposed on monthly billed subscribers of
telecommunication carriers residing within the village at a rate of up to one
dollar twenty five cents ($1.25) per month per "network connection", as
hereinafter defined.



(Ord. 91-3, § 3, 1-14-1991)



Sec. 11-123.  System Subscribers Identified:



   A monthly billed subscriber shall be deemed to reside within the
village if the "service address", as hereinafter defined, is located within
the village.



(Ord. 91-3, § 4, 1-14-1991)



Sec. 11-124.  Definitions:



   For purposes of this article the following definitions shall apply:



   Network Connection: The number of voice grade communication channels
directly between a subscriber and a telecommunication carrier's switched
network which would be required to carry the subscriber's interpremises
traffic.



   Service Address: The location of the subscriber's telecommunication
facilities accessing the network connection or connection(s) that are subject
to the surcharge. If this is not a defined location, "service address" shall
mean the location of a subscriber's primary use of the network connection as
defined by telephone number, authorization code, or location in Illinois
where bills are sent.



   Telecommunication Carrier: Any natural individual, firm, trust, estate,
partnership, association, joint stock company, joint adventure, corporation,
municipal corporation or political subdivision of this state, or a receiver,
trustee, conservator or other representative appointed by order of any court
engaged in the business of transmitting messages by means of electricity.



(Ord. 91-3, § 5, 1-14-1991)



Sec. 11-125.  Exemptions To Surcharge:
